TALK.START.PARA: —I return to the debate regarding the wheat marketing legislation. There is only one reason why the situation that I was alluding to before putting those tables on the record was possible. Throughout it all, since 1989, the coalition held firm on the two major elements of the policy: the retention of the Wheat Board's export monopoly and an underwriting arrangement, which is still better than the Government's improved position, which forms part of this legislation, of a constant 85 per cent borrowing guarantee through to the year 1999. Obviously, the deteriorating international situation has added some urgency to the legislation, and it has also provided another element for such legislation.

PARA.TAB: This legislation does buy time for the industry until 1999. By that time the wheat industry fund will have built up to between $400m and $500m, providing an adequate base for the industry if at that time there are changes to the marketing arrangements. Therefore, one would see that industry fund as a transitional arrangement.

I am aware of concern in parts of the wheat industry, in particular in Western Australia, where it queries, on the one hand, the levy, and whether or not it will increase—and the Minister has indicated the procedure that is necessary before that can occur—and, on the other hand, its use for certain value adding activities. I am sure that my colleague Senator Panizza will comment in that regard. In Queensland there is concern—and I am sure that Senator Boswell will comment on this—but for a different reason, and that is because the capital provided for the trading activities of the Wheat Board is claimed by Queensland industry representatives to provide unfair competition against their own organisation, Grainco. Overall, there appears to be support for that wheat industry fund, but there is certainly concern that it should not increase beyond the 2 per cent, that it should be closely monitored and that it should be recognised as a transitional levy.

For some time the Wheat Board has indicated that there is a need for greater flexibility if it is to achieve what it and the wheat industry want to achieve with regard to sensible joint ventures and value adding. That has been the case for some time. Whether or not there is a need for a separate board, time will tell.

That is something that the coalition will closely monitor, because we question whether there is such a need for a separate subsidiary company. But we are not trying to impose any sort of opposition to that element of the legislation, other than to monitor it from our point of view and the industry's point of view.

The coalition parties support this legislation. We recognise that it does come in time for the Wheat Board and the wheat industry to provide those guarantees for future contractual arrangements and harvests beyond the present one. As far as the coalition is concerned, the only change to the legislation between now and the review, which obviously will occur prior to 1999, will be a change to bring in our underwriting commitment for the 1994 and subsequent harvests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1992. Perhaps I can tell the Senate the official reason for the introduction of this Bill. To do so, I can do no better than to quote from the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean). The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to implement a package of measures to enhance the future of the Australian wheat industry. The package provides a framework for the development of a vertically integrated industry to the end of the century. It has the endorsement of the peak wheat grower body, the Grains Council of Australia.

That is the official reason, but I believe that the real reason for amending the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 is the failed Newco proposal that was propounded by the Minister and the Grains Council of Australia. I have never really been able to get to the bottom of who proposed it, whether it came from the supposed peak body or whether it came from the Minister himself imposing his views on the industry.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators may remember that the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 did away with the regulated domestic market. I believe that that has been a positive move. The Wheat Marketing Act gave the Australian Wheat Board sole marketing rights to export wheat, and rightly so. As well, the underwriting fee levied by the industry was reduced by 2.5 per cent per year.

The idea of Newco was to set up a private organisation with sole overseas marketing rights for Australian wheat, as well as the right to deal in the domestic market. The problem with the Government giving sole export marketing to a private organisation was very apparent to the industry at large in that the arrangement would not stand up to a High Court challenge. The private grain exporters would certainly have knocked that arrangement over in a High Court action.

As Senator Tambling has stated, the Grains Council of Australia, with the Minister, set up meetings around Australia. Unfortunately, there was a lot of misinformation put out at those meetings. Fortunately, however, Opposition members and senators were able to attend those meetings. They put to the meetings the coalition's proposals for the industry and were able to put the meetings straight. The coalition position was being misrepresented. In fact, the growers were being told that the coalition's position was exactly the same as that of the Government. Nothing could be further from the truth.

The coalition's position, as Senator Tambling has already said, is to return to 95 per cent of underwriting of the borrowings, thus allowing the AWB to be able to pay a reasonable first advance. That is the position that we arrived at. The Minister, in his second reading speech, also said:

SPEECH.PARA: I had earlier expressed reservations about aspects of the proposal.
This was after those meetings—
Moreover, after the consultative process was complete, it was clear that the Newco proposal in its original form did not have the support of the majority of growers—

No, it did not. I attended three of the meetings in Western Australia and my colleague, the honourable member for O'Connor, Wilson Tuckey, attended the fourth meeting. He caused a furore when he put the coalition position. I saw only two growers out of probably 1,000 to 1,400 growers put their hands up. That could hardly be described as majority support. I would say that it was the understatement of the year. There was another point that I wanted to make. The Minister further said:
On the question of the Wheat Board's export monopoly, it is clear that the majority of growers favour the continuation of the Wheat Board's single desk export operations.

Once again, on that question, at all the meetings held in Western Australia only two growers voted against the single desk operation. I think that that is also an understatement. Of course, on that point, as Senator Tambling has already said, while there is a corrupt world market we have to keep that sole export.

PARA.TAB: So, Newco and the GCA having failed in the growers meetings, the Minister came up with the present proposal. Basically, the present proposal is to retain until 1999 what we brought into this Parliament in 1989. As has already been pointed out, the underwriting is to go back to 85 per cent of the estimated pool return, whereas under the coalition it would be 95 per cent. Sole export powers are to stay, as I have already said. The Minister is not very definite in this regard in his second reading speech and I will be asking questions later in the committee stage to see how definite he is as far as the AWB retaining the sole export market is concerned.

I turn to the big push by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, towards value adding of the grain crop of Australia. I ask: how much can we really value add wheat? I can do no better than to quote from an article by one of my colleagues, Senator Peter Walsh—a colleague in wheat growing, I may add. I could probably say that he is a colleague in this place most of the time. He said:

The economic viability of further processing or adding value to raw materials is dependent upon the relative internal cost of processing and the freight savings which accrue to reducing the volume and weight of raw materials.

Thus, Australian bauxite is converted to alumina or aluminium. Copper is always concentrated or smelted before being exported. But the economics of processing wheat are vastly different. . . Further processing of wheat invariably increases its bulk and at best marginally reduces its weight.

SPEECH.PARA: If the bulk of the value added product is greater than the original bulk of grain, then there are no freight advantages; there are many freight disadvantages. As Senator Walsh says in the article, 30 years ago a big proportion of the Australian wheat crop was exported as flour. That is no longer the case. Anyone who travels around Australia will see disused flour mills. Some are derelict; others have been turned into other outfits, like seed cleaning outfits. The main reason for the decline was the freight cost. By the mid-1960s, freight costs took off. I quote Senator Walsh again:

PARA.TAB: Possibly a levy on wheat sales could fund offshore capital investment in wheat processing in the hope that this would maximise Australian wheat sales and returns.

SPEECH.PARA: The precedents have been set with the Australian Dairy Corporation. More disastrous lately has been the wool industry, where a levy on growers was used. Basically, that is how I view value adding in Australia. So much for the Bill.

PARA.TAB: I now turn to the real bone of contention in Western Australia that was flagged by my colleague Senator Grant Tambling and that is the wheat industry fund. A deal was done in 1989 between the Grains Council of Australia, our supposed peak body, and the Minister whereby we were to try to build up a fund of $400m to help fund the first advance after which this underwriting by the Government was to be done away with. Those contributions were 2 per cent of gross, which might not seem a lot to people in this chamber but which has a big effect on the ultimate net profits of a farmer. The fund is also going to be used for value adding. There is much resentment in being forced into value adding. After all, if someone wants to invest in value adding, he has a proper structure, a prospectus, a board of directors and all those sorts of things before he gets into it.

If value adding for wheat in Australia were so good, private enterprise would take it up without a levy from the wheat growers and that would be it; that would be sweet. What worries a lot of growers in Western Australia is that the fund is compulsory. Growers who are in strife, who have been forced out of farming and that sort of thing, still have money in that fund but cannot get it out. There are farmers who have gone into bankruptcy who have certain moneys in the fund which they cannot get out. If they have become bankrupt and have gone off the farm they have problems in getting social security, Jobstart or anything like that. A particular grower was on the phone to tell me that he has been knocked back for Jobstart because he has a certain amount of money in the fund which he cannot get out.

Also, there is a problem when a grower dies leaving money in the fund that his family cannot get hold of. When a farmer gets out of the industry altogether, sells his land and gets out, there is a problem with this money in the fund that he cannot get out. I know of no other situation, whether it be superannuation or anything like that, where, if people get out of a job or an industry, they cannot take their money with them.

The coalition listened to these people who came over from Western Australia to lobby. We decided at our coalition grains committee that we should go down the line perhaps of moving an amendment to this Bill to make it possible to get those funds out for those growers who are affected. We came up with a draft amendment that I prepared. Until the Minister does something about getting funds out for other reasons, for the present moment the amendment deals with money being paid out in the case of the death of a farmer. I have been told by some people that in the case of death the money will not do much good for the individual, but certainly it will be of use to the family. I have also been told, in the case of a bankruptcy, that it does not do the bankrupt much good because the money finishes up with the banks anyhow. Not all banks chase the money that is owed. But, of course, if they did, it would cut down the indemnity to the bank, and those people would be able to get out of bankruptcy sooner.

Then there is the situation when a farmer gets out of the industry by selling his land. I am not referring to a case of a farmer growing wheat for one year, selling, and moving to another property; I am referring to those who want to get out for one reason or another, who cannot see any future in it and want to go and just change their industry. One particular ex-farmer in Western Australia told me that he has $18,000 in this fund from which he cannot get a cent, yet he is living in rented accommodation in Perth. With $18,000 he would at least have the deposit for a home.

As I said, I prepared a draft amendment. We had discussions with the Grains Council of Australia about the proposed amendment. That Council thought there may be a better way to go than amending this Bill in the committee stage. Basically, it agreed with our proposals and said that it would be better for it to go to the Minister to talk about changing the regulations because we are all on the same course. To date I have accepted what the Grains Council of Australia has said, that it will do the right thing, and that the Minister will do the right thing. I was hoping that the regulations would already be before the Parliament when this Bill came in. I do not think they are here yet, so I will ask the Minister in the committee stage what sort of assurances we will get.

I have here a letter from the Grains Council of Australia to our shadow Minister discussing our proposals and giving us some of those assurances. Subject to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), who is at the table, clearing the letter, and to keep the Grains Council of Australia honest in its endeavours, I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 9 November, 1992
Mr Bruce Lloyd
Shadow Minister for Primary Industries
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Bruce

PARA.EMPHASIS: Proposed Senate Amendment to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1992

SPEECH.PARA: Further to my discussions with your office on the amendment to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1992 proposed by Senator Panizza, I write to reassure you and the Opposition that the issue the Senator seeks to address by virtue of this amendment is, in common with other matters relating to the management of the Wheat Industry Fund and WIF equity, currently under consideration by the Council.
In respect of the management of WIF equity, the following are "on the agenda".
1.Determination to make a payment in special circumstances

PARA.TAB: death
retirement (including moving out of the industry)
Eligibility criteria need to be determined.

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Determination to make a payment in "necessitous" circumstances

Eligibility criteria need to be determined (we are advised that in some cases farmers in Western Australia are being denied the Job Search Allowance because WIF equity is regarded as an asset for the assets test in determining eligibility.) An example of "eligibility" may be the granting of Job Search Allowance or Part C funding under RAS. In these circumstances it could be argued that the individual is likely to retire or leave the industry anyway.
3.Disenchanted growers
By this category we are attempting to identify those growers who do not want to contribute to the WIF or want to fully realise their WIF equity and exit from the Fund.
4.Disenfranchised growers

By this we mean, quite literally, growers who do not get a vote. As you know, WIF equity holders do not have voting rights like normal shareholders. However, unless a grower is a member of one of the Grains Council's State affiliates, he technically does not have the capacity to exercise, through the GCA, the power of veto over the use of Fund monies.

I hasten to add that the Grains Council considers that it represents the interests of WIF equity holders, regardless of whether they are members of GCA State affiliated organisations. As such, the Council takes into consideration any representation to it by WIF equity holders.
NECESSITY FOR LEGISLATIVE CHANGES

The WIF Regulations currently make provision for determination of a payment to be made equitably on a pro rata basis across equity holders. Indeed, you will recall that the Regulations were recently amended to accommodate the concerns of a Parliamentary Sub Committee to ensure that when a determination to make a payment was made, the distribution of funds be made equitably. (The amendments to the Regulations merely served to formalise existing WIF operating rules drafted by the AWB in consultation with the GCA, and adhered to by AWB management.) There is no provision within the Regulations for discriminating between equity holders when a determination to make a payment of WIF equity is made.

To accommodate agenda items numbers 1 and 2 that is, "special" and "necessitous" circumstances, a change to WIF Regulations will be required. Section 94 of the Principal Act makes provision for amendments to the Regulations in respect of management of the Fund. S.94(4) stipulates that Regulations relating to the management of the Fund "may not be made except after consideration by the Minister of a report by the Grains Council, made after consultation with the Board".

The "Panizza amendment", in seeking to amend the Act would require an amendment to the WIF Regulations to provide for the cashing out of WIF equity of growers who "cease to be wheat growers". In other words, the Principal Act would "compel" an amendment to the Regulations along these lines, rather than leaving that to the discretion of the Minister and the Council. It would in fact override Subsections 93(3) ". . . the Regulations may make provision. . . " and 94(4). (By the way, the amendment seeks to amend the wrong section of the Act. It ignores the amendment to s.83 (28.12.90), which transfers the power to make Regulations in respect of the Wheat Industry Fund to s.94.)

There is no necessity to amend the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1992 to achieve either the "Panizza amendment" or provisions for "special and/or necessitous circumstances", which the Council is currently addressing. These can be achieved after due and proper deliberation by the Grains Council of Australia, in consultation with the AWB, subsequently the Minister, and then amendments to the Regulations.

Even if the Bill currently before the Parliament was amended in the form proposed, the Grains Council would still need to make policy decisions to enable it to provide guidance to the AWB as managers of the Fund in defining the eligibility criteria for "ceasing to be a wheat grower".

Obviously death is an absolute definition. However, "retirement", "ceasing farming", or "ceasing wheat production" are all conditions which can be reversed. As such, there will always be a degree of ambiguity in determining eligibility for the realisation of WIF equity on the basis of "ceasing to be a wheat grower". It is this area of policy development which requires some consideration by the Council, in consultation with the Australian Wheat Board, including the Fund managers.

In respect of agenda items numbers 3 and 4, provisions already exist with the legislation to accommodate the "disenchanted" and/or "disenfranchised" growers. The Regulations make provision for WIF equity holders to either trade or transfer their equity. The Grains Council has identified that although the "power" already exists under the current Act, and will remain after successful passage of the Amendment Bill, it needs to take steps to facilitate an active trade in WIF paper. As I said earlier, this is already on the agenda.

In summary Bruce, the objectives of my Council and what I perceive to be the objectives of the "Panizza amendment" are in accord. However, to ensure that proper consideration is given to determining eligibility criteria for WIF equity holders cashing out their equity on the basis of "ceasing to be a wheat grower", and to the other provisions I have mentioned, the industry needs time and the flexibility provided by the existing legislation. My Council sees little gain in circumscribing the flexibility of the industry, by virtue of the Panizza amendment in the manner in which the industry requires the Fund to be managed.
Thank you for your co-operation in this matter, and in particular the co-operation and consultation of your office.
Yours sincerely
MITCHELL H. HOOKE
EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. That is where I will leave my remarks at this stage. I hope that in the committee stage the Minister will give us an undertaking that these three measures, as promised to us by the Grains Council of Australia, will be put in the regulations without the need for any amendments. I will be asking the Minister for an undertaking at that stage.

—So far in this debate, Senator Tambling has spent a considerable amount of the Senate's time outlining the purpose and history of the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1992. I suggest that these details can be found, almost verbatim, in the speech made by the honourable member for Murray, Mr Lloyd, during the second reading debate in the House of Representatives. A considerable amount of this material is fact and cannot be contested; it certainly would not be contested by me. We agree with the description of the history and path that these proposals have taken before arriving here as legislation. I would not contest Senator Tambling's description of it at all.

PARA.TAB: This legislation deserves support and I am pleased to see that it has coalition support. It is interesting to note that that support recognises the fact that unity is strength in world marketing and that individual negotiators have the capacity to allow buyers to play one off against the other to negotiate against the best interests of Australia. In supporting the legislation, the coalition agrees with us and the Government that a diversity of negotiators would, by definition, place those negotiators in a very weak position.

What surprises me is that the coalition can happily take that position with regard to a whole range of primary industry matters but that when it comes to industrial relations we find exactly the opposite being espoused: that is, individual negotiations are the model to be followed. In other words, it is each person for himself or herself. Survival of the fittest is appropriate for workers, but it is not appropriate for growers.

I agree that it is not appropriate for primary producers to have to venture into the world market to negotiate sales terms on their own behalf. Any sort of legislation or regulation that establishes a system which is not that chaotic jungle of survival of the fittest is what it is all about and what sophisticated world trade has become. The precise subject of all the GATT negotiations is what countries will do rather than what individual marketeers will do. It is hypocritical for the coalition not to recognise how inappropriate that model is in industrial relations. To finally wake up to that would be a denouement which the coalition should be seeking.

Not all the coalition's proposals are inconsistent. In fact, Senator Panizza's concerns about the fund and access to it by contributors who find themselves in extraordinary circumstances are, I believe, real concerns which need to be addressed before this legislation leaves this place; either through the support of the honourable senator's proposition that suitable regulations ought to be drafted to deal with the situations he described, or, if such regulations are not forthcoming, there should be serious consideration of his draft amendment. I indicate here that the Australian Democrats would consider supporting such amendments if suitable regulations were not forthcoming.

As I indicated at the beginning, we have had a good exposition by Senator Tambling of the general thrust of the legislation. I do not propose to repeat that. I simply say that the confirmation of the Australian Wheat Board's export monopoly, or single desk seller status, until at least 1999 is something that we support. We were entertained by the prospect of grower owned cooperatives being established, but that is not the proposition before us now.

The legislation, in its general thrust, is what has been negotiated through the peak bodies and it is therefore not contested by us. I conclude by simply saying that I will be watching with interest the outcome of Senator Panizza's request that the problems he raised be addressed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are addressing the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. We have just heard from Senator Panizza, a well-known wheat grower from Western Australia who has expressed some concerns about the wheat industry fund. I wish to acknowledge the presence in the gallery of the general manager of the Grains Council of Australia, Mr Mitch Hooke, who has come to listen to the debate on this Bill. It is very nice to see him here.

PARA.TAB: The Bill formalises the changes to the Australian Wheat Board announced by the Government in October. It follows three years of work by the Grains Council, Grains 2000, the working party, the Newco discussions and the months of industry discussions throughout the country on the future of the Australian wheat industry. I attended many of those discussions in Queensland, which were held in Dalby and many other places where the growers came to discuss the future of their industry. They discussed marketing, financial arrangements and the differences of opinion between the various States. Those discussions and meetings took place in small towns all over Australia.

This Bill is a result of the decisions made by those farmers through their industry organisations and taken to the Government. In the end the Government endorsed a scheme for the industry which will result in the Government guaranteeing the Wheat Board's borrowings at 85 per cent of the estimated net pool returns. That is in contrast to the Government's previous scheme to reduce the AWB borrowing guarantee to 80 per cent in 1994 and then terminate the guarantee altogether. The Bill also retains the single desk export powers of the Australian Wheat Board. Those two decisions—and particularly the decision to retain the export power of the Australian Wheat Board—are very big wins for the Australian wheat industry. In fact, if the Government had not supported those measures, the wheat industry would have been in a very seriously weakened position.

This legislation does not come up to the coalition's policy of 95 per cent underwriting, but the coalition still supports the Bill—and gives great support to the retention of the Wheat Board's single desk export powers, which are a vital life force for the Australian wheat industry.

This Bill also grants to the Board a new power to engage, through a subsidiary arrangement, in value adding activities, using in part funds from the wheat industry fund. The wheat industry fund comprises moneys from a 2 per cent levy on gross receipts of the wheat industry. Senator Panizza has some worries about people exiting the industry. It is good to note that Senator Panizza has prepared an amendment. However, he will not proceed with it today because he believes that the Grains Council will take the matter up with the Minister at the relevant time.

From the end of the Second World War to recently, the Wheat Board has operated under a system which lifted the wheat industry to the point where it grew to rival the prosperous wool industry. It also saw the growth of infrastructure through the railways, grain handling facilities and ports—all owned and purchased by farmers through levies on their industry. This successful system included single desk export selling, underwriting or some similar scheme to ensure certainty of minimum expected harvest returns at planting time; a guarantee of AWB borrowings to pay growers' first advances; harvest payments; and regulation of the domestic market.

Unfortunately, in recent years the Australian wheat industry has become the innocent victim of lower commodity prices from the billion dollar trade war between the EC and the US. It has also had to fight drought, particularly in New South Wales and Queensland, and has been a further victim of this Labor Government's high interest rate policy with interest rates up to around 27 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give it a break.

—I know that they are down at the moment, Senator, but the repercussions of those high interest rate years are still being felt in rural Australia. The industry has had to fight drought very hard. A viable and successful wheat industry is of vital importance to Australia. It is fortunate for Australia that the Government changed its mind on its wheat policy and will retain single desk selling and not end the AWB's borrowing guarantees.

PARA.TAB: It was the National-Liberal policy of strict adherence to single desk selling status for the Australian Wheat Board that, I believe, forced the Government to back down and adopt the same policy. The Government knew that once the coalition was firm on Australian single desk selling the Democrats would not move and therefore it would be defeated in this place. Rather than be defeated, the Government agreed to retain the single best selling policy. The farmers of Australia owe the coalition a lot because we were the ones who remained rock solid to the single desk market selling that put the pressure right on the Government.

Four of the world's five major wheat exporting countries have single desk selling, the exception being Argentina. Australia's efficient and unsubsidised wheat industry has to survive in a very distorted world trading situation. Seventy per cent of the world grain trade is imported by single desk buyers, 80 per cent is exported by single desk selling systems and 60 per cent of all wheat sales are subsidised.

In Australia, our single desk selling has ensured long term stability for the industry. It has led to increased efficiencies by making possible reforms in handling and freight. All major buying countries operate through single government or quasi-government buying agencies. In the US and the EC there are massive grower income support schemes. Canada has a wheat board plus an insurance scheme. If people want to debate whether there are subsidies and government assistance, they should go and have a look at the Canadian system. The Canadian Government virtually ensures farmers' income.

In Australia we have lost the regulated domestic market and underwriting to a degree. The only thing left is single desk selling. Let us compare the figures for 1990. In the US, 135,000 cereal growers received $4.2 billion in wheat payment support; in Australia 45,000 wheat growers received $200m. A report from the US General Accounting Office concluded that Australian wheat farmers were more exposed to international wheat prices and received less government support than in any other major wheat exporting country and noted that it was being reduced even further. It concluded that Australian producer subsidy levels were 11 per cent, whereas subsidy levels were 43 per cent in Canada, 44 per cent in the US and 46 per cent in the EC. Let it be said once and for all that the Australian wheat grower is probably the least subsidised of any wheat grower in the world.

The Australian assistance included in the calculation were RAS, Government research funding, tax concessions and export incentives, Government underwriting of Wheat Board borrowings and Government insurance cover on credit sales. All of these measures are acceptable under GATT, unlike the massive subsidies paid to our major competitors in the US, the EC and Canada. Despite the massive subsidies poured into the US industry, it has only succeeded in cutting its own margin. Its market share has only risen slightly from 29 per cent to 31 per cent and the subsidies are only reducing prices in the markets it already owns. These same subsidies are wreaking havoc on world prices and the Australian industry. A report of the US General Accounting Office totally refuted US traders' claims that the operations of the Australian Wheat Board constituted unfair competition. The Government, in changing its mind on single desk selling for the Australian Wheat Board, recognised the reality of the corrupt world markets in the grain industry.

The Government should now give the same assurance to the sugar industry. The international sugar market is totally distorted by massive subsidies, which in turn corrupt the international sugar price. The Government should give the sugar industry certainty for its future by rejecting the Industry Commission's recommendation to end single desk selling by 1993. The Industry Commission's final report on the sugar industry recommended that acquisition continue only for long term contracts and that this should also end by 1997. The Government has said nothing about the threat to the sugar industry arising from the removal of its single desk marketing arrangements. I think that the sugar industry is a very important industry to Australia and it should be treated equally with the wheat industry in the maintenance of its one desk selling.

By contrast, the coalition has said that it will not interfere with sugar industry issues which traditionally and constitutionally have been the province of the Queensland Government. The international market and price for the Australian sugar industry is also corrupted. Just as in the wheat industry, the effect of lowered world sugar prices from massive subsidies corrupting world prices is very clear.

In relation to the massive subsidies in the international grain market, just this September, President Bush announced that 30 million tonnes of US wheat—almost the entire US export crop—would be highly subsidised under a major expansion of its export enhancement program. Thirty million tonnes equates to one-third of the world's wheat trade. The total value will be worth more than $4.19 billion in commodity sales to the US.

According to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, there has been an 11 per cent reduction in world grain prices from the US subsidy scheme. US subsidies have robbed Australian grain export earnings of $300m a year since 1986 when EEP started. The cost of EC protection in 1990-91 to Australian wheat and grain producers was $695m. If we equate that with the 45,000 grain growers in Australia at the moment, we will understand why many of those people are finding extreme financial hardships on their farms.

The Wheat Board estimates that it costs between $120 to $150 to produce a tonne of wheat. This includes the cost of storage, handling and transport. The agreement reached between the US and the EC on oilseed and further Uruguay Round discussions could be a great breakthrough for the grain growers of Australia who have been the most severely affected by the ongoing trade war between the US and the EC. Australian grain growers have really suffered in recent years with negative incomes of the magnitude of minus $30,000.

Many seasons of negative income are disastrous to any industry and our wheat industry has been and continues to be an innocent victim of the American export enhancement subsidy program and the EC CAP program. ABARE has predicted that the effect of implementing the Dunkel package in the Uruguay Round will mean that world wheat, corn and other coarse grains prices with rise in the medium term by 22 per cent for wheat, 12 per cent for corn and 13 per cent for coarse grain.

I know that Queensland growers have taken a terrible battering from the sacrifices that they have made as part of our commitment to the success of the Uruguay Round which far exceed the GATT requirements. Let us hope that these sacrifices have not been made in vain and that there is a speedy conclusion to the GATT round.

The Queensland industry, like the whole of the industry, has worked with the proposals that are implemented in this Bill. Growers have accepted world conditions and have done all they can to cut costs and value add where possible. The industry has looked for all available opportunities. At a meeting that I attended not so long ago one of the growers said to the Chairman, `We have done everything to create efficiencies on the farm. It has got to the point where our wives have to go to work to earn off-farm income'. That is how bad it is out there. The wives are now having to take jobs in the towns to supplement farm incomes in order to keep the farms going.

Despite great export potential in South East Asia in the future there will also be tremendous competition with Australia for these growing markets. To this end, the industry's future will require a totally national approach overall—possibly with State marketing and handling facilities being brought together, as suggested by the Queensland industry—with a proper strategic direction for the whole wheat industry.

The industry has kept pace with developments. There are 40 segregations of wheat out of Australia. Each one of these categories is broken up into different contents. That is value adding. I am sure Mr Hooke, who is in the public gallery, would agree with that. By comparison, the Americans have only two segregations. There is a particular commodity for a particular market, such as turning wheat into pasta, flour and gluten.

The industry is also involved in value adding activities such as the Moscow bakeries, Egyptian silos and the Shenzen free economic zone in China. Some of the industry funds will go to develop these markets in foreign countries. They will give us not only top money for the product, but also access to markets. I commend the Grain Council and the Wheat Board for establishing a way to open up markets for the Australian wheat product.

The industry must look offshore, as the domestic industry is fairly mature. There are probably no gaps to develop further markets for wheat in Australia at the moment—they would be well and truly looked after by private enterprise. The wheat industry fund is being put to the benefit of these ventures and is doing exactly what it was designed to do. The wheat industry fund is establishing a capital base to facilitate growers investing beyond the farm gate so that they have more control over their product and its returns. All these steps are essential for the future growth and viability of our most important wheat industry. I have pleasure in supporting this Bill and wish the Australian wheat industry a secure and successful future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1992. Senator Tambling, Senator Boswell and Senator Panizza have all spoken on this Bill, so there is not a lot more for me to say. It should be repeated that this Bill continues the single desk export status of the Australian Wheat Board; it extends the Government's guarantee of the Wheat Board's borrowings at 85 per cent; it allows the continuation of the wheat industry fund until June 1999; and it allows the AWB to form a subsidiary to provide value adding grains based services.

PARA.TAB: It is rather unusual that, for once, the rural industry legislation is not being debated at the last minute. This Bill has been prepared in advance of the June 1994 borrowing timetable. However, that needs to be looked at in context. It was not the Government that provided the impetus for this legislation; it was the grain industry itself, which, like a great many other industries, has been pushing the Government to find out what the Labor Party's policies are for the future of the industry. I commend the Grains Council of Australia. It is good to see Mr Hooke, having been part of the negotiations for this legislation, sitting in the gallery today and following it right through. I commend that to other people in the community who have legislation going through this place; they should follow the legislation right through. They should play a part in the whole legislative process.

The real benefit of this legislation is that it gives direction and confidence to the wheat industry to look a little further into the future. Given the parlous state of the industry, which is under attack from within and outside Australia—and this has been very clearly put by previous speakers in relation to EEP and the European Community—this legislation is very welcome. I have always said that a single seller selling to a multitude of buyers is in a much stronger position than multiple sellers selling to a single buyer. With this legislation we will have single desk selling, which will allow our wheat industry in Australia to have a little bit of power that it would not have had otherwise.

The grain industry has had some horror years. As I have said, when wheat growers have not been contending with drought and other internal difficulties, they have been caught in the cross-fire of the trade wars between the two big conglomerates: the EC and the United States of America. We are still caught in that cross-fire. I believe that the industry has responded well to the challenges that continued failure of the GATT negotiations has provided. Hopefully, GATT now has a glimmer of hope, although I heard on the news this morning that 60,000-odd French farmers are protesting. It is nice to know that we in Australia have single desk selling to keep a little bit of strength in our industry.

It is important to remember where the Australian wheat industry fits into the world grain scene. In all, Australian wheat production is around 15 million tonnes, although this has fluctuated in recent years: it went from 22 million tonnes in 1983-84 to 12 million tonnes in 1987-88. This compares with the might of the US, which produces 74 million-odd tonnes. In other words, Australia's entire annual crop is equivalent to the annual fluctuations in the United States of America crop. On that basis, we are very much the mouse that roars, when it comes to bluffing and pushing our rights to markets.

However, Australia has become a resilient and skilful marketer of wheat through the expertise of the AWB. We have developed niche markets so that we can target our product to suit a particular customer. I commend our grain industry bodies for having done that. For the interest of people here, Australian wheat has 40 different classifications compared with the United States of America, which has recently doubled its classifications on white wheat from one to two.

So I believe that we are world leaders and I think we should be proud of the fact that we are looking for niche markets. We are going in and selling to specific markets in a specific way. It is really our quality versus some of the other countries' quantity. Some countries might dispute that. The United States might like to dispute it. But it is a fact of life that Australia has the highest quality wheat in the world. That is something that we should be really proud of. It is nice to see Senator Collins smiling and agreeing with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was just pausing for the commercial break.

—For a commercial break I will state my pecuniary interests. I am a practising wheat grower, although my son tells me I should practise a little more than I do. But, as a person who has grown wheat for a long time, I can assure Senator Collins that it is a great industry. It needs to have that bit of stability and the strength of single desk selling in order to compete with multinationals around the world who would take us to the cleaners if we did not have the strength of single desk selling.

PARA.TAB: The provisions allow the Wheat Board to expand its functions to enable it to form subsidiaries and other mechanisms to benefit from value adding activities. I believe this is an important step. Senator Panizza referred to the point made by Senator Walsh that value adding of flour is not always the way to go. I will elaborate on how I believe value adding should be undertaken in Australia to benefit all the wheat growers, the community at large and Australia. Flour is not always the way to value add. Perhaps we should value add with biscuits. We have the Campbells-Arnotts' saga at the moment. Maybe the way to go would be to make more biscuits with our wheat and then sell those biscuits to South East Asia. But I do not think the way to go would be to sell the flour to South East Asia for the manufacture of biscuits over there. It would be much better for us to do it here ourselves.

For too long farmers and their boards have tended to navel gaze a little too much. Perhaps in years past the old farm gate responsibility was sufficient. The farmer believed his responsibility stopped once the product—be it wool, wheat or beef—hit the farm gate. He received his money then and he was happy with the arrangement. We cannot do that any longer. We have to have a marketing sophistication. Farmers, along with others, have to learn to position and market their product better. In order to remain competitive, on-farm productivity gains have had to be matched by equivalent improvements off-farm.

Clauses 5 to 7 of the Bill provide the AWB with the powers to do that. Clause 5(b) amends the principal Act `to enable it to process, manufacturer or undertake other value adding activities, as well as trade in, wheat and grains based products'. I must say that I always worried a little about the Wheat Board when it started to trade on the domestic market because, in some cases, it undercut some of the smarter growers. But I think the smarter growers have worked out how they can handle that. They are either doing it through the Wheat Board or through direct selling to their people.

I add one word of caution. I hope that the Wheat Board uses its commonsense when spending growers' funds and does not speculate too unwisely in chasing new markets and new products. Although I am saying we have to find our niche markets, I do not think we should spend the money willy-nilly in an undirected way.

Of course, while this legislation is a step in the right direction, it does not match what the Opposition's policies will do for the industry. I think that needs to be made pretty clear to the chamber today. The coalition's policies for wheat are clearly more appropriate for the industry and are preferred by the industry. For example, even on the question of underwriting our policies are superior. We have undertaken to maintain the 95 per cent underwriting on price per tonne, unlike the Government's 85 per cent, scaling down to 80 per cent, based on total borrowings. In some years that could mean a significant difference to the growers.

Other benefits that will accrue to the industry cannot be overlooked either. We have to talk about Fightback, which is our vision for the future of Australia, especially of agriculture. It actually will make a fantastic difference—something like $1 billion in savings to agriculture alone on-farm. I think that is going to be a great help. All goods and services taxes on farm inputs will be fully refundable.

The tax component of all the various farming inputs will be fully rebated or fully refunded—from the machinery, the trucks and the chemicals used on-farm, through to the off-farm transport savings. The contractor who collects the grain will have cheaper fuel—26c a litre cheaper. This is a big saving when he is putting 1,000 litres in the tank at a time. His truck will cost less. It has been estimated that a $200,000 truck will cost $30,000 less. The tyres of the truck will also be cheaper than they are at present. Senator Panizza referred to the point made by Senator Walsh that, while he was worried about flour in the context of value adding, there were big cost savings to be made in the transport industries. All of those taxes will be abolished in respect of land transport. According to the Road Transport Forum and Treasury estimates, wholesale sales taxes add about $1.2 billion a year to the costs of transport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can't bring you back to the Bill at all, can we, Senator? Do you want to talk about the wheat industry fund at all?
—I think the Minister is missing the point. That is the trouble; his Government always misses the point.
—You are a mile and a half away from it.

—I am not a mile and a half away from it. We are outside the farm gate. We are talking about value adding and saving costs. Transport costs is one of the big areas in which we are going to save. What about waterfront reform? What about improving the waterfront so that we can get our grain offshore at a much better price to the consumer? If the Minister wants me to go into this, I will. If the Minister could put a photographic image of the Government's tax chain in his mind, he would see that, at every level—from the farm through to the consumer—the Government's wholesale sales taxes are adding on costs. As far as we are concerned, we do not add on costs. It is the final consumer only who will pay. Through our measures, we are going to help not only the grower but also the whole of the industry.

PARA.TAB: It is often forgotten that so many rural industries are self-funded; they ensure their own future by levying themselves. The wheat industry is no different. By the end of the decade, the wheat industry fund will have something like $400m to $500m in reserves to cushion it for the future. I think that is a step in the right direction. Not only will this Bill help Australia, but also the industry will get help when there is a change of government at the next election and Fightback is implemented. The real value adding for the wheat industry will manifest itself in the fact that all those savings which I have outlined will be made from the farm gate through to the export at the waterfront.

TALK.START.PARA: —(10.52 a.m.)—I would like to make a number of points about the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1992 and some observations about the wheat industry in general. The first point relates to the importance of the single desk selling status which is being retained in this Bill. Some 12 months ago—and it was highlighted very much in my State of Western Australia, as I am sure Senator Panizza has mentioned—there was a series of public grower meetings at which the Newco proposal was floated. It was comprehensively rolled by growers. The thing that concerned Western Australian growers in particular—and it must be borne in mind that Western Australia is, on a consistent basis, producing close to half the nation's wheat—was that part of the hidden agenda of the Newco proposal was to get rid of the single desk selling status.

PARA.TAB: We are now operating in corrupt world markets. We cannot be certain that there has been a quick breakthrough in terms of GATT and the discussions that have been going on, particularly when one saw this morning's television news showing the demonstrations that are taking place, with towns being pulled down and places being burnt down in France, which was rather horrific. We cannot be certain that we are going to see major changes quickly, but they will continue to come.

The single seller status is extremely important for two principal reasons. Firstly, 70 per cent of the world's wheat is traded on a direct government to government or government agency to government agency basis. Secondly, the single seller status is particularly important to Australia because 80 per cent of our wheat is sold under a direct government to government or government agency to government agency basis.

That is the way in which the world wheat trade operates. It will continue to operate that way while we have the mass subsidisation which is occurring in Europe and America, whether it be through direct subsidy inputs to production or by such things as EEP, under which export subsidies are paid to increase sales. So, for that reason, the single desk status is crucial to the survival of the wheat industry in Australia.

In round figures, Australia provides about 10 per cent of the world's traded wheat—10 million to 11 million tonnes of the 100 tonnes traded—but we provide two-thirds of the white wheats that are traded around the world. Approximately 85 million tonnes of red wheat and 15 million of white wheat are traded. Of course, white wheat is a better quality wheat than the red wheats. White wheat, whether soft or hard, gives more millable flour, contains less moisture and produces a better end product when processed for bread, noodles or whatever. Therefore Australia enjoys a quality advantage.

I want to mention the wheat industry fund. While I support very strongly the wheat industry moving towards being able to finance its own operations in terms of first advances or minimum guaranteed prices, which I think is very desirable and very wise, I would also like to give a warning to the wheat industry and to the legislators about mixing in value adding. With this there is the danger—we saw it happen in the wool industry—that large licks of money put together in good times can be misused when things get a bit tougher. If the moneys from the wheat industry fund are to be used for commercial activities outside of providing a guaranteed minimum price, it must be done only on two bases: firstly, that studies are carried out into whether there is potential in a particular project that can be promoted; and, secondly, that it clearly be a commercial operation.

I emphasise that it must clearly be a commercial operation, because the last thing wheat growers want and the last thing they should have to do is to subsidise commercial operations in the marketplace. As the Government is guaranteeing borrowings until 1999, it is very important that operations financed through the wheat industry fund be on a commercial basis. I think they should have to be super-commercial. We cannot have individuals getting carried away because they think something is a good idea. At the end of the day, it will be the wheat growers who have put those funds aside who will pay the price. I am sure that Senator Panizza would agree with that.

I mention one matter with regard to the wheat industry fund that I believe is going to be handled by regulation. It concerns people leaving the industry. If a grower has made his contribution to the fund over a number of years and then leaves the industry, I think it only fair and reasonable that he should be able to get his funds back. We on this side of the chamber will be watching the handling of that with interest. I personally would have preferred an amendment to the Bill which spelt out that that will happen. I think such a provision should be in the Bill. It is only fair and proper. The Government made a commitment to the Grains Council on this matter, and we will be watching to see whether it is put into effect.

While welcoming the Government's guarantee of 85 per cent estimated net return in terms of the guaranteed minimum price, the position of the Liberal and National parties is significantly better for wheat growers in that we will be underwriting the harvest to 95 per cent of the estimated price as at 1 October. I cannot understand why the Government has put the guarantee at 85 per cent. It is not logical; it is not fair. I think it highlights very much the Government's lack of understanding of how the wheat industry operates, not only in this country but also internationally. That was highlighted by what happened with EEP and the position of the United States in relation to both Pakistan and India under this program. I believe the right moves at the right time could have prevented that. Unfortunately, those moves were not made. I do not have the time to go into that today, but no doubt it will come up for debate in time.

The wheat industry is a very valuable one to Australia in terms of its exports earnings. It was demonstrated quite clearly yesterday how we need those earnings with the blow-out in the national account figures and, of course, the current account deficit figure of $1.8 billion given the day before. What can be done to improve the wheat growers' position from a national point of view—I am not talking about individual wheat growers now—and to increase those earnings, because the potential is there to produce more grain, is to get the costs of the industry down. Our policies are about doing that. They are about getting down the costs of doing business in this country.

We must learn from what has happened in other nations where they have reduced the compounding impacts of indirect taxes which flow through into the cost of production. As Senator Brownhill before me mentioned, we will be moving to remove wholesale sales tax, fuel excise and payroll tax. I will give honourable members just one example of this, although it may have little to do with wheat. Last week I was at Green and Sons, an abattoir at Harvey in Western Australia. It is a very efficient abattoir, about two-thirds of the size of the Wodonga meat works. That abattoir pays $680,000 in payroll tax a year. That is an impost which is put back directly on the industry. In this particular case, the manager of Green and Sons said it would be worth about 6c a kilo in terms of the beef that goes through there to the producer. It is an enormous amount in terms of net dollars back per beast.

The same situation applies in the wheat industry. The way that we can continue to compete against the subsidies which exist in the United States and Europe is to keep our costs to a minimum. Currently they are not. A recent raft of sales tax Bills that went through this Parliament once again added to the costs of doing business and growing wheat, as they added to the costs of a whole host of industries. Lowering costs must be the direction this country takes if it is going to address its current account problems and its debt problems because we must be able to out-compete those we are competing with.

In terms of value adding—and this is part of what is involved with this wheat industry fund—the people who are administering this must look not only at the first round effects but also at the second and third round effects with respect to those countries with which we are doing business. Often, when one goes beyond what appears to be a glossy, pretty picture on the front cover, one finds there are disadvantages down the track if one goes past a certain point. I make an appeal to those people, when they are looking at the commercial operations, to analyse them very carefully.

It is very important that the single desk status for export markets remain. It is important that the wheat industry fund be developed with the principal aim and target of funding the GMP, or guaranteed minimum payments. That fund should not be seen as some little nest egg where people can play their own little games with value adding and not look at the total commercial operations.

Australian wheat growers and those people who are employed in the wheat industry, right through to the wharf, will be significantly better off under the coalition policy of getting rid of input taxes than they are under the Government. It is important to recognise that, in changing the whole structure of indirect taxation, under our policy the tax on all business inputs that are taxed through a goods and services tax formula will be fully rebated back to the individual producers, and there will be a positive cash flow benefit for the transport industry and the cooperative bulk handling systems that we have in this country. I emphasise that point. While I support this Bill, I also believe that the Government could have done a lot better. Certainly the wheat industry, its associated industries and the employees in those industries will be significantly better off under the policies of a Liberal-National Party coalition government.

TALK.START.PARA: —In an attempt to appease Senator Panizza and not to provoke him into unnecessarily delaying the committee stage of the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill, I will be as non-provocative as I possibly can be in my response here this morning. I will ignore all of the rhetorical flourishes from Opposition senators incredibly attempting to claim credit for these amendments that are going through the Parliament. I am perfectly happy to acknowledge that the Government is not attempting to claim any credit for these amendments going through the Parliament, except to say that they are a product of the fact that we actually do listen to what the industry has to say about these matters and are very much working with industry to ensure the further progression of this legislation in allaying the concerns that Senator Panizza and others have raised this morning.

PARA.TAB: I will also restrain myself by not responding to the rhetorical flourishes that we have heard this morning about Fightback, except to say that I do not really think at the end of the day that it advances the industry all that much to remove things like payroll tax from an abattoir and then to whack a 15 per cent consumption tax onto the price of a kilo of beef when it hits a butcher's shop. But we will leave all that to another day and another time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will debate that another day.

—That is right; we will debate that another day. In order to provide the wheat industry with an adequate asset base for both making advance payments and participating in grains based value adding activities, the amendments contained in this Bill will extend the wheat industry fund until 1999. As a result, the Government does acknowledge the concerns that have been raised during the debate this morning among some wheat growers that their equity in the WIF will be tied up for a long time.

PARA.TAB: It is important to recognise that the wheat industry fund and the associated compulsory levy on wheat sales were instigated in 1989 by the industry through the Grains Council of Australia and that the fund's management by the Australian Wheat Board is subject to a business plan which has to be approved by the GCA. The proposed extension has the support of the Grains Council of Australia and the majority of its affiliated State grower organisations. For some time the GCA has recognised that there is a need to make provision for repayment of wheat industry fund equity in cases of death or retirement from the wheat industry and in financially necessitous circumstances.

The Government concurs with the Grains Council of Australia on this issue and is currently acting on its request for an amendment to the WIF regulations which would allow for repayment of equity in the case of death or a declaration of personal bankruptcy. Advice has been sought from the Attorney-General's Department as to how best this can be achieved.

The wider case for repayment of equity to growers who have permanently exited the industry, who object to the wheat industry fund on principle or who do not belong to a Grains Council of Australia affiliate organisation and therefore feel they have no control over their WIF investment, is currently being considered by the Grains Council of Australia, largely in the context of developing an active market for the trading of WIF certificates which may or may not require changes to the regulations. The Government would encourage the industry to actively pursue options to meet these needs. The Government will amend the regulations governing the use and management of the wheat industry fund only after receiving a report or a request to do so from the industry itself.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) for the assurances that he gave in his speech on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill, which remove the necessity for me to move any amendments. I also thank Senator Bell for his promised support should the Opposition have moved an amendment. On behalf of the industry, I thank the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) and the GCA for the assurance that they will look at the issues of death and bankruptcy.

PARA.TAB: I would like to further debate the matter of exiting the industry. My draft amendment included a situation in which a person ceased to be a wheat grower by selling or disposing of the property on which the relevant wheat is grown and by surrendering a grain information acknowledgment number or property number. I know that the Grains Council, in conjunction with the Minister, is looking at the matter on this basis. I do not believe it is difficult to put the right terms into legislation so that it is possible to pay out people exiting the industry completely. The rural adjustment scheme has found a way around it, and I think the Grains Council and the Minister should look at it. It is a quite simple way: growers exiting the industry sign a statutory declaration that if they want to come back into the industry, they have to pay that money back in again.

Another issue the GCA is looking at is the growers' objection in principle to putting money into the wheat industry fund. I do not place great importance on that because I believe that the industry, while it is holding sole export powers via the Wheat Board, should be paying some sort of levy to do such things as underwrite borrowings. I do not have too much sympathy in that case, but I certainly have sympathy for the people who need their money because of death, bankruptcy or financial need, and for those leaving the industry. When people who have superannuation leave their workplace they are entitled to take it with them.

The Minister spoke about creating a market for the certificate in the wheat industry levy. But that would not work. For example, there is a market for a Cooperative Bulk Ltd certificate in Western Australia, but with a very big discount it would make it not worth while. I thank the Minister for the assurances that he gave us on those points that we, especially those of us from Western Australia, raised. I would like to see him and the Grains Council work harder on helping those exiting the industry. I think there is no need for me to move my committee stage amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government would like to thank Senator Panizza for his agreement not to move the committee stage amendment. On the one hand, it is encouraging to have senior executives from the industry affected coming into the Parliament to watch these Bills go through, but it does have the occasionally negative effect of encouraging unnecessary rhetorical flushes from the floor by senators every now and again. I thank Senator Panizza, now that he has made his point, for agreeing not to move the amendment and for accepting the assurances that the Government has given in the debate this morning.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Collins) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 4 November.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we examine the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 clause by clause, I want to say as on outsider on the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs—I am not a member, but I attend Committee meetings fairly regularly—that this Bill is an example of how the committee process has worked quite effectively. For those who do not know, if we have some concern about a Bill, rather than spending an inordinate amount of time on it in the chamber, the Bill is referred to the relevant standing committee and examined there. In that situation, witnesses are called to give evidence and to put their cases forward, which is not possible when honourable senators debate the Bill in the chamber amongst themselves. We are able to call departmental officers and people who represent peak bodies.

PARA.TAB: In this case, people appeared before the Committee and it was a most productive time. There was give and take on all sides. We have seen some changes to the Bill which prove that when the committee process is working properly and effectively we can produce much better legislation. The function of the Senate is demonstrated in the scrutiny of legislation in terms of making sure that we have proper consultation, which is sometimes skated over in the preparation of legislation. It also means that the organisations that are concerned about a Bill can present their cases on the public record.

This legislation is a perfect example. It would behove people to go back and look at the transcript of that committee stage of the Bill because, as I have said, it is an example of how well the committee process is working. We ought to take note of that.

I congratulate the staff of the Committee on the report they have put together; they have had a large amount of work to do. I congratulate those people who appeared before the Committee and gave evidence. I think this shows that we have been able to achieve something. I also congratulate the members of that Committee who have put in an enormous amount of work looking at Bills over this session.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has been concerned about two main aspects of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2): one relates to the reduction in hostel personal care subsidies for non-financially disadvantaged people, and the other relates to the review of resident classifications. I propose to speak on the first issue now because the Government is in fact introducing amendments which the Opposition will support.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Perhaps we could get the Minister to move his amendments first so we have something to debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 2,page 1, subclause (2), line 9, omit "6 January 1993" substitute" 28 April 1993".
(2)Clause 5, page 2, lines 17 to 39, and page 3, lines 1 to 8, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
