SPEECH.PARA: (3)Clause 6, page 3, paragraph (a), line 11, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(a)by omitting from paragraph (2)(b) `paragraph 10D(1), (a), (b) or (d)' and substituting `paragraphs 10D(2)(b),(4)(a),(5)(b) and (6)(b) and subsection 10D(8)'".

SPEECH.PARA: (4)Clause 6, page 3, proposed paragraph (bb) line 13, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(bb) the manner in which a person is to be identified as financially disadvantaged for the purposes of subsections 10D(2), (3), (5) and (6);".

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments have been circulated to the Committee. I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum on behalf of the Government relating to these amendments. It might be useful to the Committee if I now outlined their structure and purpose.

PARA.TAB: The Government wishes to propose these amendments in order to ease the impact on hostels of the changes to personal care subsidies which are contained in the Bill. The Government is proposing that the new rates of recurrent subsidy for hostel residents will apply only to new residents admitted from 28 April 1993 onwards. We believe that this will give hostels more time to adjust to the impact of the measures contained in the Bill. As it stands, it introduces a distinction, as honourable senators will know, between financially disadvantaged and non-financially disadvantaged residents who are receiving personal care subsidies. This distinction will allow the Government to provide higher personal care subsidies of 55c a day for all financially disadvantaged residents. At the same time, subsidies for non-financially disadvantaged residents receiving personal care subsidies are to be reduced by $2.65 a day.

The basis of the Government's decision to vary the rate of subsidy according to the financial status of the residents was to make the range of income available to all hostels more equitable. Quite clearly, those hostels which take on high levels of financially disadvantaged residents will gain additional income from the decision. Obviously, those hostels which will experience a reduction in subsidies are those with a relatively greater capacity to raise income from their residents.

Honourable senators will know that, when we went into the Committee, it was the Government's intention to implement these changes in full in January next year. However, the Government has had discussions in recent weeks with industry and the consumer representatives, in which it has become apparent that many hostels would like more time to prepare for the impact of this initiative. The amendments I am proposing are a direct response to these concerns. Hostel operators have indicated that they need time to adjust their budgets to accommodate changes in subsidies and that it would therefore be preferable for the initiative to apply to new residents only. The aged care industry has also claimed that some residents have entered into agreements with hostel operators in which their fees are not easily adjustable in the short term. We believe that the phasing in of this initiative will allow old agreements to be renegotiated where necessary and agreements for new residents to be drawn up which contain appropriate fees and methods of adjusting those fees.

Existing residents will be defined as those who are residing permanently in a hostel between 6 January and 27 April 1993. This will ensure that the objectives are reached and should give hostel operators sufficient time to adjust to the new payment system, which will affect individual hostels in line with their resident turnover rates and the financial profiles of their new residents.

I believe that this particular series of amendments does illustrate the Government's preparedness to respond constructively to the concerns of the aged care industry and consumer representatives, where residents' rights and continuity of care services are at issue. Finally, I would like to remind honourable senators that government expenditure on care subsidies for hostels has increased from an average per capita subsidy of $1,500 in 1985-86 to an average per capita annual subsidy of $4,600 in 1991-92. In fact, overall expenditure on hostels is expected to increase from $234m in 1991-92 to over $316m committed in 1992-93. I trust these amendments will receive the support of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the comments by my colleague Senator Patterson a few minutes ago. She pointed out that the changes which the Government has now brought forward to the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 are as a direct result of the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. They really do reinforce the value of the committee system.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that, in the other portfolio for which I have a shadow responsibility, we saw another example very recently, and quite dramatically, where the Government rushed in legislation in indecent haste to try to overturn a High Court decision. Clearly, the evidence which was given to that Committee was so compelling that the Government felt obliged to amend its own legislation again. In both cases there is the same basic problem: the Government has failed to consult before introducing its legislation.

A sense of urgency, a sense of the Government and its department knowing best, and in many cases a wish for secrecy, seemed to lead to the undoing of the Government on these important Bills. Thank goodness we do have a Senate system of committees. The Government slams legislation through the lower House with the guillotine, and also tries it in this House, but at least there is a mechanism whereby the people of Australia can be protected by the Senate standing committees.

I turn now to the Bill in question. The Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), as originally proposed, was to provide for a reduction of $2.65 a day in the personal care subsidies going to non-financially disadvantaged persons in hostels. The Bill is a cost cutting measure by the Government. There is no other justification for it. There is no other explanation offered. Clearly, that is what it is.

The problem is that if the Bill had gone ahead, it would disadvantage the existing residents if the proprietors raised their fees. Alternatively, it would ultimately disadvantage the hostel proprietors if they did not raise the fees. Another alternative, I suppose, is that it would result in a reduction in the quality of care available to those residents. On any reading of the Bill, the results would be most unfortunate for all concerned. In addition, with the introduction of the changes to the hostel subsidy arrangements, instead of the current four levels of subsidy, there will be seven, and this will result in even more complex administrative and budgeting clerical activity.

Anybody who has visited a few hostels or nursing homes would have to understand that the members of staff in hostels and nursing homes are up to their ears in paperwork already. They are saying to me that they do not have enough time to talk to residents. The tender loving care is being jeopardised, all through this need to satisfy the bureaucratic requirements of this Government. I think that this legislation really was the final straw for Aged Care Australia, which is the peak body representing the voluntary sector hostels and nursing homes. I draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that in September that body placed an advertisement in the Sydney Morning Herald which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Aged Care Australia no longer has confidence in the Commonwealth Government's implementation of the Aged Care Reform Strategy.

It took a lot for the organisation to have its members agree to support such an advertisement. I think that the fact that Aged Care Australia felt strongly enough to protest in public in that way is a pretty gross indictment of the Government's policies over the last 10 years which have led us to this pretty pass. One has to ask: just what sort of confidence can older Australians have in this Government's long term care policies when one of the largest aged care organisations in Australia has no confidence in this Labor Government? These are the people at the coalface providing the services and care for older Australians.

PARA.TAB: At this coming election, no doubt, the Government will rush around trying to sell itself to older Australians, trying to convince them that it is deep and meaningful and caring and compassionate and that the coalition alternative would be so unfeeling and uncaring that older Australians should not even consider voting for the coalition. I say to those older Australians who are listening: talk to your local nursing home or hostel staff and find out how caring and compassionate this Government is when it comes to actually providing care and helping to finance care for older Australians now.

The system is being slowly strangled. The people who work to care for elderly Australians are being terribly disheartened. They are worried about the future and the care that they will be able to give in the future. The Government has backed down on part of its legislation, and rightly so. Therefore, the Opposition will support the Government's amendments. It is a pity, though, that it had to take pressure from the various industry organisations such as Aged Care Australia, that I mentioned, from Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association, and from the National Asso-ciation of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals. That is not to forget the Opposition, which has made quite clear its concern in the matter.

It is very sad that it had to take all that pressure for the Government to see reason. If the Government were consulting properly, if it really did understand the needs of the aged care industry, it would not have considered putting this legislation through in the form in which it has. If ever honourable senators needed a demonstration of how out of touch the Government is with the problems facing people working at the grassroots, this legislation demonstrates it.

The new amendments propose two changes: firstly, that the revised subsidies will not come into effect until 28 April 1993 and, secondly, that the changes will not apply to existing residents. Existing residents are defined as those who have lived in the hostel for at least one day between 6 January 1993 and 27 April 1993 inclusive. The Opposition thinks that this is a reasonable compromise and, therefore, the Opposition will support the Government's amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add my voice to those congratulating the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs on its work. I also congratulate the Senate committee system, which time and time again is able to bring before it expert witnesses, people who are able to give us an insight—in this case into the aged care industry—into the issues we are debating and discussing. A lot is owed to all of those people who work on the various Senate committees, the staff of the Senate committees, for doing such an excellent job.

PARA.TAB: In regard to the topic we have before us, hostels and hostel subsidies, the Bill as it stood would have caused major problems, not only for the hostels but also, no doubt, for the residents and their families. Therefore, we also welcome the Government's amendments. I had signalled that in committee the Democrats had planned to move their own series of amendments, but I believe that the Government has covered all areas that we were concerned about. Therefore, we will be supporting the Government's amendments.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the House of Representatives, Dr Woods, who took this legislation through as the shadow Minister, expressed some concern about a clause which relates to an issue regarding specialists. Patient referrals from GPs to consultant physicians or specialists are kept by the consultant or physician for 18 months and can be requested by the Health Insurance Commission to be produced. Page 4, clause 10 of the legislation indicates that that time should be seven days. Dr Woods indicated that that was a very short period of time, given that a secretary may be away sick or a doctor may be away on a conference. The doctor can suffer a penalty of $500 if, as the clause actually says, the doctor fails to comply without a reasonable excuse.

PARA.TAB: It seems that we add more bureaucracy to it if we do not have a reasonable length of time for persons to comply with the request from the Health Insurance Commission, and persons having to produce a reasonable excuse, if they have not complied, as to why they have not complied. Dr Woods moved an amendment in the House of Representatives that the time during which the doctor was able to provide the referral information be changed to 30 days. The Government obviously was not prepared to support that. We had discussions with the Democrats outside, and they were not prepared to support that 30-day provision. In order to look at some compromise, I foreshadow amendments that will substitute 14 days.

I ask the Minister to think about this. I recently posted something from my office and it took nearly a week to get to the same suburb. There is a problem in that a whole lot of bureaucratic nonsense goes on. People then have to demonstrate what day they posted the letter and have evidence that they posted it on that day. It is the doctor's word against that of the Health Insurance Commission as to whether the doctor actually posted it, or the doctor has to send it by registered or certified mail to get indication of the date. I think that is absolute nonsense. It would seem to me very reasonable if we could reach a compromise here and have 14 days, which is often the time that is required to respond to Telecom or other statutory authorities, if one is asked to provide information. I call on honourable senators to consider this proposal and see whether we can come to an arrangement which means that we would have less doctors' time spent on bureaucratic nonsense and less taxpayers' money spent on bureaucrats chasing up people who do not get a response back. I call on the Committee to consider these amendments. I seek leave to move the amendments circulated in my name.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 10, page 4, line 19, omit "7", substitute "14".
2.Clause 10, page 4, line 37, omit "7", substitute "14".

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to start with the comment that the Health Insurance Commission will not be randomly requiring the doctors to provide this information. It will be required when there is some need; in other words, if an investigation of some sort is taking place. Surely it is reasonable, when specialists are being paid by the taxpayer, to expect them to be able to run their financial and accounting systems and their office administration sufficiently well that they can file material for 18 months, know it will be there, know where it is, be able to retrieve it within seven days and post it off as needed.

PARA.TAB: I cannot understand why we cannot accept the clause in the Bill that clearly provides for the physician or the specialist to be able to put forward a reasonable excuse. The postage van could be burned or the particular surgeon could be overseas; there is a range of legitimate excuses which surely could be used. I cannot see any need to extend beyond seven days—we are looking at quite a reasonable period of time—the period in which that information has to be provided. I imagine that the particular doctor would be very keen to make sure that he or she had some evidence of time and date of postage in case it was requested, and I am sure that those records are so important that all that would be taken care of. So the Democrats will not be supporting this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lees said that the referral information has to be sent off within seven days. It does not have to be sent off within seven days; it has to be at the Health Insurance Commission within seven days. I want to get that fact clear.

PARA.TAB: I agree with Senator Lees that it ought to be stored; I agree that it ought to be kept for 18 months, but I think it is an unusual demand that it ought to be there within seven days, given the state often with Australia Post. I think it only reasonable that it be 14 days. I say to Senator Lees that they do not have to get the information off within seven days; I repeat: they have to have it at the Health Insurance Commission within seven days of the request. There is quite a difference between getting it off and getting it there within seven days.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will clarify what I said. I have not come in here today to defend Australia Post, but I do believe its record of delivery is quite reasonable and acceptable. The doctor will obviously have to plan so that the referral information is delivered within seven days. Therefore, presumably, it will have to be found and posted within three days. If the doctor's filing system is such that a document cannot be located within two or three days, we really have to ask what the problems are. Perhaps the doctors will have to look again at how they run their offices and their whole administrative situation. Perhaps they will have to look at some staff education or re-education to ensure the availability of these very important documents.
—I think we are making a mountain out of a very small molehill.
—Well, make it 14 days.

—No. The Government will abide by its original and best thoughts in this regard. The fact is that the referral letter from a general practitioner to a specialist will almost certainly be in the clinical file of the person who has been provided with that specialist attention. It will be easily accessible. If, for some reason, the specialist's consulting rooms are closed and the matter is not dealt with due to a reasonable excuse, that is well provided for within the Bill. I really believe that making the retention of the referral letter mandatory as an audit matter will add almost nothing to what goes on in any well organised specialist's practice.
—We haven't argued that.
—No, I am just saying that. So, therefore, it will be available. It is just a question of getting it off within seven days, and I believe that is a very reasonable matter.
—Will you answer your mail within seven days?

—I always do, usually within 48 hours. If it comes from Senator Newman particularly, I will be extremely diligent. I think we will stick with this. I have not been sufficiently persuaded by Senator Patterson, who normally manages to sway me in this chamber; but on this particular matter I will stick to the Government's original proposal.

—I would like to ask Senator Tate how he arrived at the seven days. I would like to put the boot on the other foot. If Senator Tate has been bulkbilled for a medical service in the last 18 months, could he produce within seven days the receipt from the doctor to prove that he had received that service?

—No, I could not, but I think that is utterly irrelevant. We have a situation where, as I say, in all instances the GP's referral letter will be on the clinical file of the person who is being treated by the specialist. It is just part of normal, good clinical practice to do that. It will be very accessible and immediately available so that, for example, any dealings I have with my GP and Medibank or whatever—
—Medibank! So you are privately insured?
—Did I say Medibank?
—Yes, you did.
—I meant Medicare. They would be matters for which I would not, and do not, have to keep records. In fact, I hardly know what happened last week.

PARA.TAB: As to the seven days, the original proposal within the Department was for one day. As I understand it, the AMA was consulted. But the AG's Department, in looking at the proposal, thought that seven days would be a reasonable time, so that is where it arose. I believe that seven days is a reasonable time. As I say, this can be easily complied with and I do not believe that it will cause any great difficulty to specialists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has Senator Tate never had anything misfiled by any of the staff in his Department? Can he always find what he wants on every occasion?

—I have never had responsibility for something as important as the treatment of somebody's life threatening condition or disease, or for dealing with the results of a traumatic accident or some acute episode in the progress of some disease. If I had that sort of responsibility, I would be certain to have a record keeping procedure in my office that was absolutely infallible.

—We are talking about a referral slip, which is a piece of paper with a number on it that says, `Dear doctor, would you please see Senator Tate, who has a particular problem, yours sincerely'. We are not talking about a clinical letter. The Minister obviously does not understand the Bill that he is proposing.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 22, page 9, paragraph (b), proposed subsection 40AFE(4), lines 33 to 35, omit the subsection.

The Opposition is not prepared to support the proposition in clause 22 of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, which proposes to amend the classification and review provisions for nursing home residents. It provides for the retrospective classification of these residents to the date of the original classification. This amendment will remove the retrospectivity element.

PARA.TAB: Currently, when a resident is classified according to the resident classification instrument and the validation of this assessment means a change in classification, the changes take place from the date of validation. The entire aged care industry is opposed to the retrospective reclassification of nursing home residents because that can occur at any time up to the time of reassessment, which is 12 months.

If a classification is revoked and substituted by a classification that requires a lower funding level, the nursing home proprietor would be required to repay to the Commonwealth the difference in funding between the reclassified level and the level of the original classification. Refunds would be required even though the nursing home proprietor has already spent the money on personal care for the resident.

The harshness of this system is that somebody receives care, staff are paid wages to give that care, and then at a later date—a date of his or her own convenience—somebody from the Department comes along, looks at the documents, usually does not bother to look at the resident and says, `This resident has been wrongly classified'. The result is that the Department wants the money back that has already been paid to the staff to give care to that resident.

I believe, and the Opposition certainly believes, that it becomes grossly unfair when the proprietor has to hand that money back. Inevitably, it makes for hard times in the nursing home. That must impact to some degree or other on the ability of the nursing home to continue to provide that quality of care.

The directors of nursing and the nursing staff assess residents based on their needs and, based on that assessment, they make a professional decision as to what care is required. That is reasonable enough. They do not usually, in most cases—according to the evidence we had at the Committee—set out to abuse the system by deliberately increasing a classification level.

If there are persistent offenders, the Department has within its power mechanisms which would prevent that nursing home from continuing to assess residents. They could be suspended from self-assessment. But that action has not been taken by the Department for the few nursing homes that are deemed by the Department to be persistent offenders in mal-classification.

The professional standards are adversely affected by the validation process and the original decision by the nursing staff—using a departmental assessment tool—as to a patient's care requirements is being challenged primarily on the basis of the inadequacy of documentation.

If the Department does not believe that, I urge it, as a learning exercise, to start visiting the nursing homes around this country as I have been doing for the last three months. In the Senate inquiry it was very clear from the answers we got from witnesses that senior officers in this Department are not doing that. How can they possibly expect to be making important decisions and giving important advice to government if they really do not know what is actually happening and the realities at grassroots level?

Now, with the introduction of this stupid system, which is heavily dependent upon paperwork and which is tying up professional staff who should be providing professional care, we are requiring them to answer the needs of this Department. The level of the documentation that is required in order to meet the Government's standards is not only time consuming but also, as I said earlier, it reduces the time available for other forms of care. Once again, there was minimal consultation on these changes.

During the second session of the legislation committee the issue was addressed by correspondence from the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. The Minister proposed that the Minister have the power to issue a directive to the Department that the review of classifications be undertaken within three months of the resident being classified, with some exceptions for nursing homes in rural and remote areas.

The Opposition does not believe that that suggestion from the Minister is good enough. We believe that the Department has to lift its game and carry out assessments promptly. The coalition's amendment will remove the retrospective element and put pressure on the Department to be more efficient and speedy in validating the assessments which have been made.

I do not have any brief to protect an incompetent director of nursing. I certainly am not here to support anybody who is trying to defraud the taxpayer in some way. The Department has to do its job effectively. It has to be efficient and speedy. Another area of this Department is right now going back and validating expenditure which was made in 1986-87 and clawing back hundreds of thousands of dollars from nursing home proprietors. That is a measure of my concern as to why the Department should be allowed to come in at any time and claw back money that may have been paid many months ago.

The delays in validation are unjust and our amendment is intended to ensure that the Department has financial pressure on its shoulders to make sure that the delays in validation do not occur. By removing the retrospective element, the Department can change the funding received by the nursing home only from the date the validation occurs. That is a prospective effect on funding and that is the way it should be.

Before I conclude I want to say a few words about this documentation. The entire complexity of the system as it currently operates is absolutely appalling, in my view. An assessment is required of each resident in each nursing home in Australia. Then there are the reassessments of the residents if their condition changes, which of course happens to older people. They can improve in their condition but more usually their condition declines. They must be reassessed because of the requirements of this funding system.

Incredible documentation is required on the care actually being provided. The Department says that the industry is overdocumenting for its requirements. The industry says that if its documentation is not as substantial as it is making it, the Department refuses to be convinced that the care has been provided and therefore the funding is reduced. People who run a business—which a nursing home is, no matter who is the proprietor—know that they cannot afford to allow their funding to decrease if they are providing a service on which that funding is based.

The Department's attitude rather reminds me of the attitude of some of the factory managers that I met in the Soviet Union, who did not understand very much about the difference between revenue and profit and how a business can survive. Maybe the Department should have a bit better understanding of business principles and then perhaps it would be more understanding of people who are trying to operate a business of providing care for the aged.

The departmental directives may not, in fact, demand this massive paperwork, but the effective requirement is demonstrated in the assessments which get knocked back in the validation process for want of documentation. This is a complex, onerous and bureaucratic process which is compounded by delays in the validation process and then the clawing back of funds from organisations which have paid that money to their staff for care already given to residents. Only a government and a bureaucracy which have little understanding of or concern for the needs of the industry and for the way it actually operates could devise such an Alice in Wonderland system. The proposals on which the system was originally based do not seem unreasonable, but the implementation and the execution of the system are sheer madness. A simpler, fairer, more certain funding system is urgently needed.

The Opposition will be very interested to receive Professor Gregory's report into the funding of nursing homes. We can only hope that he will be prepared to do more than tinker around the edges. It is a pity that he was not given terms of reference which allowed him to consider hostels funding in conjunction with nursing home funding. Once again, one wonders at the Government's intention when that task was not given to him. I hope I have made very clear our concerns about the current arrangements and the way they are being implemented. We certainly cannot support the retrospectivity element. That is why the Opposition is moving to have that retrospective element removed from the legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in the second reading debate and again in the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs on these clauses, the Government's proposal to allow for retrospective classification of nursing home residents was never acceptable to the Australian Democrats. In the Committee hearings, there was a suggestion from the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that there was an undertaking by the Government that there would be nothing more than three months in terms of reclassification; in other words, if it took longer to reclassify then the money would not have to be paid back.

PARA.TAB: However, after considerable debate and discussion on this issue we will now be supporting the Opposition's amendments. In fact, these amendments are very similar to the ones that we foreshadowed in the Committee. We do not believe there is any compromise on this issue, once we look at the fact that the other measures such as suspending the self-assessment have not really been tried and that, as we heard in the Committee, it is often a paperwork problem that causes the reclassification in the first place.

Therefore, we will support the removal of any retrospectivity element. We hope that, if there are still some problems with nursing homes which are regularly placing an inaccurate classification on their residents, there will be continued education and support and that the Department will use some of the powers that it already has only as a last resort.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are most concerned that the best possible care and attention are made available to those hostel residents and those in nursing homes throughout Australia where the Commonwealth Government does have a funding role. By a funding role, I mean that we make decisions which allow other members of the Australian community, through their contribution to the taxation system and in other ways, to provide the sorts of subsidies and amounts of money which do ensure the high degree of proper care and attention that those residents properly deserve.

PARA.TAB: However, that puts a tremendous responsibility on government to ensure that, for example, where different amounts of money can be paid to a nursing home, depending on the classification of a resident, the classification being undertaken by the management of the nursing home is as accurate as is humanly possible, given the vagaries and the difficulty in borderline cases of how a perhaps frail, elderly person is to be adjudged in regard to the various classifications. But there is a very real responsibility on government. It is in relation to that that the proposal is put forward in this Bill which deals with the effect of the review of classifications.

Senator Newman has spoken of the role of departmental officers in this whole area in a way which I think is, at times, simply in the mode of literary allusion such as Alice in Wonderland, which perhaps is not too hard for officers to bear. It was unfortunate that Senator Newman drew an analogy with managers of factories in the Soviet Union. Although she will say that she was confining her analogy to particular instances of the understanding of revenue and profits and the like, it was a most unfortunate analogy. I certainly wish to indicate that I do not believe that there is any parallel or comparison at all between those caricatured and stereotyped persons, if you like, who are managing affairs in the Soviet Union and those whom I know to be very sympathetic and professional officers of the Department trying to manage a major area of expenditure in order to ensure that, in the end, residents receive the care and attention which is their just due.

Honourable senators have mentioned the appearances before the Standing Committee on Community Affairs. I think it was a very useful exercise. As a result, evidence was given that there could be a severe financial impact on some nursing homes if residents classified many months earlier were down classified. I can understand that there could be an impact, but how severe would depend ultimately on the misclassification those many months before.

Nevertheless, a very sympathetic and practical response by the Minister emerged during the Senate Committee hearing. A very real willingness was indicated to alleviate the impact on the nursing homes concerned and, importantly, to maintain the responsibility of the Government to ensure that proper expenditure of money is provided by taxpayers for these purposes. Honourable senators will recall that I offered to the Committee that the Minister issue a directive to ensure basically that reviews be restricted to residents classified within the previous three months. It was thought that that would provide an incentive to the departmental officials to get out and do the validations within three months of the initial classification. So there would be an incentive there. It would also reduce the adverse financial impact on nursing homes by the retrospectivity being restricted to that three-month period from the reclassification backwards, if I can tautologise.

That particular offer of a directive was sympathetic, but practical. It would have served to allay the more extreme fears that were expressed on behalf of nursing homes in relation to financial impact. We are now left with a situation where the Opposition and the Democrats have agreed to completely omit this retrospective element and make the reclassification purely prospective, quite apart from the fact that an upgrading can also occur. Presumably, it is the intention of the Democrats and the Opposition that that have only a prospective effect.

It is interesting that Senator Newman and Senator Lees have both mentioned what we might call reserve powers in the Department, which I do not think have been invoked very often. If a home is somewhat recalcitrant and persistent in its misclassification, its entitlement to carry out the classifications might be suspended and the departmental officers will undertake the assessment from the earlier stage. Perhaps that suggestion should be taken up by the Department in those particular instances and that section dusted off at the invitation of the Opposition and the Democrats.

Quite clearly, the matter will now have to go back to the Minister for his consideration as to what to do if this clause is omitted. It will have some impact on the expenditure expectations of the Government. This will have to be assessed and decisions made in the light of what happens in the chamber today. To reiterate, what was put forward was a sympathetic and practical response to the problem identified in the Senate Committee hearing. I still maintain that it is a response which is worth the support of this chamber, and for that reason the Government opposes the amendment moved by Senator Newman.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1992ABORIGINAL EDUCATION (SUPPLEMENTARY ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1992OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate on Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill, States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1992 resumed from 11 November, and debate on Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992 and Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1992 resumed from 4 November, on motions by Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the following five education Bills: the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2), the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill, the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill and the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill. The 20-minute speeches in this debate, which will continue throughout the afternoon, will limit the consideration of these five Bills.

PARA.TAB: The Bills appropriate $7,000m of Australian taxpayers' money for schools and higher education. Yesterday we dealt with the Bills relating to funding for technical and further education. We have before us $7,000m to provide for education. My case, on behalf of the Opposition, is that that $7,000m for education is not being and has not been used wisely by the Labor Government. Opportunities have been missed for the last five, even 10, years of the Labor Government. We need a refreshing change in Australia. The election of a Liberal and National government will give more resources to schools, refresh our policies and ensure that we will gain excellence from both schools and higher education institutions.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you may smile; Government members may smile at their complacency about education in this country. The Liberal and National parties continue to criticise the inadequacies and failures of the Labor Government. We have sharply criticised the Government's predilection for centralism and bureaucratic intervention. These are the two diseases of the Labor Government. It thinks that all wisdom is in Canberra and that everything must be monitored and agreed to by some public servants and the Ministers here in Canberra.

We believe that we have had a period of regulation, that a framework has been put in place for education decisions in this country, and that we now need to give initiative back to Australian students and institutions, both schools and higher education institutions. This will be the theme of an incoming Liberal and National Party government next year. We believe that we need greater choice. We also believe that there should be greater incentive, greater local initiative and autonomy and, in all, a much better outcome of excellence in education standards. Our policies, as presented in the Fightback package, to which I will refer briefly in this debate, will turn education right around in this country and get the kinds of good outcomes for which the Australian public is looking.

The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) changes the shape of funding arrangements by providing Federal Government funding directly to institutions and not, as I have been debating for the last 15 years in the Senate, through the States to those institutions. This is a worthwhile change which is entirely consistent with Opposition policy. There is another very regrettable attempt by the Labor Government to entrench compulsory student unionism; it is a deplorable step which the Opposition will strongly oppose. We will vigorously seek to delete clause 66 at the committee stage of this Bill.

The underlying problem with the new funding, however, is that it does nothing to change the basic framework of higher education under Labor; it is a framework of intrusive Federal regulation, assaults on the autonomy of institutions, the imposition of bureaucratic requirements for education profiles and forced amalgamations without educational justification, and the list goes on. The Government remains committed to that approach. There is not one change in general direction after these 10 years of failure. As I say, the only way ahead for Australia in education matters is to change the Government.

Let me refer to the recent words of Emeritus Professor Hugh Stretton—an old friend and teacher of mine from the University of Adelaide. He is a well-known academic, historian, commentator and a person of high standing in the Australian community. Professor Stretton is reported in the Australian higher education supplement of 11 November as speaking very critically of the Government's interventionist merger mania, pushed so strongly originally by the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, when he was the relevant Minister, and subsequently by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin. The opening lines of the article state:

Forced mergers of Australian universities created exaggerated community expectations of the institutions and shattered the legitimate expectations of staff, according to a Emeritus Professor of History Hugh Stretton.

The creation of `cumbersome, extra-large, multi-campus institutions' had served to `sow division and jealousy' between institutions. He said that while this was being overcome in many cases by goodwill and good sense, it was a `needless and harmful thing to do'.
`I think it has been a great pity to produce swollen, multi-campus institutions for no good reason at all . . . '
In respect of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No.2) 1992, on behalf of the Opposition, I move:

At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for persisting with its flawed funding framework for universities, a framework which has led to overcrowding, staff shortages, huge unmet demand, and a severe decline in research infrastructure, and for its continuing attack on students' rights to freedom of association.".

SPEECH.PARA: Let me refer to a person who, above all, I respect as the one who has made the biggest impact on education in this country over the last 20 years at least, and that is my good friend Professor Peter Karmel.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all your good friends.

—He is a very good friend of many of us here because all sides of the Parliament respect him. I would love to read extracts of his Sir Robert Menzies oration delivered last month. But, because of the time constraint, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an extract of an article about that speech.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
The Australian's Education writer, Helen Trinca, in her article about Emeritus Professor Peter Karmel on the day he delivered the Robert Menzies Oration.
An extract of the article:

Tonight he gives the Robert Menzies Oration in Melbourne, an addresswhich will upset many in the system because of what will be seen as somewhat unfashionable elitism. He wants more specialised universities, with some focusing on advanced learning and research work. He reckons there is too much mimicking going on in the post-Dawkins system. Everyone wants to run PhD programs. Everyone wants to do high-flying research. Not every institution can be a Harvard and we need to make some hard choices.

There is more: the dangers of the competency-base approach to training spelled out particularly by the Carmichael committee headed by former union leader, Laurie Carmichael; the need to deregulate and, in Karmel's words, get the bureaucracy off the universities' backs.
There is a warning that the university system may already be too big and a call to slow the growth.

And, most of all, a virtual endorsement of the Coalition's plan to introduce vouchers and variable fees in higher education in place of the present centralised system of direct grants to institutions plus a set fee for students.

Karmel is the new apostle of deregulation in higher education, of allowing universities to compete for students in the open market, after years of running the show from Canberra via the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, which he chaired.

The first moves came about this time last year through public lectures, particularly the John Curtin Memorable Lecture in Canberra, when he advocated vouchers and fees and surprised those still arguing against the market.
Since then he has firmed his position. Tonight he adds the call to concentrate resources—effectively the creation of a top rank of institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In marked contrast to the failures of this Government, I refer to the positive policies of the Liberal and National parties that have been set out in the Fightback package. Again, for want of time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard my summary of those policies.
—Is it an accurate summary?
—It is a very accurate summary.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: KEY POINTS ON HIGHER EDUCATION IN FIGHTBACK PACKAGE
.Major thrust of ending centralism, restoring autonomy to institutions and freedom of choice to students.
.Inadequacies of present system lead to substantial unmet demand, allocation of resources at political discretion, rigidity of academic wage-fixing

.Greater accountability and flexibility to be introduced by providing most recurrent funding through National Education Awards and Scholarships, at least maintaining present real levels of per student funding by Commonwealth and the number of Awards not to drop below present numbers of places
.An Award, once granted, may be used at any institution, including accredited private ones, in Australia
.Institutions free to offer places as they choose in any course (control over number of medical places to be retained) thus ending bureaucratically determined profiles
.Institutions free to offer places to students without Award on any basis institutions see fit
.Scholarships to be made available to accredited institutions to award on merit/need basis as they see fit
.HECS to be retained, available for course fees up to standard fee level (for higher fees, loans available with repayments through HECS)
.Discount for upfront fees payment to rise from 15 to 25%
.NBEET to be abolished, and replaced with an independent Higher Education Commission to accredit institutions and advise government
.Force amalgamations policy to be abandoned
.Number of postgraduate research awards to be increased by 200 and value to rise by $2,000
.To encourage basic and applied research in universities, Commonwealth will provide matching grants of 1:5 for industry contracts gained by university researchers (up to $25 million per year)
.Review of student assistance arrangements to ensure it is provided equitably and no-one is shut out of higher education purely on financial grounds
.Better targeting of AUSTUDY, including not paying to anyone eligible for under $30/week
.AUSTUDY and ABSTUDY to rise by 6% as compensation for GST
Education (General)—
.$3,000 million additional spending on new education programs during the 1990s
.All education services free of GST

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. One of the main changes proposed by this Bill is to provide for Federal funds for higher education to be paid directly to institutions, rather than to the States which, in the past, have been required to pass them on to institutions. This reflects the reality of the prime role of the Federal Government, acquired over the last two decades, for the provision of public funds to higher education. The Opposition does not oppose this significant step. But I observe that it will much more easily enable the implementation of our policies on coming to government.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal and National parties will focus on empowering individual students and individual education institutions. We will put aside the current intervening powers of governments and of the central bureaucracy. This direct link of funding to institutions and our further approach of direct funding linked to individual students and their choices will be the way ahead in the coming years.

I also note the insertion by clause 61 of some `objects' for the higher education system. This will provide a measure by which we can judge the Government's policies. So far it would appear that, even by the measures now set out in statutory form, the Government has failed. However, we support the inclusion of such worthy objects in this statutory form.

Another change is that, from 1994, we will see capital grants incorporated into institutions' recurrent or general operating funds. This is very welcome. I have called for this for several years and I thank the Government for implementing our policy. In another direct steal from Fightback the Government has shifted the discount given for up-front payments for HECS, the higher education contribution scheme, from 15 per cent to 25 per cent, which is the figure that the Liberal and National parties announced in the Fightback policy. Again, we thank the Government for implementing our policy on this matter.

This legislation also makes provision for 200 more postgraduate research awards. That is exactly the number that we announced in the Fightback package a year ago. I thank the Government for recognising the strength of the Fightback package yet again. I could go on and on, but time forbids my mentioning those positive elements of this legislation which have in fact been borrowed directly—exactly—from the Liberal and National parties' Fightback policies.

However, we will increase the value of postgraduate awards by a further $2,000 a year. The Government just does not have the resources to do that. We will. We will not only increase resources in the area of postgraduate awards, we will give greater resources to all areas of education—schools, higher education, TAFE. Education is the big winner in Fightback because of the provisions for additional resources and a completely refreshing approach to the policy directions in these three areas of education.

The Bill also embodies the Government's open learning initiative. However, from what Ministers have said, it seems that the Government does not really understand exactly what it is about and what its role can usefully be. It is very vague indeed. This open learning initiative will help to provide opportunities of access for some who have not so far had the opportunity for university education. However, it is still no answer to the massive problem of unmet demand for higher education places. In the Budget Speech, the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, described it as making a university degree available to everybody with a television set and a letterbox. What a facile description of an aspiration held by so many Australians. It is not as easy as that. A great deal more thought needs to be put in to ensure that this open learning initiative will succeed. Indeed, it is no answer to the unmet demand of so many Australians. This year 50,000 students were turned away from our universities.

This Bill repeals chapter 5 of the Act, which was the product of a particularly nasty action by Mr Dawkins when he was the Minister. To save the Senate's time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the last two pages of my speech on this Bill.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: When the original Higher Education Funding Bill was put before the Parliament in 1988, it included some increases in funding and also the introduction of the HECS scheme. Mr Dawkins made it clear that the higher level of funding was conditional on the HECS scheme being passed. This chapter 5 provided for a lower level of funding if HECS was not passed. It was a clear case of political blackmail, quite disgraceful. In the event the circumstance which the Chapter was designed for did not occur, and so the Chapter was never proclaimed. It is right that we are now removing it from the statute book, but it recalls for us a very shabby bit of behaviour by this Labor Government.

PARA.TAB: The final aspect of this Bill which I will refer to is clause 66, which entrenches the obnoxious practice of compulsory student unionism. The Opposition vehemently opposes this clause. It is wrong in principle and inequitable in practice. The Government has tried to get this disgraceful proposal through the Senate before, in 1990, and the Bill at that time on my motion as spokesman in the Senate on education matters was defeated at the third reading. That was the right outcome then, and it ought to be the outcome this time. May I urge the Democrats (who may be tempted to support this clause this time) to be fair-minded on this matter, to uphold freedom to choose for all Australians, and not to give it away to vested interests. If they vote for this clause the Democrats will again place themselves as nothing more than another faction of the Labor Party. While I shall have more to say on this when we are in Committee, I say now that this clause is disgraceful. The Minister makes the ludicrous claim that the Bill `includes protection for the rights and responsibilities of higher education institutions to make their own decisions, independent of Government interference, on the provision of services and amenities for their students'. It is in fact the reverse of this. Moreover, for this Government to pretend it is concerned about `institutional autonomy' is simply ludicrous. Its whole record is one of interference with institutions, not the reverse. The Government is here seeking to punish and penalise those States which choose to provide for freedom of choice for students. This is a matter of basic principle. I remind the Senate of the right to freedom of association. This Bill tramples all over that.

It is offensive for a student to be compelled to belong to a body which may take up political and other causes that the student considers strongly objectionable and to which the student has no wish to contribute financial support. The Government is here legislating against freedom of choice but we should be doing the opposite. We should be legislating to enhance and entrench freedom of choice. That is why the Opposition is so adamantly opposed to clause 66 and why we shall vote against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move on to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2). We have only 20 minutes in which to deal with five Bills appropriating $7,000m. The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) is a short Bill in the routine form that will provide supplementation for this year. It also provides extra funds for the award restructuring assistance program and extends eligibility for the English as a second language program. The Opposition has no objection to this Bill.

PARA.TAB: The more substantial schools Bill is the third one, entitled the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1992. It is in a new form which provides the legislative framework for Federal funding to Australian schools for the 1993-96 period; an extra $2.87 billion is authorised. We are entitled to ask whether Australia's schools are offering value for the taxpayers' money. The answer, just as in the higher education area, is no. The Government is failing in terms of schools as well. It is Australian families and children who are being denied their opportunities by the inadequate policies of the Labor Government. There are major problems facing our schools which the Government is not tackling and, indeed, does not even seem to grasp.

I note, for example, the conclusion of the Finn committee, the important inquiry set up by this Government and led by Brian Finn, the Managing Director of IBM, to look into post-compulsory schooling and training. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is firm evidence that a significant number of school leavers do not have even very basic literacy skills adequate to their training or work contexts.

One can readily point to studies that indicate an inadequate level of literacy and knowledge on the part of young Australians. This is just not good enough. Australian schools are failing young Australian people and we are not seeing the solution to this problem from this present Government.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal and National parties have announced refreshing new policies for schools and additional resources. They are set out in a prominent way in the Fightback package, and I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a summary of those policies. I will be happy to allow the Minister to see these documents. I would have liked to have given them to him before I began speaking but he, of course, came in during the course of my speech.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: KEY POINTS ON SCHOOLS IN FIGHTBACK

SPEECH.PARA: National Standards Program
$5 million per year program for Languages Other Than English
$10 million per year Schools of Choice program within government sector
$10 million per year Quality of Teaching program for teachers' professional development
Australian Excellence in Teaching Awards
$5 million per year Literacy Start program for early intervention programs for literacy and numeracy
Abolish assets test for Assistance for Isolated Children's Scheme
$2 million per year program to support initiatives for gifted children
Simplified categories for grants to non-government school, with minimum grant per student
Capital assistance to non-government schools to be doubled to $162 million per year
Restrictive New Schools policy to be abolished
Intrusive accountability requirements for non-government schools to be ended

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I now move a second reading amendment in these terms:

PARA.TAB: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for its failure to give priority to raising standards of schooling in Australia to international levels, and for the unjustified restrictions it continues to impose on the rights of parents to choose their children's schooling.".

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation does nothing substantial to lift the burden of the repressive new schools policy. The Bill makes some minor changes. They are welcome; they are borrowed from us. For example, it lifts the previous restrictions on the maximum number of students at existing non-government schools.

PARA.TAB: However, the main components of the `new schools policy' of the Labor Government remain—and they remain as barriers to the aspirations of Australian families and Australian children. The Government's ideological hostility to private provision in education remains, even though this is a choice which a significant number of parents increasingly wish to exercise. Thirty per cent of Australia's school children attend non-government schools but at least 50 per cent aspire to. The barriers that have been placed in the way over these last 10 years are of the Labor Government's making.

The Liberal and National parties will completely remove those barriers. We will allow choice. We will allow families to gain the opportunities that they have been urging upon us now for years. I believe that it will be one of the major reasons why Australian families will choose to support the Liberal and National parties in the coming election.

The Bill sets out per capita grants that are to be paid to non-government schools. In real terms the per capita grants for levels 1 to 4 schools are actually frozen—not a jot more. That is right through, from 1993 to 1996. Only the schools in the higher levels of grant are to receive some real increases. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the three remaining pages of my speech. They deal with the remaining two Bills on behalf of the Opposition.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

Such increases as there are are nowhere nearly enough to give real choice to families, especially low income ones. More resources are needed in these schools. I can state that over the rest of this decade parents choosing a school in the non-government sector will receive from the coalition some $1 billion more than they would receive under the policies projected by this Bill. Giving these increased resources to independent schools is not at the taxpayer's expense because in fact they represent a saving to the taxpayer. Every student who moves from a government to a non-government school moves from 100 per cent government funding to an amount substantially less than 100 per cent.

That is why the Liberal and National parties have the happy coincidence or complementarity of a good policy popular with Australian families and a policy which saves the taxpayer's money. Increased choice and higher standards are what Australia's school systems need, and those things will be enhanced under the policies of a Coalition Government.

SPEECH.PARA: ABORIGINAL EDUCATION (SUPPLEMENTARY ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This short Bill provides for funding of some $241m during 1993-95 for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy, a program that has, in principle, considerable merit, and we welcome its continuance for a further three years. That is not to say that the administration of the program has always been ideal, as Audit Office reports have pointed out. However, the basis of the program has the support of the Opposition, and accordingly we support this Bill. There are no contentious clauses to which I have objection, and I am happy simply to indicate my support. I know full well from my own involvement in Aboriginal affairs policy over many years as a senator how important education is for the future of Aboriginal people. It is the most significant foundation for Aboriginal Australians achieving equal outcomes as for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: OVERSEAS STUDENT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This final Bill in this cognate debate involves only a small amount of money, a diminishing amount in fact, as the program to which it relates is being phased out. Under this subsidised program, charges need to be set for certain overseas students studying in courses here, and the Bill makes adjustments to the charges in accordance with the index of higher education charges.

The Bill is in itself uncontroversial, but it again draws our attention to the general record of the Government in handling overseas student matters. It is not a good record. This is a sector that underwent massive expansion without the Government providing a satisfactory legislative or administrative framework. When major problems then arose, there was a need for urgent legislation to try to put right the Government's earlier neglect. We have had tabled in the Senate only this week the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on the operation of that legislation. However, those problems are not directly affected by this Bill, and the Opposition does not oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and the Minister, for looking at these pages. I am frustrated; there is so much to be said about the need for new initiatives in education and in our schools and this is the time to say it. Yet I am given 20 minutes in which to outline the alternatives for solving the problems that are before us. It is only in the Hansard that the positives of our policies will be set out most clearly. I thank the Senate for giving me leave to incorporate these sections of my speech. I speak on behalf of the Opposition in condemning this Government for its failures in education. Nevertheless, I support the Bills that are before us.

—I rise to discuss the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1992, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992, and the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1992. I agree with Senator Teague that we have been given a relatively short time within which to discuss this legislation, and there is quite a lot involved in these Bills. However, I imagine we will have a closer opportunity during the committee stage to flesh out some of the details that Senator Teague has outlined. I certainly look forward to a vigorous debate in committee.

PARA.TAB: This package of education Bills before the Senate today covers a wide range of areas. It is unfortunate indeed that a discussion as wide ranging as to involve secondary schooling, university funding, Aboriginal education and overseas students charges, should be a cognate debate. I wish to address briefly each of these Bills and speak on the issue of universal membership of student organisations.

The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill provides the funding for primary and secondary schools for the next four years, totalling some $2.8 billion. This includes funding for projects under the national equity program, the implementation of the revised new schools policy, and the introduction of new broad banding arrangements for schools equity programs in 1994. This will affect the assistance for ESL training, literacy and learning, special education, education in disadvantaged schools and country areas, and disabled students.

The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) provides for the supplementation of funds appropriated for schools programs for 1992 and extends eligibility for English as a second language to dependants of certain categories of temporary entry permit holders. The Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1992 adjusts the higher education charges for overseas students to the maximum level of 55 per cent of the full cost of an average higher education place. This is expected to raise $10.3m in 1992-93. The Australian Democrats will not be opposing this legislation; however, during Question Time we will be looking closely at the second reading attachments circulated by Senator Teague. I have not had an opportunity to examine those in detail at this stage and I will be considering our support for them over lunch.

However, on the question of overseas students charges, I warn the Government against using overseas students studying in this country as `milking cows'—which was the term used by the National Liaison Committee representing overseas students in Australia, which complains of helping to finance higher education in this country and yet receiving minimal assistance in the form of orientation or bridging courses for overseas students. While overseas students are paying fees as high as $9,732 per annum for degrees such as dentistry, they are entitled to the highest education standards.

It is no secret that the declining quality of degrees and infrastructure on campuses is of tremendous concern not only to overseas students but also to local students who find declining quality of library collections and overcrowded lecture theatres the norm of the day. In my department of archaeology, ancient history and classics at the University of Sydney, our funding has been cut to such an extent that both second and third year tutorials are now non-existent, which represents a serious decline in the capacity of the faculty of arts to deliver a broad ranging and well-rounded degree in Middle Eastern archaeology.

The final Bill we are looking at today is the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill, which provides funding for the State and Territory governments' non-government school systems, Aboriginal education institutions and education consultative bodies for the 1993-95 triennium, totalling quite a great deal of money. This Bill represents a 13 per cent funding increase in this area, which is certainly very welcome.

With the findings of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody in mind, this Bill seeks to redress the poor levels of education attainment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. This involves incorporating awareness about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and their history into the curriculum and the implementation of programs like the national Aboriginal languages and literacy strategy and the national reconciliation and schooling strategy.

The final Bill, the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No.2), provides funding for the purposes of higher education in the States and in the Northern Territory. It provides for direct payment of Commonwealth funding to higher education institutions and also reflects the decision to incorporate capital funding into operating grants. It commits a total of $4.7 billion in funding for higher education in 1995, the third year of the new funding triennium. This amount includes $23.6m for additional student intakes, $274m for capital works and a further $252m for research programs.

This Bill also provides the funding for the open learning initiative in 1993. I maintain that there are some outstanding questions about the quality of the open learning project and about its inequitable fee structure. Senator Teague pointed to the statement made by the Minister regarding access to open learning. The question we asked about the open learning program was: where are the quality control mechanisms?

It is simply not sufficient to say that every person with a television and a letterbox can have access to a university degree. Some quality control mechanisms must be in place and an equitable fee structure must be established to ensure that the very disadvantaged groups that the Government is attempting to reach are able to access the open learning program. OLI certainly does have the potential to widen access to higher education for traditionally disadvantaged groups but, with the financial disincentive of up-front fees, many of these groups could well be locked out.

We understand that the Government is looking at some kind of deferred payment mechanism for open learning such as the HECS mechanism, and we would certainly support that. However, the decision to establish some kind of deferred payment process was done only after pressure from the Democrats and from a range of student and academic groups who had voiced their concern. Open learning must not be considered as a solution to unmet demand and it is not a quick fix or stopgap measure.

The decision in the Budget, reflected in this Bill, to increase the discount for up-front payment of HECS from 15 to 25 per cent per annum rewards those from higher socioeconomic backgrounds. I see no comparable discount being offered to those students in financial straits, only punitive schemes like the recently introduced student loan scheme.

The discount and loans seem to be ideas pinched by the Government from the coalition's Fightback education policy. Increasingly, the Government's attitude towards education reflects that of the Opposition. Both parties seek to implement a user pays education system that will see a return to elite education for the rich.

The increase in postgraduate research awards is a welcome move designed to boost Australia's research pool from which public and private sector researchers will come as our future academics, who are now in short supply. Our concern is that HECS still applies to research degrees unless a student has an exemption, which really does penalise our brightest and best students.

The AVCC recommended that HECS be abolished for students undertaking research degrees. In fact, it sent me an amendment to move to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2). However, I received the amendment only some half an hour ago and I really have not had an opportunity to examine it in detail and prepare it for dissemination on the floor of the chamber today.

I ask the Government to please consider abolishing the HECS for research degrees at universities. I understand that it would have budgetary implications, but I ask the Government to please consider that as it is penalising our best and brightest students, on whom our economic competitiveness rests. In terms of developing ideas and innovations, it seems to be a very bad decision.

An important section of the HEFA Bill is the provision which seeks to safeguard the autonomy of higher education institutions in relation to student organisations. This provision allows the Commonwealth to make up any shortfall in the revenue experienced by an institution as a result of State interference in the collection of student organisation fees. The Democrats are committed to supporting this provision, which will protect the vital services that student organisations provide.

This debate has not been without controversy in the past, and even today Liberals have guised their contempt for the supportive role that student organisations provide on campus in the language of individual rights and industrial relations terminology. The claim by the shadow Minister for education, Dr Kemp, that he would introduce voluntary student unionism within 100 days of being elected to office has dire consequences for students.

The Liberals seek only to emasculate the power base which students currently have. They seek to deprive students, who are amongst the most financially powerless members of our community, of vital support services such as counselling, welfare, subsidised food and photocopying, meeting rooms and grievance procedures. There is strong support for this legislation from a variety of groups, including student groups, from whom I have received many letters of support, the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, university administrations and other community groups.

Payment of a fee is an obligation of enrolment within a university, which generates automatic membership of the student organisation and its affiliate bodies. The term `student union' is a misnomer; more appropriate is the term `guild' or `organisation', as student unions—contrary to the Opposition's claim—are not akin to industrial trade unions. This is a fundamental distinction. Student organisations are not industrial trade unions. They are not involved in the setting of awards or wage rates or in the legal complexities of arbitration and conciliation. Student organisations do not exercise any legal control over their members. They offer support and encouragement for social, cultural and intellectual pursuits. Student organisations provide a range of services and facilities, including bookshops, legal services, sport and recreational facilities, health services, employment services and publications, and even personal injury insurance, as well as academic and educational representation.

Many of the services provided by student organisations could not be provided by universities, nor could many students afford them without the subsidies that student organisations offer. In the absence of student organisations, this responsibility would fall to the Government or the universities themselves, which in the current economic climate would be unlikely to meet these funding needs. The fact that university administrations could not adequately cater for the quantity and quality of services such as those provided by the student guild is acknowledged by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, which endorses universal membership and claims that student organisations are efficient and representative. The AVCC's view is that fees charged for student services are an obligation of enrolment.

Student organisations are part of a university education which involves the fulfilment of both formal and informal modes of education. A university is a distinct social entity in which student organisations play an essential part. They are an important element in the social and cultural aspects of university existence and should not and cannot be considered separate from the whole education process.

Universities can be compared validly with distinct communities and operate in a similar way to local councils, extending benefits to the student community through the provision of representation and services. Home ownership, by way of comparison, brings with it rights and obligations within the context of a municipal council. Payment of rates for the provision of services such as garbage collection, child-care and gardening is an obligation of becoming part of a local community. Some of these services are used and others are not. Rates also go towards payment for what are, to varying degrees, political activities of a council.
Debate interrupted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, will be absent from Question Time today. He is in Sydney on government business. Questions normally addressed to Senator Evans should be directed to the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given that the Government's One Nation forecasts were badly wrong, unemployment forecasts wrong, job growth wrong, deficit forecasts wrong and infrastructure spending now revised, when will the Minister let the people of Australia know what the Government's employment policy will be for the next election? Or will it simply be more of the same with a million Australians out of work, low economic growth, record foreign debt and continuing policy paralysis?
—It is of course correct that the One Nation forecasts were revised in the Budget context. There is nothing new about revision of forecasts—
—You didn't get anything right.
—The OECD has revised forecasts for all OECD member countries this year.
—They had to; you got it wrong.

—It shows how much Senator Alston knows about it all when he says, `They had to because you got it wrong'. I will illustrate the problem by reference to one other country—the United Kingdom. Last year, the total domestic deficit in the United Kingdom was #3 billion. In the first six months of this year it was #20 billion.
