There has been a bit of revision of forecasts in the United Kingdom, as there has been in France, Germany, Japan and the United States. There is nothing particularly miraculous about revision of forecasts. Perhaps the Opposition ought to do a bit of that itself. When the Opposition has a $6 billion hole in its Fightback package, as it has, perhaps it ought to do a little bit of revision itself. Perhaps it ought to do a little bit of revision on all its policies. On the issue of unemployment, when we came to government we inherited in this economy 10.3—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—That is ancient history!

TALK.START.PARA: —It has nothing to do with ancient history, I am just making the point. Of course, as the economy recovers the employment situation will improve. But I am not convinced that a cyclical recovery will produce the sort of full employment which we would like to have in this country. All economists say that. Only Opposition members say that they are going to create two million jobs. The only job creation program we have seen from them is from their shadow Minister for industry, Mr McLachlan, who invented 12,500 people being employed in the food processing industry. He just made it up. He took the figure out of the blue and made it up. That is the sort of job creation policy those opposite will provide.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Reith, says. He says, `I believe that we will do that'. If it is said, `But, Mr Reith, you are going to get rid of 5,000 public servants', his reply is, `Oh yes, but I believe that we will create jobs'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. On the question of relevance, the Minister was asked whether this Government has any alternative policy prescriptions. All we have had is the Minister rabbiting on for a couple of minutes about everything else but. I ask you to bring the Minister to order or simply let the Australian public accept the fact that this Government offers nothing by way of an alternative.

—On the point of order, Mr President: this is in the tradition of vexatious points of order. Senator Alston knows that there is no point of order. Under the guise of making a point of order, he seizes the opportunity to make a political statement. This has become a pattern of behaviour of the Opposition which simply delays and interferes with the answers of Ministers. Mr President, I ask that in future you consider sitting down people who raise vexatious points of order, particularly when there is a coordinated campaign of interjection upon a Minister who is giving an answer. Senator Button should be heard in silence.
—Order! Senator Button was asked a very wide-ranging question. I thought that he was in order. The points of order that are being taken from both sides are often not points of order.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I am astonished that the Minister has finished because we did not get an answer to the question which was, as Senator Alston said, a simple one: when will we see the Government's employment policies? What the Government is offering now is nothing further at all. There are a million people unemployed and there are no policies on the table to recover the situation. In fact, it is even worse because the Minister said in his sort of answer that a cyclical recovery will not be enough. I put it to the Minister: will the Government consider some alternatives—such as abolishing the insidious $5.8 billion tax on jobs, the payroll tax, which it believed should be abolished in 1985; reducing the tax on exports to $1.7 billion, as in Fightback; abolishing the $9.4 billion wholesale sales tax; reducing personal income tax by one-third—or other incentives to get the economy moving and to give people in Australia the opportunity to get jobs?

—Senator Hill described his question as quite a simple one. I agree with him in part; it was a simple-minded question. Opposition senators come in here at Question Time and say that we should not debate the questions in answers. But those opposite put them right into the field. Is their argument that the abolition of payroll tax will create jobs? It just shows how relevant they are. That is a policy which would have created jobs before such things as automation and computerisation in industry. Sure, it would have created jobs in labour intensive industries in those days; it would have helped. It is a policy from the 1970s which they tend to apply in the 1990s. It is all about technology these days, fellows. You had better wake up to yourselves. It is not just about huge factories employing people. They are not for us; they are for low labour cost countries such as China. Those opposite can go through their particular remedies. Having had the invitation, I intend to do so in answers to questions.

—I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the Uniting Church national assembly statement on economic policy issued yesterday which slams the Opposition's industrial relations policy of dismantling the industrial relations system and deregulation of the labour market. In the light of the Uniting Church's comments, does the Government intend to adopt a policy which will deregulate the labour market and shift the balance of bargaining power in favour of the employer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the Uniting Church's policy statement on industrial relations issued on 30 November. The statement reflects the church's very valid concerns about what would occur in Australia should Dr Hewson's outdated and cruel policies on Australian industrial relations ever have a chance to take hold. I will illustrate what I mean by quoting what the Uniting Church said—and I apologise to the Senate for the long quote, but it is very interesting—on page 8 of its statement:

PARA.TAB: Fightback and Jobsback are built on the assumption that there are only two options available: free market or totalitarian control. There is no evidence of any effort to look at other options of how to build successful economies on the basis of cooperation and collaboration between industry and labour.
If the heavy-handed actions of the incoming Kennett Government in Victoria over the last few weeks is a sample of what would pertain under a Coalition government, and Dr Hewson says it is, then we—

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has experienced a period of industrial peace and wage restraint, with a minimum of strikes over the last decade, even when unemployment figures were down.
. . . (Jobsback). . . would shift the balance of power in bargaining between employer and employee in favour of the employer by weakening the power of trade unions.

. . . migrants, women and non-unionised and the industrially weak would experience a drop in their wages and conditions under a deregulated environment as proposed because of their relatively weak bargaining positions.

PARA.TAB: The current industrial relations system evolved to protect workers from unscrupulous employers, unfair dismissals—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tendentious nonsense!
—On a point of order, Mr President: is it in order for Senator Alston to accuse the Uniting Church of tendentious nonsense, as he has across the chamber?
—Order! That is not a point of order.
—The Uniting Church goes on:

ANSWER.PARA: which is our industrial relations system—

evolved to protect workers from unscrupulous employers, unfair dismissals, exploitation and poor standards of occupational health and safety. Under Jobsback this institutional structure would be destroyed.
We do not dispute the need for further reforms in the workplace. We dispute that this heavy-handed method will be effective or just . . .

It then goes on to make other observations. Our Government will continue to support the structure which is fair and just and provides a decent award structure for Australians and the basis for Australian workers to work with Australian employers to lift this country out of recession into greater industrial growth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given the policy paralysis of the Keating Labor Government, which has now been identified by every responsible commentator in the country, without exception, I refer the Minister back to his ministerial statement of 14 November last year on the economy and employment—one of the many misleading economic statements which he has made since Labor came to office—in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The gains and rewards of the long, hard process of restructuring are within our grasp . . . In this statement today we bring to the people of Australia a message of fundamental confidence . . . that the work of this Government over the years . . . has brought us together to the threshold of a new era of achievement.

I ask the Minister: is his definition of a `new era of achievement' a further 86,000 Australians becoming unemployed, to a level of one million; an increase in the nation's foreign debt of a further $30 billion, to more than $44,000 for each average Australian family; and an additional $13 billion to Australia's current account deficit?

TALK.START.PARA: —The comments I made last November were about issues relating to restructuring of the Australian economy. That is a difficult process, which is taking place. The fact that it is taking place is reflected in the enormous diversification of Australian exports, the vastly improved competitiveness of many Australian firms—a whole range of things which are affecting the international performance of this country for the better. That is what I was talking about at that time.

PARA.TAB: Now Senator Short seeks to put together a few figures he has scrabbled up in contradistinction to the words I used in that statement. It is all very well to say, as he has said in the last couple of days, that the Australian national debt represents so much for every man, woman and child in Australia. He should have a look at Australia's national assets and how they have increased—Australia's national wealth. It would be equally ridiculous for me to come in here and say that in terms of national wealth, divided up for every man, woman and child in Australia, I could produce a result which was different. Producing those sorts of things is the sort of shonky level of political debate which discredits this place. I am not going to do that. But the fact of the matter is that that is a reality.

Opposition senators come in here and make a lot of noise about the current account deficit announced on Monday. The current account deficit represents 3.4 per cent of GDP. When those opposite were in office throughout the 1970s, the current account deficit was a higher proportion of GDP than it was on Monday of this week. They should not come in here with all this pious talk. They have to recognise that in terms of structural adjustment, which is taking place now and which never took place under them, we are closer to achieving these goals than we were several years ago. There is no doubt about that. I have absolute confidence in that taking place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Yet again we have seen another total failure by this Minister to answer the questions put to him. Let me try again. I refer the Minister to today's dramatic and accurate statements about our nation's economic crisis by leading business identities, Paul Simon and Don Argus. I ask him to have a look at those and contrast them with the vacuous utterings of the Bobby McFarren of the Keating Government, Mr `Don't worry, be happy' Dawkins. I invite the Leader of the Government again, on behalf of the Prime Minister, to inform the Australian electorate: what is the Government's so-called fifth term agenda? Does it actually have any new policies for a further term in office? If so, when will it have the guts to let the Australian public know about them?

—I really do not know what Senator Short is talking about. It is only this week that the Leader of the Opposition said that the Opposition would be bringing out new policies on a range of issues. He said that only this week. Senator Short and Senator Hill said last year—and I have them on the record in that file—`Fightback is the thing we are going to the election on. We don't need any new policies. We'll go to the election on Fightback'. `Look at the polls', they used to say. `People will support us'. In August, September, October last year they were saying these things. `Look at the polls. Fightback is the thing upon which we will go to the election'. I thought that Mr Argus's comments were measured and sensible. I thought the—(Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook. The Minister would be aware of the attacks by the Premier of Victoria on nurses taking strike action against his industrial relations legislation which would reduce their take home pay. Is the introduction of similar legislation to remove penalty rates from awards and to force workers into individual employment contracts and thus reduce take home pay planned by this Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I will tell honourable senators what the Government will not do. Nurses in Melbourne are apparently today demonstrating and marching on the Victorian Parliament. The response by the Victorian Minister for Health, Marie Tehan, according to radio, is that she has promised that she will sack 3,500 health workers. This Government will not conduct industrial relations on that basis. As I have said, we do not take any joy from the ongoing industrial unrest in Victoria. It does not have a positive economic impact.

PARA.TAB: The blame for this action has to be laid squarely at the door of Mr Jeff Kennett. I will refer honourable senators to the latest `Jeffism' concerning nurses. Last week in the Australian Financial Review Mr Kennett commented about nurses. I believe that nurses are regarded in our community as workers who are specifically dedicated to their profession, who are self-sacrificing and who are not, in the scheme of things, regarded as overly highly paid. Of nurses, Mr Kennett said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . it must give them a great deal of pleasure to walk away from hospitals, not hurting the Government with their actions, but making those who are sick suffer just that little bit more.

Mr Kennett's comments would have us believe that nurses are, in fact, undermining the level of health care by taking protests. They are not. They have ensured that the needs of patients in hospitals who are in any state of criticality or health need are protected but, at the same time, they are taking industrial action. They are taking industrial action as a group of Australian workers who traditionally never ever do so. But Jeff Kennett has forced them on to the streets into protest.

PARA.TAB: Why has he done that? The Kennett Government has proposed to abolish penalty rates, which means that the weekly income of a nurse who is a shift worker is reduced by 25 per cent—a reduction in income of a quarter. No-one in our community—no-one in this chamber—can afford to have their income cut by a quarter unilaterally. In the case of nurses it has been cut by that amount without any recourse to fair arbitration, without any independent inquiry and without any right for nurses to state their position in a proper forum. It has just been done unilaterally. It is an example of Liberal Party's industrial relations policy in action. It is what John Howard and Dr Hewson would do if they were in power. It brings Australia back to disputation and confrontation, something that we left behind in the days of Fraser. It is something that this Government will not do. We will work with Australian workers to improve the economy—not against them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thought I heard the Minister say that the Kennett Government threatened to sack 3,500 nurses. If this were to take place, how does the Government plan to staff hospitals and provide health services? Is this not making the sick suffer?

—Mr President, I take a point of order. That question has nothing whatsoever to do with the Minister's area of responsibility. It is simply inviting the Minister to speculate on what action the Victorian Government might be forced to take as a result of the intransigence of Senator Cook's colleagues.
—Order! I really do not think it was a proper supplementary. I think it was asked because of an aside that the Minister made.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the Government's plan to eliminate quantitative restrictions on imports in textiles from March next year. I ask: is the Minister aware of the textile and clothing industries' belief that the removal of quantitative restrictions, which are far more important than tariffs in this area, will cause employment in the industries to fall by another 25,000 people? Is the Minister aware that no other OECD country has such a policy and that, in fact, the Americans and Europeans have bilateral agreements which prevent products such as low cost, subsidised bed linen from flooding their markets? I ask: has the Government decided that the low capital, labour intensive sections of the textile and clothing industries have no future in this country? Finally, is the Minister willing to display the flexibility in industry policy which he says distinguishes him from the coalition and at least reschedule the insane timing of the quota cuts, or, at best, drop the plan to eliminate them altogether?

—The proposed abolition of quotas in the textile, clothing and footwear industry at 1 March next year will make little difference to the industry because of the current situation of taking up of quotas in this year. It is not likely to be an extraordinarily dramatic event in itself. But the point of the question is: why do we not offer high levels of protection to low cost, labour intensive industries in Australia when so many other countries offer them to theirs. We are in a geographically different position from European countries that do, in some cases, offer some higher levels of protection. Seven out of 10 of our major trading partners are in this area. Both from the point of view of consumer benefit and trade we have to take that fact into account.

PARA.TAB: But it is ridiculous for the honourable senator to say, as about a third of the textile, clothing and footwear industry might now do, that these industries have no future in Australia. Of course they have a future. They do not have a future making cheap clothes. They do have a future making quality clothes produced for the upper end of the market. We have a great future in textiles in this country. We have an extraordinarily good future in leather production in Australia, which has been shown now in the export figures. Throughout sections of this industry there are companies that are doing extraordinarily well. Look at the brand names that we sell overseas and will continue to sell overseas: Sheridan sheets, Maggie Shepherd dresses, Country Road clothing. One can go through a whole set of companies in this industry which are not amongst those who are saying that the world has come to an end because they have only 50 per cent tariff at present. They are not saying that; they are getting on with the job, and they will continue to do so.

It is ridiculous to say that this industry is finished. Every time there is a downturn in the Australian economy this industry is the first on politicians' doorsteps saying, `We are losing a huge number of employees'. That happened in 1983 and it happened in this recession. Although the industry will be smaller over time, we will have a very good industry in this country because it is now concentrating on the things it does best instead of trying to do everything which countries with lower labour costs and so on can afford to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer, but indeed it is those people who make sheets—which was one example the Minister gave—who are most concerned about the Government's policies and where they are heading. Does the Minister agree that we had an 8 per cent increase in imports in this area in October alone, and that already there have been massive losses in employment? Where are these people supposed to go? The Minister mentioned in his answer that we will have a smaller industry, so where will these people now be working?

—First of all, if we look at textile and clothing industries around the world—in the European countries that were mentioned and so on—we will see that the import penetration in clothing, footwear and textiles in Australia is low by international standards. It is less than 30 per cent. For example, in Sweden I think the import penetration level is 90 per cent. In various countries in Europe it is much higher than ours.

PARA.TAB: What is important about the European industries, as distinct from ours, is that their export propensity is much higher. The exports from those countries are huge. If we have to set about the task of trying to help an industry to restructure, it has to be about exports. That is something which industries can do. For example, it is something which Sheridan, which I mentioned, is doing, as are a lot of other companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—I direct my question to Senator Collins representing the Minister for Tourism. I refer the Minister to media reports of an attack by Mr Tenshin Kobayashi in a Japanese travel magazine in which he criticised the Australian Tourist Commission, accusing it of being obsessed with building tourism numbers `at all costs'. Mr Kobayashi was critical of Qantas and its choice of Cairns as a major tourism destination. I ask the Minister: has this criticism any foundation? Can the Minister inform the Senate about the aims of the Australian Tourist Commission in promoting Australia as a tourist destination, and what its activities mean in economic terms for this country?

—I am aware of these criticisms by Mr Kobayashi, who is the marketing manager for the Tokyo based Play Guide Travel Company. However, not only are they not borne out by an examination of the situation in Japan, but also I am pleased to say that, on the information available, the situation with Japanese tourism currently—to the great credit of the Australian Tourist Commission—is very positive indeed.

PARA.TAB: The ATC maintains a close liaison with the major Japanese wholesalers and retailers of tourism packages into Australia to ensure that the needs of business operators and the travelling public are met. It is consistent, is it not, that when you have a good news story to tell about Australia, it always gets knocked by the Opposition in the Senate? Surveys to determine—

TALK.START.PARA: —If you don't listen to the buyer you're dead!

—Perhaps Senator Parer would like to listen to this point: surveys to determine the effectiveness of the ATC's advertising campaigns in Japan have found that Australia is the most desired destination for travel and the No. 1 destination for intended travel. In 1990 a study was conducted of the satisfaction levels of travellers from Japan, and that investigation discovered that holidays to Australia surpassed expectations prior to travel in all areas, including service and infrastructure. Respondents rated Australia highest for scenery, enjoyment, the vastness of the country, its people, friendliness and safety. Ninety-seven per cent of respondents said that they had enjoyed their holidays.

PARA.TAB: The ATC and the Government are conscious of the need to maintain the quality of the holidays, as the continued growth of Australia as a tourist destination is largely influenced by word of mouth reports from those who have travelled here and who repeat visitation. I might add that I never miss the opportunity to speak to tourists every time I come across them in the Northern Territory. I am delighted to say that they express a high degree of satisfaction about what they are offered in Australia.

The ATC has been a highly successful organisation in its international promotions, which have led to an increase in arrivals to Australia from under one million tourists in 1983 to 2.52 million last financial year. The growth has been led by increases in travel from Japan. Arrivals from Japan were 25 per cent higher for the first nine months of this year compared with the same period last year.

Australia has also continued to increase its share of the outbound market. In September, when there was a 3 per cent decline in travel out of Japan, travel from Japan to Australia increased by 4 per cent. All in all, it is a very satisfactory situation in terms of the Japanese tourist market, and it is a credit to the organisation in terms of its promotions of Australia in Japan.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to his answer in Question Time yesterday during which he tabled a contract of employment between Copperart and its employees. In his answer, the Minister stated:

QUESTION.PARA: I have a document . . . which is a proposed individual employment contract put to workers in Victoria.

In condemning this as an application of the new Victorian industrial relations system, why did the Minister not tell the truth: that this is a voluntary agreement being offered to employees, without compulsion, across Australia under his industrial relations system and has had a 95 per cent acceptance rate among Copperart employees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Parer for confirming the existence of this very pernicious work contract which broke award standards in Victoria under the award I cited yesterday—which, as I recall, is entitled the electrical retailing award. It will reduce the income of the persons for whom it was proposed by $41.86c per week.
—It's under your system!
—In the face of these interjections, I say categorically say that this is not our system; this is the Kennett industrial relations system. If I am allowed to, I will complete my answer.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Could you ask the Minister whether he is trying to tell us that the State of Victoria now makes laws for the Commonwealth of Australia?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—There is no point of order, although that was yet another vexatious example. The individual work contract which is being offered to workers who are employed by Copperart and which I tabled yesterday is in breach—
—Across Australia?

—It is in breach of awards across Australia as it rolls working on Thursday nights or Friday nights for late night shopping or working all day for Saturday shopping into a flat rate per hour irrespective of the existence of penalty rates.In the case of the Victorian agreement, my statement was absolutely 100 per cent accurate. It has been checked by both my legal department and me. I am advised by the relevant union that in fact—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections. I cannot hear the Minister's answer.

—Copperart has said to its employees in Victoria, `Accept this contract or be sacked'. Copperart has not said it in those crude terms. It has said, `If your loyalty to the company is not such that you will agree to this, we may have to review our relationship'. It has said it `silently' and quietly, but the inference is totally unmistakable. Therefore, I am not surprised that a number of people faced with that sort of private coercion and without access to the protection of their award, as soon will be the case in Victoria, have had to choose between accepting a reduction in their income of $42-odd a week. Mr President, this is not our industrial relations system in operation at all.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If these parrots and cockatoos opposite will be quiet, I will explain the facts of the law to them so they will know where they are wrong and will then cease their unruly interjections because they will know that they are wrong. Under our system the contract has to be presented to the Commission, and if it reduces the award rate it is illegal and disallowed. In this case this contract would be disallowed.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that the Minister has talked about this income being reduced, how does he explain that under the voluntary agreement contract which has been offered, the increase in wages as compared to the award, and taking into account 10 hours overtime a week, will be $29 more a week instead of the $42 less that the Minister talks about?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Simply because Senator Parer is wrong—absolutely, A-grade wrong—and he has been clean bowled middle stump. It is interesting that he simply accepts one side of this argument. He simply accepts what the employer says. He does not go to the award and check. If he checks the award, he will find that this so-called contract is at $12 an hour, no penalty rates for overtime and no penalty rates for weekend work. The actual loss to the worker is more than the $41.86 that I mentioned. The actual loss is greater.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is an important question and an important answer. The Minister should be given the courtesy of giving the Government side of the argument on this matter. It should be heard because it will need to be understood by the electorate. Interjections in this place are unruly and I suggest we will have to look at a new standing order to give those opposite a breathalyser before they come in here after lunch.

—Order! There is no point of order, but there are far too many interjections from both sides of the chamber. Some people on my left are persistently interjecting, ignoring the Chair and I will not hesitate to name them.
—Mr President, on a point of order: there was a serious reflection in what Senator McKiernan said and I ask you that you require him to withdraw it.
—Order! I think it was an imputation, Senator McKiernan, and you ought to withdraw it.
—I suggest that it was a debating point rather than anything else.
—Order! At a time when I am asking for order in the chamber, I ask you to withdraw it.
—In deference to you, Mr President, I withdraw.
—No, Senator McKiernan, you will withdraw.
—I withdraw.

—I know those opposite are trying to gag me because an assertion has been made which is wrong. The Opposition believes the lies it has been told and has latched on to them as if they were truth. I am happy to submit the truth of this matter to an independent arbitrator so that the truth can come out. Let us see then whether the Opposition maintains this fiction. If that is done, it will be shown that this is a reduction of $41.86 per week per worker.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. Is the Minister aware that the Victorian Government has withdrawn operational funding to day care nurseries from 1 January 1993, putting in jeopardy the future of 34 centres which have 18 days to find other sources of funds, having been comprehensively Jeffed? If so, how did the Minister become aware of this decision? Is the Minister aware that the Victorian Government is insisting that the Commonwealth provision of operational subsidy and fee relief to subsidised child-care centres should be extended to the State day nurseries to cover the State funding cut? What is the state of negotiations between the Commonwealth and Victoria on this matter? How does this situation relate to the fact that Victoria has not yet become a signatory to the national child-care strategy?

—I understand that the Victorian Government has announced the withdrawal of its funding support for the State day nurseries from 1 January next year. I am sure that would be a shock to many households and families throughout Victoria who do use those State day nurseries. I think since the mid-1940s the State Government of Victoria has provided operational funding for those nurseries. It now wishes to transfer the funding responsibility to the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: Senator Powell asked when we learnt about this. I think it was about 19 November, when a public meeting or some such thing was held and this became apparent, that we first became aware of it. The Commonwealth has been providing child-care fee relief to all private and State funded child-care services, including the State day nurseries, since 1 January 1991 and will continue to do so. But we are not going to accept this transfer of funding on the operational side, which the State Government obviously wishes to impose on the Commonwealth taxpayers.

The Commonwealth will not assume responsibility of funding for services which have been a longstanding Victorian Government responsibility. The State of Victoria has now moved quite unilaterally to defund its operational funding responsibilities in this area and has tried to transfer them to the Commonwealth taxpayers, including Tasmanians—and we are not going to cop it.

Senator Powell also asked what negotiations are going on. I understand that Victoria has not accepted a Commonwealth offer to cost share the increased provision of non-profit, community based child-care in Victoria. I believe the majority of the other States and Territories have reached agreement on this. So, altogether, there seems to be an impasse and an attempt to shift funding responsibility to the Commonwealth. We are not going to accept that.

I am advised that a public meeting on 30 November passed a resolution condemning the Kennett Government's withdrawal of funding for State day nurseries and its failure to sign the national child-care growth strategy. This is altogether a very sad story of unilateral imposition on households and families by the Victorian Government. I am sure it will be rejected by all those households and families, and I have no doubt that Senator Powell would share that sentiment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Now that the Australian Securities Commission is having an inquiry into the Prime Minister's piggery group in which he paid $430,000 for a half interest that the company itself reported was worth $4.2m only six weeks later, I ask: will the Government at last have its own inquiry into Mr Keating's blatant breach of Cabinet rules by not advising the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, that he had acquired a half interest in the piggery group on 15 May 1991 while he was still Treasurer despite the Cabinet rule requirement that `any substantial alterations' to his declaration of interest be advised to the Prime Minister `as soon as they occur'? Mr Keating made no declaration of any kind until 7 June when he became a backbencher after his failed coup attempt. I know for a fact that he did not inform Mr Hawke as required. Why have such Cabinet rules if they do not have to apply to Mr Keating?

—I often refer to Senator Baume as a scarred veteran of 100 shadow ministries. He is the shadow Minister for the arts and heritage. In the last 12 months he has not asked one question about his shadow Ministry. He has now asked 17 questions at the instigation of his Leader in the other House, who does not have the courage to ask them himself.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Baume asked a perfectly straightforward, direct question of the Minister. He is attempting to volunteer information regarding things that are not relevant to that question. I would ask you to ask him to answer the question which is within his responsibility.

—On that point of order, Mr President, this is the fourth time during this Question Time that we have had points of order raised that were not points of order. It is a blatant breach of the Standing Orders and a blatant disruption of the business of the Senate. I ask you to advise senators that raising points of orders when no standing order is being breached is itself a breach of the Standing Orders.

—On the point of order, Mr President—a very important point of order—the Minister well knows that senators are entitled to ask questions on a range of matters; frontbenchers are not confined to asking questions in their own areas of responsibility. Therefore, it is quite irrelevant for the Minister to take up time in pretending that somehow frontbenchers are so constrained. I therefore ask you to rule that part of his answer out of order.

—Mr President, on the point of order: this is the second time that Senator Bishop has called a point of order. She called a point of order during an answer I was giving a moment ago which was clearly and blatantly in breach of the Standing Orders. She purports to be an expert on the Standing Orders. In the past, she has quoted the Standing Orders to justify her points of order, but that was a blatant breach and Senator Bishop knows better. She is doing it again and she is delaying the proceedings of this Senate. She should be sat down and indication should be given that if any of these vexatious points of order continue, the people making them will be cut off and the time for Ministers to answer questions will be extended.

—Mr President, on Senator Alston's point of order where he asks you to direct the Minister on how to answer the question, I point out that Senator Button is entitled to go to the credibility or lack of credibility of Senator Baume. I do not think that Senator Baume will object to that. I do not see why Senator Alston has to step in and try to protect him.

—Order! Today, in particular, there have been too many spurious points of order from both sides. The question was in order. In relation to the point of order that was taken on Senator Button, he had hardly started to speak at all, but I ask Senator Button to answer the question that he was asked.

—I was interested that Senator Bishop led on this issue. It is Senator Bishop who, in the Senate, tried our Ambassador to Thailand on a charge of sexual harassment. It is Senator Bishop who prejudged the so-called loans Committee.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. That Senator Bishop tried the Ambassador to Thailand on that charge is a reflection upon her. She is certainly entitled to ask the questions that she asked without any reflection being made against her as to her motive. I ask that you ask Senator Button to withdraw that. It is factually incorrect and it reflects upon her.
—Order! I do not think it is a point of order; I think it is a debating point. I ask Senator Button to answer the question.
—Let me just say about this issue—
—You'll do anything rather than answer the question.
—Perhaps, if I am going to be continually interrupted, I will finish with Senator Bishop. Just let me say this: Senator Bishop even prejudged the US election.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Button is flouting your order again and again. You have just ruled that he should answer the question asked by Senator Baume. He refutes your ruling by saying, `Just let me finish saying what I am saying'. Either he should be sat down or he should answer the question in terms of your current and previous rulings.
—Order! There is no point of order. I am sure Senator Button was doing that.

—Mr President, I respect your ruling in this matter. What I was just pointing to was the course of conduct of the Opposition. Senator Baume asks these questions at the instigation of his Leader in the other House who could ask them directly of the Prime Minister himself and does not dare. So he sends Senator Baume over here to do it on his behalf. Senator Baume started off on this issue about six months ago. His first three goes were quite wrong and he is still at it.

PARA.TAB: As far as I am concerned, as a Minister in this Government, arrangements between citizens in this country, irrespective of who they are, and the Taxation Commissioner will have the respect which they deserve, and that is privacy. Arrangements between the Australian Securities Commission and people under its aegis will, as far as I am concerned, have respect and privacy. They will not be matters which are the subject of scuttlebutt in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the question.

—Senator Bishop says that is not so, because she wants to do it all the time in here. She is in league with her colleague Senator Baume on this issue. Senator Bishop can keep on trying, but these are not matters which are appropriate for debate in the Senate, they are not matters within my ministerial responsibility and they are not matters about which I intend to follow Senator Bishop down her snail trail and emulate everything she does.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's comment that the Prime Minister's breaching of Cabinet requirements is not a matter for the Senate. In view of the fact that at recent Senate Estimates I was criticised for asking too many questions relating to arts and sport, I now ask: if the Minister cannot answer the question I have asked today, can he answer the question that Australians want to ask? How did Paul Keating turn $430,000 into $4.2m, or are his company's figures just plain shonky?
—As Senator Baume well knows, to talk about a company in which the Prime Minister has a shareholding, as if he owned it—
—A half share!

—No, as if he owned it. Senator Baume talks about figures which he ought to understand, as a former partner in Patrick Partners, and does not. I am not going to answer all these questions. Why should I bother? This lot opposite want to involve themselves with everybody's privacy and Senator Bishop is their principal supporter in this little exercise.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister reviewed yesterday's television broadcast of an alleged interview by East Timor's Governor Mario Soares of captured Fretilin leader Xanana Gusmao? What confidence does the Minister have that the man interviewed was Xanana Gusmao, and that he was not speaking under any duress? What progress has been made towards securing access to Xanana Gusmao by the Red Cross and Amnesty International?

—I have not seen the interview referred to by Senator Bourne, but it has been seen by officers in our Jakarta Embassy. The embassy confirms that Xanana Gusmao was speaking in a prerecorded interview with East Timor's Governor Soares. I do not think it is possible for the Government to comment authoritatively on the circumstances in which the interview was made. We do not know for sure. We can say that our embassy reports that Xanana appeared well in the interview and there were no obvious signs of duress. The Government has sought assurances from the Indonesian Government at the highest levels that Xanana will not be ill-treated and that he will be accorded due legal process. Having received these assurances, we remain confident that they will be honoured.

PARA.TAB: Our latest information indicates that Xanana has not yet received visits from the International Committee of the Red Cross or international or other national non-government organisations. As Senator Evans said last week, the Government has specifically requested the Indonesian Government to allow the ICRC access and we continue to support its efforts in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Consumer Affairs. I refer to a statement and subsequent radio interview today by a senior member of the Trade Practices Commission, Mr Allen Asher, accusing life insurance agents of all manner of dishonourable conduct. Is it a fact that such comments not only completely pre-empt the findings of a continuing Trade Practices Commission research project in which life agents have been enthusiastically participating, but also are starkly at odds with survey results which show consumer approval rates of the industry of 81 per cent? Can the Minister confirm that he has already given the Commissioner concerned, to use his own description, `an almighty serve'? Has the Minister undertaken to do the same to his colleague Ms McHugh? Can the Minister explain why Mr Asher, a former employee of the Australian Consumers Association, should not be regarded as irredeemably biased and unfit to remain a member of the Commission?

—I certainly do not regard Mr Asher as being irredeemably flawed by his background of association with the consumer movement. I believe he brings great strength to the Trade Practices Commission in its various deliberations. However, I do regard the fact that he has made some statements—which I do not have before me—which indicate a view as to the way in which the life insurance industry ought to reform itself or to be reformed as being somewhat pre-emptive in relation to the report which is to be published by the Trade Practices Commission within two or three weeks. It is that aspect, not so much of prejudice but the indication of a viewpoint before the publication of the report, which led me to an expression of concern.

PARA.TAB: The continuing cooperation of life insurance agents and their representatives in what I believe has been a very constructive series of consultations with the Trade Practices Commission inquiry is not totally jeopardised by this particular action of Mr Asher. Sufficient good work has been done during that consultation process to enable a confidence in the final report still to be held within the life insurance industry.

Nevertheless, in so far as the report—and the inquiry itself—was generated by widespread concern in the community, I have no doubt that it will touch on matters which are still of concern to those who have dealings with the life insurance industry and agents. I hope that it is a very considered, well documented, well researched and balanced report. If it is, it will have a ready acceptance within the life insurance industry. If it includes such reforms as indicated are necessary in order to enable consumers to better play their role in the marketplace and fully understand the products that are offered to them, then I believe those reforms should be readily and speedily implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it correct that the Minister has indeed rebuked Mr Asher and made clear his own displeasure in his own terms? Has the Minister given Mr Asher an almighty serve and has he undertaken to others to do the same to Ms McHugh?

—I have certainly not indicated any intention to deal with a ministerial colleague in any such terms as have been indicated by Senator Alston. In so far as I have conversations with persons, I regard those as private.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Is the Minister aware of media reports, and the rally to be held outside Parliament House today by the New South Wales Teachers Federation, protesting about changes to adult migrant English language courses? Has the Government reduced funding for adult migrant English language courses, reduced hours and introduced fees, as claimed by the New South Wales Teachers Federation?

—The campaign that is being waged at the moment—and I believe there was some sort of rally outside Parliament House earlier—is based on a completely distorted impression that has been given to those participating by certain leaders, principally within the New South Wales Teachers Federation. The fact is that the Government has increased its funding in the current financial year by $27m to a total of $143m for the teaching of English to those migrants and refugees who come here who obviously need to participate fully in the community, socially and culturally, and to engage in employment and ordinary commercial life and other transactions. There is a need for them to be fully equipped to participate in the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: The Government is prepared to make a contribution but we are saying that, whereas the average tuition time which was offered to past clients of the adult migrant English program was some 370 hours, they should have an entitlement of 510 hours of tuition. I am told that some were getting 900 hours and some were getting 2000 hours.That cannot be funded by the Commonwealth Government in an open-ended way.

We are offering 510 hours of tuition. In relation to some of those persons who are receiving such tuition, we are asking for a modest payment of $250; that is, 50c an hour to be taught English to enable people to equip themselves to participate fully—socially, in employment and in other spheres—in the Australian community. As I say, $250 is the normal fee for residents for 510 hours of tuition. Migrants overseas wanting to come to Australia will pay varying fees. For example, a person in the concessional family category will pay $1,020 before getting a visa, while a person coming under the employment nomination scheme or the business skills program will pay $4,080.

Refugees who come under special humanitarian categories and those who are registered job seekers or hold a health care card will not have to pay the $250. So in fact this is a very practically oriented program which does not deny the possibility of—
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If Senator Alston and Senator Ray are going to have a private conversation, could they conclude it outside the chamber?

—The charging fee structure that will come into place on 1 January will obviously take account of those persons who cannot afford to pay. But 510 hours of tuition will be offered. People will be able to derive a very substantial personal benefit in social, employment and other terms from undertaking these courses. That will be their entitlement for a small fee of $250. As I say, it is a worthwhile program and the Government believes that the distortions relating to it should be rebutted.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that in the last three months Australia's foreign debt grew by more than it did in the entire 80 years immediately following Federation. Given that our gross foreign debt now stands at $209 billion—which is more than that of Brazil at $169 billion; more than that of Chile, Mexico or Colombia; and twice Argentina's debt of $89 billion—when will the Labor Party be honest with the Australian public and admit that we are now the Argentina of South East Asia? What policies do the people on the other side of the chamber have to solve this foreign debt crisis which is about to consume the future of the next generation of Australians?
—Mr President, Senator O'Chee's elocution is better than his erudition. Just let me say a few words about that. If you go around this country spreading lies like that, we will be following after you.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. You probably do not need me to remind you that that is a gross breach of the Standing Orders. Senator Button has no right to suggest that anybody tells lies in this place. He should be asked to withdraw it promptly.
—It is unparliamentary to suggest that Senator O'Chee was a liar.
—No, Mr President—I did not suggest that. I said, `If you are to go around the country spreading lies like that'. I am not suggesting that he has done that.
—Continue, Senator Button.

—Mr President, on the point of order: are you ruling that that language is disorderly or are you ruling that it is orderly? Senator Button is playing on words. He knows what he was saying; he knows what he meant. It is thoroughly disorderly and contrary to the Standing Orders. It does him no good service and he should apologise.
—I will withdraw if it is taken as an imputation against Senator O'Chee. If that is the way he takes it, I withdraw.
—Stop grinning.

—I have now been accused by the Opposition of grinning, for God's sake! There must be a point of order there. The lad has asked a very dramatic question. But it is absolute nonsense to equate this country's foreign debt, which is at about the middle of the OECD pecking order, with countries in South America like the ones Senator O'Chee mentioned.

PARA.TAB: This country's sovereign debt is very low. Private sector debt, true, is high. But the debts of Mexico and Brazil and the other countries to which Senator O'Chee referred are government debts; they are sovereign debt. Those opposite really have to become better educated about some of these things if they ever want to be in government.

The Commonwealth Government of Australia was a net foreign lender to the tune of $4.7 billion last year. The Commonwealth Government reduces the total private sector debt figure. I do not know what those opposite think the total figure is. In an urgency motion which is before the Senate today, those opposite say that the gross foreign debt is $200 billion. They want to concentrate on that figure rather than the net foreign debt, which is the relevant figure. Senator O'Chee said the figure was $209 billion. I do not know whether he is suggesting that it has gone up in the hour since the urgency motion was put together. That is very dangerous stuff, if that is what he is trying to do.

I might say one or two other things about Australia's debt. The important thing about debt is the capacity to service it. Those opposite never talk about the fact that, since this Government came to office, Australian investment overseas has increased to $58 billion. It was not there when we came into government.

Those opposite do not want to talk about any of those figures. They play this schoolboy debating trick of either saying that it represents so much per family or, in Senator O'Chee's case, making these silly comparisons with countries in South America which have high levels of sovereign debt. No respectable economist would do that and a young senator should not do it either because, in the longer term, it will run him into trouble.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does Senator Button really want the Senate to believe that our private sector debt is of absolutely no significance to the future of this nation? Given that Senator Button wishes to talk about this nation's ability to repay its debt, perhaps he might like to direct his mind to the fact that Argentina, Chile and places such as that run a balance of trade surplus, whereas this Government has delivered to Australia not only higher debt, but also a balance of payments deficit. Can Senator Button direct his mind to those questions and give us an honest answer?

—I am being invited by Senator O'Chee, whose first question was silly and ignorant, to fix him up in my answer to his supplementary question. The supplementary question asks whether I believe that private sector overseas debt is unimportant. I never said that for a moment. So Senator O'Chee should not misrepresent me in order to cover up his own intellectual deficiencies and ignorance with regard to this matter. That is his problem, not mine.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Parer this day relating to employment contracts.

SPEECH.PARA: During Question Time I asked Senator Cook to explain why he misled the Senate yesterday in response to a dorothy dixer question from Senator Faulkner. In answer to the question during Question Time yesterday, Senator Cook waved a document around saying, `I have a document that proves that the ink that is not yet dry on the Kennett industrial relations system is already working to the detriment of the people of Victoria'. Senator Cook is wrong. This document applies across-the-board to all the operations of Copperart in Australia. It is not something that is specific to Victoria. He then went on to say:
. . . this offer is based on a `take this contract or be sacked' style of negotiation.

Senator Cook is wrong. He should have checked his facts before he deliberately misled this place. This contract is being offered on a voluntary basis. The employees of Copperart are being offered the choice of staying within the award system or taking the contract. Ninety-five per cent of them have taken the contract because they will get more money out of it. In his answer, the Minister then went on to say:
The contract proposes a $12 hourly rate for 38 hours, with an abolition of rates for working late on Thursday and Friday nights. . .

Senator Cook is wrong. If he would like to check with Copperart, the 38 hours includes working Thursdays and Saturdays or Fridays and Saturdays. If he just wants to check the figures, the award rate in Victoria—which for this particular group of people is the highest of anywhere in Australia—for a 38-hour week, where people work three hours on a Thursday or Friday or seven hours on a Saturday, is $427.41. As I have said, that is much lower in other States because we know how silly the Victorians have been and the way in which they have brought their State into the basket case position. Under the contract being offered by Copperart it is $456, which represents a $30 increase—not the $47 or so that the Minister talked about.

PARA.TAB: Further in the Minister's answer he said:

SPEECH.PARA: This is a reduction of $41.86 per week. . .
That is in wages. I have shown quite clearly that it represents an increase. In respect of the answer to the supplementary question, another dorothy dixer, he said:
They relate to loss of annual leave loading,. . .

and so on. Senator Cook is absolutely wrong. In fact, holiday pay is calculated on the basis of four weeks at $456 a week. The Minister went on in his answer to say that there will be a loss of the full level of superannuation entitlement. Senator Cook is wrong. In fact, the superannuation is calculated on 4 per cent of the $456, which is higher than the employees would have been paid if they had worked under the award.

PARA.TAB: I believe that this Minister has to come clean on this. It is all very well for him in hysteria to grab at something to support his own particular constituency—which is the ACTU and the Trades and Labour Council stuck down in Melbourne—but he is prepared to do anything to distort things. I do not mind him coming forward with a decent argument, but when he does not do his homework he deserves some criticism by this place. I ask: why did he table a document which was not limited to Victoria? Why did he not point out that the flat hourly rate included allowances for overtime? Why did he not state that the proposal was voluntary and that employees have the choice of accepting it or not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear that what we have here is an attempt to defend by attacking—and by attacking me on grounds that are not true, that are erroneous and that do not hold up to proper inspection. The award that applies in the particular case of the classification of `employee' that I referred to yesterday is, as I recall—and I do not have the paper in front of me—the electrical and hardware retail award. Under the classification of `manager' in that award, which equates with the classification of the person to whom this document was presented, there is a weekly reduction in gross pay of an amount of about $41.80c-plus per week.

PARA.TAB: The contract that was presented is a contract which purports to do a range of things. One of the things that it purports to do is to replace penalty rates for working on Thursday night for late-night shopping or on Fridays, or penalty rates of payment for working all day Saturday. As I recall, the document required the individual to present for work for 38 hours at any of those times as directed and receive a flat payment of $12 per hour. If we add that up and compare it with what they would receive, attracting penalty rates for working after the normal spread of working hours on Thursday night or Friday or all day Saturday, the reduction in the award, I repeat, is $41.80c-plus. They are the facts of the case.

Let me look now at what has been said. I am marked down as having misled because, according to the allegation, this was presented all over Australia and not just in Victoria. Logic dictates that it was therefore presented in Victoria. If it was presented elsewhere, what would be the legal standing of that document? That document's legal standing elsewhere would be that it would be illegal where it breached the standards of the award because it did not pay for the penalty rates for working on weekends and overtime and it therefore could not stand, unless people wished to collude to break the law. That is the first point.

The second point is that in Victoria it was presented as a voluntary agreement. This is a retail store, part of a chain. I have seen the covering letter to the agreement, and if those opposite want me to present it for them to see the terms in which it was presented to the individual worker, I will produce that happily. The terms of the covering letter make it clear that there is an obligation, expected by the management, on the individual to agree to this document and to accept a cut in gross pay of $41.86 cents—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that in the letter?

—That is the implication that anyone can clearly draw from the letter: `If you don't accept this, then we will have to review our relationship with you as an employee'. In a labour market such as Victoria it means `Accept this contract or be sacked'. Everyone knows that. We do not have to spell it out in neon lights. The implication is well understood by ordinary people.

PARA.TAB: The other thing with this contract that I thought was totally unbelievable, until I saw it in writing, is that it lists a series of areas in which people can be instantly dismissed without having any benefits at all. One of them is if employees are believed to have been loitering in the toilets. Another one is if they engage in gambling or in lotteries. Who judges what is fair? Those employees have no access to the umpire under this agreement to judge whether the actions were fair or not. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to make some comments on the answer that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has given. This is one of the great battles which have now been joined by the two major parties as we go to the next election. One of the problems this Government has is that the enterprise based agreements typically give a major advantage to employees. Senator Cook and his colleagues set out day after day to misrepresent the nature of these particular agreements. In view of the fact that Senator Cook, in his comments, laid particular stress on the agreement being compulsory, I quote from a press release that Copperart issued:

SPEECH.PARA: All First Senior Shop Assistants in Copperart will be invited to join this totally non-compulsory scheme. If the employee does not elect to take up the contract, they are most welcome to remain on the current state award rate of remuneration.

That is a very key point, I would have thought. The interesting figure that Senator Parer quoted was that 95 per cent of employees, given a choice between the new contract—which, as has been shown, considerably increases their wages and salaries—and remaining on the award, naturally chose to go on the new contract which was offered by the management.

PARA.TAB: Another point that was made in relation to overtime is particularly interesting. The press release from Copperart also says—again, a point not put forward by Senator Cook:

SPEECH.PARA: On an average 56 trading hours per week in an Australian Shopping Centre, the Copperart employee can now, in consultation with his or her Manager in charge, adjust the shop roster to work as many of the 56 hours as they like—

Therefore, a 50-hour week will yield $600. In comparison with the award wages, the new contract offered by Copperart will give very substantial benefits to its employees. Naturally, free from the restraints of the award and the trade union bosses, the employees have chosen to strike an award with the management of Copperart which is to their benefit and to the benefit of Copperart. I put it to you, Mr President, that a senior Minister of this Government has come into this chamber and deliberately misled this chamber and the Australian people as to the nature of this Copperart award.

PARA.TAB: This has become a major issue, because time and time again Senator Cook has come into this chamber and given totally misleading information. The contract, which has been signed by 95 per cent of Copperart employees, will give them a substantial benefit compared with the old trade union bosses' negotiated award. Senator Collins and the Labor Party really hate it when Australian workers and Australian management can get together and strike a decent deal to the advantage of both parties. The trade union bosses are cut out—and don't you people hate it!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President—
—Here is another one.

—Unlike those opposite, I do not cast reflection on the issues on which they speak depending on their background. I made the point the other day to a number of Opposition senators that I am an ex-union official and proud of it. I do not make any apologies for that. It gives me certain knowledge about industrial relations. I do not condemn those from the rural community because they happen to be members of the National Farmers Federation. I listen to what they have to say and I judge them on the quality and merits of their arguments; but I do not condemn them on the basis of where they come from.

PARA.TAB: On this issue, the Federal Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) is spot on and he is absolutely correct. He pointed out that the Copperart contract was offered to employees around Australia, including those in Victoria. It is a State award. It is clearly in breach of a number of awards in a number of States. It is certainly not in breach of the new regime in Victoria, it is certainly not in breach of the new changes in Tasmania, and it is probably not in breach of the new regime in New South Wales. But it is certainly in breach of the State award provisions in other States in the retail industry.

Senator Parer claims that 95 per cent of the employees voluntarily accepted this contract. Senator Cook made quite a legitimate offer. Let us put this offer before an independent arbiter who will determine how many people are better off and by how much. Let us go one step further: rather than accept the word of the employer through a media release, the word of the so-called union bosses or anyone's word, let us ask the employees. I challenge the Opposition to call a few of these employers and employees before a Senate committee. Let us ask the employees how they felt when they signed these contracts. Let us be the judge of it in a forum in which they can make a statement free of any alleged coercion.

Then we had a claim from Senator Campbell that employees are free to present themselves when they choose to go to work. Does anyone seriously believe that? The employer wants to know when employees will come to work. That employer wants a roster. The employee does not have any choice in that matter. The employee has to turn up when the employer wants him or her there. Frankly, if I were an employer, I would want the employee to turn up when I wanted him or her there. There is no freedom of choice in the hours that employees work.

The Opposition has to come to grips with the fact that it wants to abolish penalty rates and shift provisions by the back door. The Opposition is not honest enough to say, `This is our policy, let us abolish penalty rates and shift payments', because it knows the result. Fortunately, an ever increasing number of Australians are seeing the result in Victoria—chaos and a reduction in wages. That is John Howard's policy. That is the Liberal Party policy everywhere in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleagues in this debate on the motion to take note of an answer by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) to a question that was asked as a result of a question asked by Senator Faulkner yesterday of the Minister. Quite clearly in that answer yesterday Senator Cook set out to imply that the example given was typical of what would occur under Kennett legislation. In other words, he was quite clearly misleading this Senate and the people who were either listening to or watching a broadcast of Question Time. I quote from his answer; I will not deal with the figures of the various levels. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have a document which I will table which is a proposed individual employment contract put to workers in Victoria.
Even though it has been presented around Australia! I emphasise that. The Minister was, either deliberately or by default, emphasising that this contract related to Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is irrelevant.
—It is not irrelevant, because that man, who has left this chamber, clearly endeavoured to mislead the people who were watching the broadcast yesterday. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Before the State election in Victoria, a document was circularised by the Liberal Party in Victoria.
`Victoria', once again—no mention of Australia; no mention of any other awards. He tried to back out of it in his answer today. The answer he gave yesterday continued:
The contract by Copperart gives the lie to that undertaking—
referring to the Victorian situation—
and proves that employers, in some cases, will attempt to use the provisions in the Kennett legislation . . .

How in God's earth can an employer in New South Wales, Queensland, the ACT, South Australia, Tasmania or Western Australia use the Kennett legislation? How can he do it? He cannot do it. How the Minister thinks he can slide out of what he said yesterday by claiming in his answer today that it would be in breach of the award in the other States, I do not know. He clearly set out yesterday to link this contract, which he tabled here—he did not have a copy today, but I have—to the Kennett legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, Ha!
—Senator Button can laugh until he is blue in the face, but that was a major deception of this Parliament.
—It is legal in Victoria.

—It may be legal in Victoria, but he set out to mislead us that this document was linked to the Kennett legislation. It clearly is not linked to the Kennett legislation. I am prepared to take up his challenge to let an independent arbitrator look at it and see whether people are better off, whether they have better job security, whether they have more flexibility and whether it will increase employment in those businesses. I am prepared to look at all those things, because I believe it will achieve them, and I do not think we have one thing to hide. The point is that yesterday in that answer the Minister for Industrial Relations set out to mislead the Senate and the people listening to or watching Question Time by trying to link that contract to the Kennett legislation when it clearly is not linked.

—Some honourable senators opposite have indicated that industrial relations will be a substantial issue between the major parties in the next election. They surely are right about that. We know that what the Opposition seeks to do is to put this country back 100 years. What those opposite are talking about is not new; it is what happened under the servant and master legislation, when people had no rights to organise and to negotiate when they were at a disadvantage, and when judges in this country said in court cases that if they had been in a dispute situation they would have had the right to shoot the strikers. That is in a transcript of the shearers trials in Rockhampton. Those opposite may not be able to read well enough to understand it.
—Are you worried?

—No, I am not worried at all. We are discussing a contract. We would prefer to have and have striven to have agreements made between two parties which can be mutually beneficial. But what the Opposition has is a contract that was initiated by an employer and thrust upon the employees. Those opposite talk about certain public utterances that it is voluntary and that people can accept it or stay on the award—an award which the Opposition would like to destroy; awards in the Commonwealth area which it will destroy as quickly as it can; awards that will be destroyed in Australia by the current Victorian Government. The work force in Victoria is totally disenchanted about what is happening. To my knowledge, public servants who would never have considered going into dispute are thoroughly disenchanted and have joined the disputations that have developed.

PARA.TAB: There may not be collusion between the employer and employee in this case, but there is agreement to sign the contract because the employee has been stood over and intimidated. The company is saying publicly that it is voluntary, but employees know that, if they do not sign the agreement, they will not have a job. In Victoria in particular, their opportunity to protect their position is not very great.

The trade union movement was born out of a need for workers to protect their rights and positions. It will never be destroyed. In private industry in this country, union membership is not much beyond 30 to 40 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —And falling.

—It may well be falling. In recent times, because of the efforts of the Opposition, union membership is now starting to climb again, and will continue to do so. A great number of people are not members of unions, but they have the protection and rights under awards which have developed and been varied as a result of applications by unions. I challenge any member of the Opposition to tell me about a beneficial variation to any award which has resulted from an initiative of an employer or employer organisation.
—Mudginberri.

—Never. In the 31 years that the Opposition was in government, all it ever did was oppose wage applications in the Federal Court and try to prevent workers from having a reasonable standard of living and security and protection in their employment. Robe River was the result of a totally ineffective trade union and employer representation. (Time expired)

—We have just heard a short dissertation on class war from Senator Burns. He would like us to believe that employers and employees in Australia are in battle. We know that is not the case. Those of us who have been to successful workplaces or successful enterprises would know that there are very good relationships between employees and employers. Only a very small group of Australians want to continue the class warfare and the fight between employers and employees: Labor Party Ministers and members who do it for their own political ends.

PARA.TAB: Not one member from the Liberal or National parties wants to see employers and employees at each others' throats. We have heard today from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) that the Liberal Party would set out to reduce people's salaries by 25 per cent. He is right in one respect: we have joined together to reduce the pay of one small group of people in Australia by 25 per cent—the Government front bench. We would like to see their pay reduced and we want to see them on this side. I will admit to that.

The Liberal and National parties' policies are designed to enhance the living standards and the take-home pay of all Australian workers. We are not interested in setting out to have an industrial relations policy which reduces living standards, as the policies of the Government have done in the last 10 years.

Those honourable senators who tuned into Lateline last night because they were bored with the debate that was taking place in the Senate would have seen an excellent program on the destruction of the middle class in Australia and the destruction of the living standards of Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under your policies.

—Under Labor's policies over the last 10 years. The Liberal and National parties' programs seek to achieve that. The Copperart issue that we are talking about today is a classic example. These people have been given the freedom to choose how many hours they work—between 38 and 56 hours every week.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry said I was wrong when I said that they have freedom of choice. They do have freedom of choice. Of course, Senator Sherry is right; the employer likes to see people working when the customers are in the shops. But there are many hours during the week when a lot of shops do not have customers. It is quite silly for shop assistants and first assistants to be in the shop for many hours of the week when there are no customers there.

People are being given the freedom to choose the hours they work. They can work for either 38 hours or 56 hours. As Senator Kemp quite properly said, they are being given the freedom to earn up to $600 a week. Senator Cook would like to see them restricted to $450 a week. The Copperart offer gives them that freedom.

I do not know enough about Copperart or the negotiating process to put my neck on the line about how fair this process has been. The reality is that the offer gives people the choice between staying in the award system or going to a new deal where they have enormous freedom. Under this new deal, people have the potential to earn more money, to put some money away for a holiday or to invest in Australian industry, something that they are not offered at the moment.

The people of Australia have a choice between Minister Cook's system, where they are stuck on $450 a week, or the offer to earn more money and to increase their living standards. They can stay in the system that has seen a million people go out of work, and have no living standards at all, or they can change to a system where people are protected, where they have a chance to enhance their own place in this world. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder why there is so much heat in this particular debate. The Minister has made the suggestion—supported by Senator Sherry and Senator Winston Crane—that the issues involved in this discussion should be considered by an independent arbitrator. I think that is an excellent idea. Then we can have a look at the real situation. I do not know why we are arguing about this at the present time.
