I would be happy to sit down with my colleagues from both sides of the chamber and see how we can best go about determining the issue.

PARA.TAB: Other matters will need to be considered as well, such as whether the agreement will result in the further casualisation of that industry, whether Sunday is to be treated as an ordinary day for the purpose of payments, whether there should be split shifts, what the spread of hours will be, and so on. I do not see that we can do that in taking note of an answer but, as I said, I would be happy to examine the facts of this situation together with my colleagues from all sides of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President—
—Order! The time for debate has expired.

—Pursuant to the order of the Senate of 28 September 1988, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to explain why an answer has not yet been provided to my question on notice No. 2397, relating to the old Swan Brewery site, of which notice was given on 26 October 1992.

—I thank Senator Chamarette for pursuing this outstanding answer. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) has now provided me with an answer, and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
Senator Chamarette asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs upon notice on 26 October 1992:

With reference to the letter that former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Gerry Hand) wrote to Isobel in September 1989 regarding the Old Swan Brewery site, where he, in part, stated ". . . the Perth Aboriginal community, of course, may apply to me under the Act in the future, should they consider that the site is endangered", I ask:
(1) Has the Minister received any request from Aboriginal or other persons or groups to reimpose a protection order on the old Swan Brewery site?
(2) What action has the Minister taken in response to any requests?
(3) In view of the work and disturbance at the site, if no action has been taken, can the Minister explain the delay?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following information in response to the honourable Senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister for Aboriginal And Torres Strait Islander Affairs has received three applications from Aboriginal persons, under the provisions of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 (the Act), for the protection of the old Swan Brewery site in Perth.

(2) In line with his obligations under the Act the Minister wrote to the Honourable Judyth Watson, Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in Western Australia, to determine what action, if any, she intended to take to protect the site. The Minister also considered whether the State's actions had breached an agreement, concerning the administration of the State Aboriginal Heritage Act 1972, entered into by the Commonwealth and State Governments in 1989.

(3) After having consulted with the Western Australian Government and with his Cabinet colleagues the Minister has decided to decline to make a declaration under the Act preventing the redevelopment of the site.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer and explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: I express my extreme disappointment at the Minister's failure to respond to my question. As I have only just received this answer and have not yet had a chance to read it, I would like to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Would it be better to respond tomorrow when you have read it?

—I am basically responding to the delay in having it provided. I am entitled to do that. I want to express my disappointment at the Minister's failure to respond to the question in the due time. Mr Deputy President, there seems to be some concern. I understand I have a right to take note of the delay.
—The time for taking note of answers has expired.

—Order on my left! Senator Chamarette has the floor. Under the procedures in relation to the past matter, Senator Chamarette does not need leave; she is entitled to move a motion, which she has done. I ask Senator Chamarette to proceed.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: this is an important procedure, but it was limited to half an hour by Senator Chamarette, with the support of the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. The half hour has now expired and Senator Chamarette is now trying to take advantage of a procedure which we strongly supported and which she opposed.
—Order! There is no point of order, because it is a totally different procedure that we are dealing with.

—On 26 October, I asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs whether he had taken any action in response to any request from Aboriginal or other persons or groups to reimpose a protection order on the old Swan Brewery site. I have not received a reply to that answer. I believe that this is an issue of great grievance, not only to Aboriginal people but to the Western Australian community.

PARA.TAB: I have here a letter that was written in September 1989 by the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand, and I believe it explains very well the underlying grievance relating to this matter. The letter is addressed to Isobel, who made an application to the Minister at that time. The Minister acknowledges receipt of the letter of 22 June and states:

SPEECH.PARA: You may be aware that Mr Robert Bropho, on behalf of the Perth Aboriginal community, lodged an application with me in February—
that is in 1989—

seeking Commonwealth assistance to protect the old Swan Brewery site which is associated with the Waugal or rainbow serpent. The application was lodged after the Supreme Court of Western Australia had ruled, in an action brought by Mr Bropho, that the State Government was not bound by the provisions of the Aboriginal Heritage Act (WA).

In accordance with the requirements of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 (the Act), I commissioned a report which addressed the issue of the significance of the site to Aboriginals and other matters laid down by the Act. Following consultations with the State Government, I decided on 21 June to make a declaration for the protection of the site from further ground disturbance.

I can now advise that, as a result of further consultations between the Commonwealth and State Governments, the State Government has agreed to act in respect of the site as if it were bound by the Aboriginal Heritage Act (WA), and to legislate to bind itself. The State Government specifically agreed to commit the old Swan Brewery site to the processes set up under the Aboriginal Heritage Act (WA). Consequently, the declaration made by me was revoked. A copy of my press statement is attached for your information.
I will be taking a careful interest—
please note this—

in the manner in which the site is dealt with under the Aboriginal Heritage Act (WA). The Perth Aboriginal community, of course, may apply to me under the Act in the future, should they consider that the site is endangered.
Thank you for your interest in this matter.
Yours sincerely
Gerry Hand.

As I said, that letter was received in September 1989. When I asked my question of 26 October as to whether the present Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs had intervened, I was aware that on many occasions, due to the disturbance of the site by Multiplex, applications had been made to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to intervene and to reimpose the protection order that had been placed by the then Minister, Gerry Hand, upon that site. Since that time—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I put it to you that, technically, Senator Chamarette is out of order. Under the relevant sessional order, she has a right to seek that the Senate take note of an explanation given during Question Time. That applies in the case of an explanation. In this instance, it was not an explanation for a non-answer, a failure to give an answer by the Minister; it was, in fact, the answer. Therefore, technically, Senator Chamarette comes back within the previous procedures. In fact, that does not even properly apply because the previous procedures are limited to questions asked and answered on the particular day. But, in any event, under that sessional order, Senator Chamarette is not entitled to give a speech today without leave.

PARA.TAB: When you ruled that she was so entitled, as I understood, I respectfully suggest that that was wrong. In any event, because we are reasonable people on this side of the chamber, we would not object to Senator Chamarette making a point about the failure of the Minister to answer within the prescribed period. But this is now a debate. That is an abuse, I would suggest to the honourable senator. Therefore, I take the opportunity to raise this point of order to suggest to the senator that she might conclude.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on the same point of order, may I support—
—It might be wise to receive the call first. I would like to give the call to Senator Coulter.

—On the point of order, it seems to me that it is quite in order for Senator Chamarette to establish the reasons why the delay was very significant at this particular time. It seems to me that that is precisely what she was doing. To do that, she has to go into some detail to establish the case and, through that, to establish the reason why the delay was absolutely critical. This matter involves court cases, judgments and the like. For that reason, I think that her explanation is in order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Teague

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Hill's point of order, and add these words. Page 124 of the Standing Orders states:

INTERJECT.PARA: The senator may, at the conclusion of the explanation, move without notice that the Senate take note of the explanation.

In this case, the Minister actually gave the answer to the question. He did not give an explanation. He gave an answer. We have a procedure whereby, in terms of any answers that Ministers give to questions, we have a half hour limit in which there are five minutes for speaking time for any senator to take note of an answer given that day to a question. If we are to allow the words that are set out on page 129 of the Standing Orders to lead to a half hour speech, then I believe that we will find that this whole procedure will be used as a loophole for half hour speeches, even where an answer is given to a question.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying that Senator Coulter and—I am not totally sure, but I think Senator Chamarette—were among those who limited the Opposition to only five minutes in terms of moving to take note of an answer. So, to have a half hour speech—it is now almost 10 minutes—would be, I think, an abuse of our Standing Orders. I really think that we want to be fair on this side and allow, say, five minutes only for this kind of response. Technically, I believe that it is out of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not need any further assistance. What I would like to do is read the relevant parts of the Standing Orders contained under the chapter `Resolutions and Orders of the Senate of Continuing Effect'. Under the heading `Questions on Notice'—I will read the relevant parts—it says:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) That, if a Senate Minister does not answer a question on notice asked by a Senator within 30 days of the asking of that question, and does not, within that period, provide to the Senator who asked the question an explanation satisfactory to that Senator of why an answer has not yet been provided, then—
(a) at the conclusion of Question Time on any day after that period, the Senator may ask the relevant Minister for such an explanation; and
(b) the Senator may, at the conclusion of the explanation, move without notice `That the Senate take note of the explanation';
It goes on, but that is the relevant part which I think we should be looking at. There is nothing in there which says that the Senator's contribution must be limited to five minutes.

PARA.TAB: As far as I am aware—and I can be corrected on this point later—the contribution by Senator Collins did provide an explanation, and then it was followed by an answer. Under those circumstances I am going to ask Senator Chamarette to continue. But I would indicate to you, Senator Chamarette, that the motion before the Chair that you moved, or should have moved, is that the Senate take note of the explanation. I would ask you to confine your remarks to that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, may I ask a question about that ruling that you have just made? You seem to have based it on an assumption that an explanation as to why the answer was provided outside the 30 days is in existence. I ask you to please read out—or have somebody read out—where the explanation is, because for people who were sitting in this chamber there was no explanation given by the Minister at all as to why it was late. There was merely the statement, `I have an answer'. Therefore, the standing order cannot become operational because the words you read out are quite right. It says that it relates to—and I quote:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . an explanation satisfactory to that Senator of why an answer has not been provided. . .

No such explanation was given. The fact that the Minister simply brought in an answer does not meet this standing order. So we have a dilemma. The point that Senator Teague raised is a very good one. If this is a loophole, then my gosh it will be used—I promise.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated earlier that I would check this later, but having had it raised and put before me, I am checking it now. The answer starts:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

There is no indication in there of an explanation for the delay. Senator Chamarette, under those circumstances, Senator Hill's point of order is correct: you are technically out of order. The Senate might grant you leave for a period of time to conclude your remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I query that point of order? As I understood the Standing Orders as you read them out, it was the failure of the Minister to provide the answer within 30 days that is the justification for requesting an explanation. Regardless of how adequate or inadequate the explanation is—and I agree with the honourable senators that it was a most inadequate explanation—then I believe that it is the expiration of the 30 days, which occurred before today, that entitles me to take note of the Minister's answer.
—How long do you want to finish the statement?
—I am quite happy to do whatever is in the legitimate Standing Orders of this chamber.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to your point of order, Senator Chamarette, I indicated that I did not read the full resolution. The full resolution goes on:

INTERJECT.PARA: (c) in the event that the Minister does not provide an explanation, the Senator may, without notice, move a motion with regard to the Minister's failure to provide either an answer or an explanation.

I guess that under (c) you could do that, if no explanation has been given. But in the view that there is no explanation there, it is not in order to move that the Senate take note of the explanation. I understand that members of the Opposition are willing to allow you five minutes to continue your remarks. You might seek leave to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will accept whatever time is permitted by the chamber to express my concern. I seek leave to do so.

—This is wasting an awful lot of time. Senator Chamarette has had five minutes, and we are only allowed five minutes to take note of things. If the honourable senator wants another two minutes to finish her statement, we will give leave; otherwise we will not, and we will get on with the business.

—by leave—I am very disappointed; I think two minutes is an inadequate amount of time in which to finish an explanation when I expected to have 30 minutes. I can assure honourable senators that I did not support any time limit on taking note of answers at any point.

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) to respond to my question within the time limit is a grievance that will lie within the Aboriginal community and the Western Australian community for some time. I realise that the Minister has been placed in a difficult position by Cabinet, and that his hands may well have been tied. However, this has led to his failure to do his duty as Minister. Prior to my request to him to give a reason for his delay in responding, he received a letter requesting his intervention. In failing to give a response to the people who requested his intervention, or any response to my question asking for the reasons for the delay, he has actually betrayed the Aboriginal people who have deep concerns about what is happening at the Swan Brewery site in Western Australia.

In the past year, the State Government has overruled its own response to the previous Minister, Gerry Hand, regarding its preparedness to abide by the Aboriginal Heritage Act. It has actually amended that Act so that it has entrenched ministerial control. It proposes amendments which give greater protection to mining companies and developers than it does to Aboriginal people.

There is a very urgent reason for intervention at a Federal level. I believe the matter is being impeded by Cabinet for political or electoral reasons. I would therefore urge the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to do his ministerial duty and to take the consequences that may result. (Time expired)

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 2 December, from the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President
URGENCY MOTION
Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need to condemn the Labor Government for its total policy paralysis and failure to address the economic crisis facing Australia—where there are now one million people unemployed, a record foreign debt of $200 billion, and a massive and worsening current account deficit.
Yours sincerely
ROBERT HILL
Is the proposal supported?

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Hill, I announce that I understand arrangements have been made for speakers in the urgency debate to speak for agreed times, and with the concurrence of the Senate I ask that the Clerk set the clock accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need to condemn the Labor Government for its total policy paralysis and failure to address the economic crisis facing Australia—where there are now one million people unemployed, a record foreign debt of $200 billion, and a massive and worsening current account deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the most important political issue facing the nation at the moment. In this country we have a situation of policy paralysis against a background of mass unemployment. We have the worst unemployment record since the Great Depression—nearly one million Australians officially out of work and, according to most commentators, by the time one takes into account those who have given up seeking work and those who are underemployed, the figure is probably nearer double that. So there are nearly two million Australians either out of work or underemployed. That is the background against which the policy procedures of this Government have ground to a halt.

PARA.TAB: What have we seen in the last two days? We have seen the most deplorable economic figures—economic figures that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and his colleagues have sought to talk down today. Last night the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) sought to talk them down. These figures indicate that the background economic situation is much worse than I think any of us ever imagined.

We have current account figures which indicate that, despite the parlous state of the economy, Australia is still absorbing imports at an enormous rate. The current account deficit is back up to the terrible figures of a few years ago—a $1.8 billion deficit is the latest figure—producing a trend line that has been rising for the last nine successive months. But that is discounted by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Government as not being of any great consequence.

The following day—yesterday—we received the deplorable foreign debt figures, which the Minister also seeks to talk down. They indicate that, in gross terms, Australia's foreign debt is now over $200 billion. Yes, that is government sector and private sector, but private sector debt in this country is created within the parameters of the economy as determined by the policies of this Government. It is a terrible figure. The Minister can say what he likes, but there can be no other interpretation than that it is terrible. The figure is tenfold what it was when this Government came into office. The Minister might not like it being expressed in these terms, but it means that every man, woman and child in this country is indebted to the extent of $11,000.

Today the Minister again sought to discount that by arguing that instead of worrying about the extent of the debt we should just concern ourselves with the capacity to pay for it. But the Minister—and Senator O'Chee is well aware of this—did not address this vitally important point: a comparison of the trends between Australia and these Third World economies, which we do not like to refer to in these debates, indicates that their position is getting better and ours is getting worse. Mexico is an apt example. In 1985, debt as a percentage of GNP in Mexico was 55.2 per cent. By 1990, it had reduced to 42.1 per cent. In Australia in 1985 it was 23.7 per cent, and by 1990 it was up to 42 per cent. It is now even higher. The Minister may dismiss it, but the important fact—

TALK.START.PARA: —Sovereign debt or not?
—I am talking about gross debt.
—What about Mexico?

—Mexico is heading in the right direction. Under the Government's policies, Australia is heading in the wrong direction, and at a rapid rate. Not only foreign debt figures came out yesterday; the growth rates were also released. The growth rates tell us that, with an economy running at about 2 per cent growth, this Government will not even be able to maintain the employment rate at its current figure. What that sadly means, and what the Australian Bureau of Statistics has been telling us, is that the trend line for unemployment is still rising.

PARA.TAB: That is the record of this Government after 10 years in office, and that is the background to the debate. We and the Australian people must now address the alternatives that are open to us at the next election. At the moment, there is only one alternative. Only one side of politics in Australia—the coalition—is putting forward an alternative plan and vision that can result in growth and jobs in this country.

This Government is offering nothing new, and that is deplorable. Every day this week we have come into this chamber and asked the Minister, in these critically important economic areas, particularly employment: where is your policy? On each occasion he has refused to answer that question. There is no explanation for it other than that the Government has no further policies. It has nothing new to offer at all. In other words, what it offers the people of Australia is its record and achievement—more of the same, more of the same picture that has resulted in the worst unemployment situation in over 60 years. The Australian people should be furious about that. They deserve more, and they are not getting it from this Government.

In asking the Minister this question today, I suggested to him a few options that he might consider—options that are included in the coalition's Fightback package to rejuvenate and rebuild Australia. They are good, sound, sensible ideas. I started by suggesting the funding of the abolition of payroll tax, which is worth $5.8 billion in this country and which is a direct tax on jobs. What did the Minister say? He said, `That's irrelevant to job creation. We are not interested in that'.
Madam Acting Deputy President, I remind you that in 1985 at the Tax Summit Senator Button had something to say about payroll tax. Senator Button is grinning at this, but he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would propose that we refer the question of payroll tax to that forum, with the strong direction that the Summit believes every effort should be made to reduce or eliminate this tax.

That is what he said in 1985. He knows it is a tax on jobs, yet his Government will not support it—and the reason that his Government will not support it is that it is in the coalition's Fightback policy; not because it is not in Australia's best interests, but because it is within the Opposition's policies.

PARA.TAB: I went on and gave other alternatives. I asked, `Why don't you reform or restructure the tax system as we have suggested in a way that will take $1.7 billion off tax on exports?'. We all know that to do something about the growth figure and to control debt we need to transfer more opportunities into exports. He said, `No, we are not interested in taking these taxes off exports at all, because that would require the sort of tax restructuring that the coalition is proposing and we are not interested in that'.

I asked, `What about the $9.4 billion of wholesale sales tax which is retarding economic growth and job creation opportunities in this country?'. He said, `No, we are not prepared to do that either'. I said, `Why don't you do what the coalition has said; that is, structure a tax system whereby you can cut one-third off income tax and provide a real incentive to Australian business to grow, expand and provide jobs?'. He said, `No. We are not interested in doing that either'.

What the Government is offering is nothing new at all. It is more of the same; more of the tragedy we have had in this country under the Labor Party's record for the last 10 years. Senator Short followed the question up with one directly on the policy paralysis, giving the Minister yet another opportunity to say what he and his Government offer as an alternative for the next election. In that way the people could at least have a choice, because at the moment the choice is simply between his record—one of failure on anyone's analysis—and the constructive alternative policies that have been put forward by the coalition. In effect, he again said, `I am not going to answer the question'. He talked through the question and about all sorts of other things but he did not even attempt to provide an answer to that question.

I am restricted to 10 minutes in this democratic break-up of time. I hope that in that very restricted timeframe I have indicated the importance of this issue. That is what we want to have debated today—the issue and the fact that the Government's policy program has ground to a halt and that the Prime Minister himself has said that the micro-economic agenda is more or less complete.

The fact is that the Government offers no new or better alternatives at all. The fact is that it is going to the Australian people on its record. It is offering its record and more of the same. And its record is a tragedy for those unemployed and for the additional Australians who will become unemployed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it is a pretty fair allocation of time—
—What about those behind you?
—I do not need one; he does. Senator Hill's allocation of time is probably appropriate because he was running out of things to say.
—You tell me I have got too much to say.

—I am unfair. Let us look at the terms of this motion which has come from an intellectually bereft opposition. It refers to alleged government paralysis. This comes from a political party which had to get a team of consultants to put its policy together and still today at Question Time quotes from that firm of consultants on the question of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: This is a political debate. I cannot come in here and say that we can be satisfied about the position of the Australian economy. I do not and never have. I am not pretending that for a moment. This is a political House and the real issue is a debate about the politics of who would do better in this situation.

I remind those opposite that some 75 per cent of leading economists surveyed believe that interest rates and unemployment would be higher and economic growth substantially lower under the coalition if it won the next election. A lesser majority believe that inflation would be higher under a coalition government than with Labor, according to an exclusive survey. A majority of the same economists say that, with the introduction of a consumption tax, by the year 2000 Australia might be better off.

Opposition senators come in here with all their windy rhetoric pretending that if they were elected to government the unemployed would be better off, when everybody knows they would be worse off. Those opposite pretend that there would be fewer unemployed if they were elected to government. No-one believes that either.

Before I deal with some of those issues I want to say that we accept some responsibility as a government for the application of monetary policy in 1989 and 1990 and the very high levels of interest rates which prevailed at that time. When we started to reduce interest rates, who was the one person with economic qualifications who opposed every one of the first six reductions in interest rates? It was Dr John Hewson.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right.
—It is absolutely right.
—He was talking about structural reform at the same time and you didn't do it.

—That is what he did. He was ably supported in this place by Senator Short. Senator Short is on the record as saying a number of things about these issues at that time. The important point that Senator Short made right through this period when we were reducing interest rates to take some of the pressure off the economy—
—Tell us your views on the payroll tax.
—I am coming to that. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: .The main target should be inflation. The balance of payments deficit is a symptom of our economic disease, not a cause. The cause is inflation . . .

We now have the lowest—or if not the lowest the second lowest—inflation rate in the OECD. That was the alternative prescription put by the people who offer themselves as an alternative government: Dr John Hewson on interest rates, Senator Jim Short on the current account deficit and so on.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the first issue which Opposition senators refer to: employment. The level of unemployment in Australia is tragically and unacceptably high. Let me make the point again that it is not a peculiarly Australian problem. Australia's unemployment rate is 11.3 per cent, the same as in Canada. The unemployment rate is 10.2 per cent in the United Kingdom and rising; 10 per cent in New Zealand; 10 per cent in Italy; 18 per cent in Ireland; 10 per cent in France; and 13 per cent in Finland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you keep making comparisons?

—I say this because the Opposition is stuck in the mentality of the 1970s when this was an island economy. But we are now part of the global economy, which Senator Lewis should have noticed. The European Community average is about 10 per cent. As I said, unemployment is a tragic and difficult situation. As the Governor of the Reserve Bank said recently, it ill becomes those who oppose reductions in interest rates and who oppose fiscal stimulus to now cry wolf about unemployment. It is those opposite who did that. That is who the Governor is talking about.
—Who said this?
—The Governor of the Reserve Bank.
—Who? That lackey of the Labor Party.
—I object to that. I ask that that remark be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Do you mean Senator Macdonald's comments referring to the head of the Reserve Bank?

TALK.START.PARA: —Cowardly.
—Why should I withdraw it? I am not talking about Senator Button; I should be.
—Senator Macdonald should not use this place to abuse people who cannot defend themselves. He described the Governor of the Reserve Bank as a lackey of the Labor Party. He should withdraw it.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: Senator Macdonald is entitled to refer to anyone other than another member of parliament in this place in whatever way he sees fit. There are perfect remedies for those people who feel that they have been maligned in this place that have been quite recently introduced. If Senator Button is not aware of that, that is his bad luck.
—Minister, do you wish to speak further to the point of order?
—No.
—There is no point of order. The Standing Orders about what is unparliamentary do refer to members of parliament and senators.

—I am quoting from the Governor of the Reserve Bank and the quotation which he made fits those opposite. But it is not only the Governor of the Reserve Bank; listen to the shadow Minister, John Howard—`Honest John Howard' as he is sometimes called. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not pretend that if we in the Opposition fell into government tomorrow—
and fall they would have to do, staggering drunkenly across the line—
that overnight we could pull unemployment down.
He agrees with 75 per cent of economists. He continued:
Anybody who runs around saying that is not coming clean. I am not making any promises about the level of unemployment. There will be no transition effects.
That is what John Howard said on this unemployment issue about which the Opposition is now making so much. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Reith, said on Monday:
I believe jobs will come if we are elected.

`I believe', he said. When this issue of the solution to unemployment was raised and flushed out at Question Time today, those opposite all started to interject about payroll tax, for goodness sake. Just listen to what the preliminary inventor of the GST, Professor John Freebairn, said about payroll tax as a generator of unemployment:

Unlike the coalition, I believe the swap of a GST for payroll tax will have virtually no effect on employment or unemployment levels. The economic effects of a consumption tax and a payroll tax are similar.

He went on to say more on the same point. All I am saying to those opposite is that they launched this urgency motion. They came in here and said, `We have the policies which are the answer'. But nobody else thinks so; and that is their problem. That is why it is urgent today—because nobody outside this place believes them about these issues.

PARA.TAB: I reiterate that this is not a peculiarly Australian problem. There is no merit in people who opposed the reduction of interest rates and fiscal stimulus coming in here and saying that they would have done better. There is honesty in what Mr Howard says; there is truth in what Professor Freebairn says about payroll tax. There is no truth in this belief put about by people like Mr Reith. He said that he believes that somehow the Opposition would create jobs. Economists do not agree with him and many of the other people to whom I have referred do not agree with him either.

If a person is unemployed in this country, the Opposition will fix them up. It will make sure that they exhaust all of their long service leave entitlements before they are eligible for unemployment benefits or Jobtrain benefits. That is what it will do. It will also take them off the unemployment benefits at the end of nine months. This is its solution to the social problem created by unemployment. So much for its views on unemployment.

There was some fuss made about the massive and worsening current account deficit. The words in the Opposition's motion are, `massive and worsening current account deficit'. I have news for those opposite. When they went out of office in 1981-82—their last full year in office—the current account deficit as a percentage of GDP was 5.6 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Figures from one year.

—I will take the next year as well, if Senator Lewis likes. In 1991-92 the current account deficit was 3.1 per cent of GDP. Recently there was a rise in the current account deficit with the fall of the dollar. Of course that is reflected in the current account deficit. But the real issue in relation to the current account deficit is a country's capacity to service it. It is very important that a country has the capacity to service a current account deficit of the sort we have.

PARA.TAB: I make the general point that we are a member of the OECD. Looking at the OECD countries one after another, in terms of level of international debt we are not the highest by any manner of means; we are about the middle. In terms of current account deficit as a percentage of GDP, we are not the highest; we are about the middle. As to unemployment, we are in the top three by half a per cent. But, apart from that, we are not much different in the figures which apply in respect of other countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have any ideas?

—I know that Senator Crane comes from the rural sector. We have continual Animal Farm interjections: `Baa, four legs good, two legs bad', from Senator Short and `Fightback good, everything else bad', from Senator Crane. That is all they can do—baa, baa, baa. I know that Senator Crane is a wheat farmer, but he ought to get into sheep; it would suit him better. He could have an intellectual dialogue with sheep. It is no good coming in here and getting into the kitchen with people with these sorts of interjections.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask honourable senators on my left to display a modicum of reduction.

—Those opposite came in here today thinking that they had some grenades to throw. They have turned out to be overripe watermelons balanced in the hands of people with weak wrists. That is what has happened to this great motion that the Opposition moved today.
—Blown you out of the water again.

—It is very flattering to have these continual interjections. The Opposition does not want to hear what I have to say; I understand that. Nothing is more threatening to a group of ideologues, who have got their policies from a hired consultant, than a few facts. As I said, what matters is the ability to service debt. The debt service ratio has fallen. Rather than 19 per cent of exports of goods and services being used to pay the interest on the net foreign debt, it is now 15.4 per cent—a reduction from 19 per cent to 15.4 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Because Senator Hill does not understand these issues, he comes in here and talks about every family having a debt of $11,000 and all this rubbish, which is very good for dodgers to stick in letterboxes but he cannot get away with it in here. Since this Government came to power and the internationalisation of the Australian economy has taken place, Australian equity investment overseas has risen from $6 billion—in the Opposition's time—to $58 billion last year. Senator Hill came in here and spoke about debt levels. What about wealth levels for the Australian economy? That has all happened because of relatively high growth rates, expansion, internationalisation and restructuring of the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's because companies have gone offshore. That's what you are saying. Pacific Dunlop has gone offshore.

—Senator Lewis says that Pacific Dunlop has gone offshore. If Senator Lewis knew anything about it, he would know that the going offshore of 59 per cent of Australian companies has resulted in increased activity in their Australian business. That is a fact.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite refer to a massive and worsening current account deficit. It is not worsening from the days they were in office, not at all. In regard to debt, we are in the middle range and our capacity to service that debt is better than that of others.

I have already commented on unemployment, but I say again that nobody out there—except those opposite, pumped up with windy rhetoric—believes that a coalition government, if elected, would do anything about unemployment. Most economists believe it would not happen. John Howard believes it would not happen; so does the Governor of the Reserve Bank and a whole range of others.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very educative experience for Opposition senators; I know going back to school is painful for them. Most of them should really never have left. But they have to be confronted with a few facts about some of these issues.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition's problem is: why do all these things become urgent? It is not because any new massive crisis in the Australian economy has emerged this week as a result of a $1.8 billion current account deficit, for example. The urgency is that those opposite see that the hired consultants have led them up the garden path. They see that people like Dr Hewson, Jim Short and Peter Reith, who were part of the cabal that went off to the consultants, have been led up the garden path. Those opposite look at the remedies which the consultants proposed over the last two years for rectifying the Australian economy and find they are all wrong. That is the problem. So the urgency arises because, true, the current account deficit went up, but so did the approval rating of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). As other indicators go down, so John Hewson's approval rating goes down and so the approval rating of the Opposition goes down.

If those opposite are so concerned about us producing any magic wand, they ought to read the editorial in the Australian Financial Review today—I know it has some big words in it and some of them will not be able to understand them. It is a sensible editorial about the problems with which this country is confronted in terms of its economic management and so on.

After spending the week wasting my time with economically illiterate questions, with `four legs good, two legs bad' type interjections from Senator Crane and Senator Macdonald and all this type of thing, the Opposition comes in here today, yesterday's stunt not having worked, with the grand climax: this urgency motion on the Australian economy. Of course, it has failed because it has been launched by people who have no credibility whatsoever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether it is the time of the year or whether it is because there are so many sittings until midnight but, listening to the earlier part of this debate, one is reminded of Omar Khayyam when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Myself when young did eagerly frequent
Doctor and Saint—
and he might have interpolated `politicians'-
and heard great argument
. . . but evermore
Came out by that same Door wherein I went.

We have just heard the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) defending the indefensible and the Opposition using precisely the same tools to attack the indefensible. The reality is that Australians outside this place are genuinely very concerned. In the gallery at the present time are some schoolchildren who are visiting the Senate. There are also other people in the gallery. Those who are still in employment recognise that wages generally, with the exception of those at the top of the scale, have fallen steadily over the years of the Labor Government. Those who are not in employment are feeling desperate disillusion; they are turning to drugs; they have higher rates of suicide and higher rates of crime. The situation is one which is serious and one which is not being addressed by either the Government or the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Moreover, one finds that the same infection which infected the remarks in the last half hour of both the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) and the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has spread into the senior levels of the bureaucracy—into Treasury, Finance and Prime Minister and Cabinet. I am referring specifically to so-called economic rationalism. A book by John Carroll, by no means a leftie, and Robert Manne called Shutdown states:

SPEECH.PARA: Economic rationalists have wired themselves up to highly abstract, mathematical models of a fantasy economy, and then deluded themselves that they are making realistic policy.

That summarises very nicely what we have just been listening to. The response of government to the present worsening economic climate is totally inadequate. In that respect, we agree with the motion moved by the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: The scale of the crisis is such that it is simply not good enough for Senator Button to turn around and say, `Well, it is bad in other countries as well'; to point to the high unemployment rates in other European countries, for instance, and say, `Well, Australia is a middling country'; and to point to the level of debt in those countries as say, `Well, Australia is about the middle, therefore, it is okay'. It is a serious problem. Australians are genuinely worried about it. It is inappropriate for the Government to attempt to excuse itself on those grounds.

It is absolutely true, as Senator Button said, that the Government has attempted to internationalise the Australian economy. It is part of the economic rationalist belief that free trade will somehow benefit Australians. The proof of the pudding is in the eating. This has not happened. In the last 10 years since the Labor Government has been in office, economic racialism has produced a worsening economy.

We have seen the flow of wealth from the less well off to the wealthy in the misguided belief that the more wealthy people become, the more they will invest in productive investment and the economy would recover. We were told that after a trickle up, we would see a trickle down and, as a consequence, those who were less well off would become employed and the economy would recover. This has not happened. It will not happen under the Opposition either. The Opposition will pursue, with greater vigour, precisely the same sorts of policies. The trickle up and trickle down principle simply does not work.

Labor governments in South Australia and in other States have also pursued precisely the same sort of free market and speculative agenda. We see that in the case of the State Bank of South Australia. Mr Bannon attempted to excuse himself by saying that he thought the operations of the bank would be profitable, whereas he should be ashamed that he allowed the bank to continue with the same sort of speculative activity which has brought the rest of this country to its knees.

Under a deregulated regime, money which flowed to the more wealthy did not go into productive investment; it went instead into speculation, particularly into property speculation. A great deal of it went offshore. A lot of it simply went down the shute as inefficient speculators became bankrupt.

The principal task of government is not to defend some abstract ideology. The principal task of government is to look after the citizens of a country. As John Carroll says in his book, economic racialism has failed every practical test by which one wants to measure it. Every promise which has been made by the economic rationalists over the last 10 years has simply not been fulfilled and has turned out to be false. Of course, one must stress again that the pattern which the Opposition would impose on this country is of the same kind. It would simply screw down harder the thumb screws of economic rationalism.

Those opposite have turned their attention particularly to industrial relations. They point out that a deregulated industrial relations system would work better in this deregulated economy. I ask those opposite to look at the example of Canada, where the level of education, the size of the population, the distribution of the population and the wealth of the country are very similar to Australia. Contrary to Australia, Canada does not have the centralised wage fixing system that we have in this country. Yet Canada finds itself in precisely the same situation as Australia is in. So the idea of the Opposition, which is that a deregulated labour market will turn the other aspect of deregulation into some sort of profit and benefit for this country, will simply not be realised.

What is needed in this country is a good dose of re-regulation and government policies which intervene on the part of ordinary Australians to turn this economy around. We need to ensure that tariffs are left in place for those industries which still have tariff protection. We need to hang onto those industries that we still have. We need to reimpose quotas on imports. It is absolutely ridiculous that we continue to import large amounts of goods which we produce in this country. We imported $2.3 billion worth of food last year—all of it material which we can produce here. That is the policy that we need to pursue, and it is simply inadequate for the Government to defend itself on the grounds that other countries are worse off than we are. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to very strongly support the urgency motion moved by Senator Hill today, which states:

PARA.TAB: That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to condemn the Labor Government for its total policy paralysis and failure to address the economic crisis facing Australia—where there are now one million people unemployed, a record foreign debt of $200 billion, and a massive and worsening current account deficit.

The release of the national accounts, balance of payments and foreign debt figures over the last two days has reinforced the ever-increasing evidence of the disaster that the Australian economy is now facing. It also reinforces what we have known for a long time: this Government has no idea how to deal with these problems. It is paralysed. The figures speak for themselves: the horrendous current account deficit of $1.8 billion for October and the foreign debt breaking the $200 billion barrier in the September quarter, which is equal to $44,000 for each average family in Australia. The net percentage of debt to our national income has grown under this Government from 10 per cent in 1982 to a whopping 42 per cent today. That gross debt now, as a proportion of our national income, exceeds 50 per cent.

PARA.TAB: While the figures suggest that the economy is growing overall, albeit very slowly, private non-farm growth declined in the September quarter. There was negative growth in the September quarter in private non-farm GDP. Private consumption expenditure is flat. Private capital expenditure continues to decline. There was a negative contribution to growth from net exports. There is no basis whatsoever for reading any kind of sustainable recovery into these figures.

Faced with this undeniable condemnation from the facts of the Government's policies, or lack of them, there is no prospect of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) or the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) doing anything at all to redress or address the deep-seated problems which are at the heart of the malaise which they have caused. This crisis has been caused by this Government and, in particular, this Prime Minister, who has been the self-confessed architect of the economic policies of this Government for a decade now.

We are now caught in a vacuum of policy paralysis until the election. Even the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser, who tried to put the very best gloss on the situation the other day, has called for a White Paper. In his press conference yesterday, the Treasurer said that he did not think that was necessary because White Papers required new policies and this Government was not considering any of those.

What will it take to get this Government to recognise the problems that it has created? How can it be shaken out of its complacency? It has no answers and is not interested in finding any. As Terry McCrann wrote in the press yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we have a Prime Minister determined to win the coming election at any cost. And that cost is the future of Australia . . . we have a Government ruthlessly feeding fear and uncertainty about the reforms we desperately need.

I believe that those views of Terry McCrann are echoed by countless millions around this country. Not only does this Government have no policies, but it wants to stand in the way of those who do. Yet the situation is very, very grave. Things have gone from bad to worse since the banana republic statement that the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, made some 6 1/2 years ago.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at how things have moved since Mr Keating told us 6 1/2 years ago that we needed an `internal economic adjustment' and that `if we don't make it this time, we will never make it', as he said in May 1986. Back in May 1986 our net debt compared with that of the rest of the world was less than half of what it is today. Mr Keating called that a crisis. If he calls that a crisis—and it was—where on earth are we now? The September quarter figures which were announced yesterday showed a truly staggering net foreign debt position of $163,000m. That represents a growth of 9 per cent in the last three months alone and it is a figure something like eight times that which the Government inherited back in 1983.
The prospective Federal Government Budget deficit for this year is now over $9 billion higher than it was in 1985-86, even though Mr Keating in the banana republic interview in May 1986 suggested:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we have got to slow imports and that means cutting back the public sector.
Unemployment in May 1986 was 7.8 per cent. Today, with nearly 400,000 more people unemployed than there were in May 1986, it is 11.3 per cent. Mr Keating also said:
. . . it is private sector activity which will put the activity in place to give us a better level of local production against imports.

But since 1986, private business investment has fallen as a proportion of GDP from 11.3 per cent to 8.6 per cent. Yesterday's national accounts figures indicate a continuing decline in business investment, the engine of growth of the whole economy. The Reserve Bank Governor has said:
. . . the message of modern growth theories is that the more you invest, the faster you grow.
He also said:
. . . the need to boost investment to boost growth is widely accepted.

Given our abysmal investment performance, we have no prospect of a sustained export led recovery while Labor remains in office. Labor has been mouthing the same platitudes for 10 years but it has delivered absolutely nothing.

PARA.TAB: Those comparisons with 1986 show the abject failure of every so-called initiative since the banana republic statement days. We have gone backwards, not forwards, since the days when the present Prime Minister said that we should be taking every action to avoid becoming a banana republic. The only progress we are making is along the Argentinean road. Criticism of the lack of policies to address this disastrous situation is not just coming from the Opposition, it is coming from the Government's own economic advisers, from within the Government itself, from the business community, and from the millions of Australians who have either lost their jobs or been otherwise cruelly hit by the failed policies and the policy paralysis of this Government. The ALP's own Federal President, Barry Jones, said in Perth this week that the Government—and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . would need to do more than just knock the Coalition's policies to win the election.
He is absolutely right. The truth of that statement was made absolutely clear in the recently released Industry Commission report, which noted—and I quote:
. . . our progressive slippage down the ranking of OECD countries in terms of per capita incomes. Many countries in the Asia-Pacific region are also catching us.

Yet the Treasurer tries to kid us that we are possibly `the fastest growing economy in the OECD'. He said that three times in his press conference yesterday, as if saying it enough times might make it true. Well, it is not true. We are not making the grade on growth or on anything else.

PARA.TAB: This Government's inept approach to micro-economic reform has also been highlighted in a report from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in the last day or so, which states that `the micro-economic reform agenda is not complete'. This report calls for further reforms on the waterfront and in transport sectors to fully exploit the export opportunities arising in the South East Asian region. Again, only yesterday, the Treasurer was emphasising the importance of tying in to the Asian region. He said that we need to `maintain our attachment and our economic integration with the more rapidly growing countries of Asia', but it is clear from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade report that it is not acting to deliver that. That report echoes the Industry Commission report released last week which said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in light of what governments must do to lift Australia's economic performance, reform initiatives have been lacking in number and scope.

The Industry Commission report makes a very strong case that, without accelerating the pace of micro-economic reform on a broad front, unemployment will remain at high levels for the rest of the decade, even if strong growth starts.

PARA.TAB: Despite the worst recession in 60 years, our debt continues to balloon, our imports continue to outstrip our exports and the economic gloom just grows and grows. Faced with all this, the Government sits on its hands. It is paralysed. The third most senior Minister in the Government, Senator Button, went through his usual charade today without once mentioning anything original. There were no new policies, and no recognition even of the problems and the policy failures of the past. It is a disgrace that this Government will have to live with. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this motion to condemn the Government not only for the failure of its economic policies and its subsequent failure to change direction but also because the Government, like the proverbial ostrich with its head in the sand, will not even admit that its policies have failed to deliver. Honourable senators might recall that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in his 1992 Budget said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia will grow more quickly this year than last. Australia is once again on the move.

I could not agree more with the Treasurer. Australia really is on the move. Our employed are moving—they are moving out of employment into the dole queues. Our small businesses are moving—those that have not already been made bankrupt are moving towards bankruptcy. Our farmers are on the move—they are moving off their farms and away from the productive wealth that they create there. Our foreign debt is moving—it is moving inexorably upwards. So Australians are really on the move.

PARA.TAB: The current account deficit is on the move—it is moving further into the red. Our dollar is moving, mostly downwards. Our home owners are on the move—moving out of homes that they can no longer afford because in many cases they no longer have jobs. Our families are on the move. A lot of them are moving onto welfare queues outside the Salvation Army, the Smith Family, the Red Cross or other welfare bodies. Multinational companies are on the move—they are moving to New Zealand or Asia where the cost of production is lower. So Australians really are on the move. As a matter of fact, we are all moving closer and closer to the worst economic disaster this country has possibly seen.

In all of this time there is only one thing that has not moved, which ought to be moving, and that is this Labor Government—off the Government benches and onto the Opposition benches. But it is only a matter of time, and the sooner the better.

We need only to look at some of the headlines in our newspapers to know what popular sentiment is about this gross economic mismanagement. I will give a few examples. Today's Sydney Morning Herald said, `New figures kill hopes of recovery'. The Telegraph Mirror, `Outlook bleak for unemployed'. Today's Canberra Times, `Bold Government front on debt crisis'. Yesterday's Australian, `Economy sinks, protest fizzes'. Today's Australian, `Dollar gyrates as Reserve fights loss of confidence'. Yesterday's Age said, `Jobless the price of our deficit'.

We must not forget Michelle Grattan's comment in today's Age under the heading `Jokes aside, Dawkins is in a jolly world of his own'. The article quotes the Treasurer as saying that Australians have no reason at all to whinge. Michelle Grattan writes:

SPEECH.PARA: John Dawkins has to be joking. With Australia registering 11.3 per cent unemployment, massive debt and sluggish growth, he dares to accuse people of whingeing?

This is the incredible arrogance of a government which claims to represent the working people but which really does not have a clue about what is happening in the real world of retrenchment, sackings, huge debt, lost farms, bankruptcy, homelessness and soup kitchens.

PARA.TAB: As we all know, the Government's One Nation policy is an absolute failure. `No Nation' is what we would have left under another term of Labor. Of course, Labor will not admit to the failure of One Nation. Why else would Labor need to bring in the latest child of One Nation? Why the need to take away money urgently needed for rail projects to give to job creation programs elsewhere?

The ultimate irony is that the money directed to so-called job creation programs will not create long term jobs for any of our unemployed. In some areas it has not even created any short term jobs. As Senator Tierney pointed out in this place only the other day, not one new job was created from the $400,000 allocated to the Byron Bay Council for street improvements. The council used existing employees.

What do the commentators think about the new child of One Nation, or whatever one likes to call it, and the ability of this Government to make policy? One newspaper headline said, `Labor's all talk and no policy'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The child is stillborn.

—It is definitely stillborn. Another newspaper headline reads, `Government lacks vision, says ALP chief'. Even the Labor Party's own President says that the Government lacks vision. Other headlines read `Jobless scheme under attack' and `Local capital works bring few new jobs'. Under the heading `There is no fairy godmother cure' in today's Telegraph Mirror, Terry McCrann says:

SPEECH.PARA: John Dawkins was spouting dangerous nonsense at his press conference yesterday. Australia is in deep trouble and the Federal Government refuses point blank to embark on the reforms which offer the only way out with the least pain.

The people of Australia have no faith at all in this Government. Why should they when things keep going from bad to worse? When unemployment hit 11.1 per cent in June, shock waves were sent through the community. This well exceeded the 10.75 per cent peak forecast contained in the 1991-92 Budget. Yet in his 1992-93 Budget Speech, the Treasurer said:
The combined effects of all these measures will see unemployment decline from 11 per cent last June to below 10 per cent 12 months from now, and keep on declining in the years ahead.

So what do we have? We have an unemployment rate that has risen to 11.3 per cent. Why should we believe Labor any longer? Why should we believe a Treasurer who says that `the Government is acting now to reduce unemployment more quickly, to ease the pain and burden on Australians and their families'? Why should we believe the Government about our growth figures which were confidently predicted not so long ago to be 4 per cent? Those figures were revised downwards in the 1992 Budget to 3 per cent; and now it does not look like we will reach anything like that target. Now we have suffered the worst balance of payments result for nearly three years. It has come in at $1.8 billion, which not only stunned the Government but also pushed the Australian dollar to a six-year low before the Reserve Bank stepped in.

PARA.TAB: How has all this economic mismanagement been impacting on our community? We all know what the unemployment figures are. Do honourable senators know that the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics estimates that this financial year the average broadacre farmer will lose $25,700? Do they know that over a period the rural population has declined from 21.8 per cent of the national total to just 14.5 per cent?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bad thing, is it?

—South Australia has lost 1,000 farmers a year for the past six years. Try to tell them! Where are these people moving to? They are joining the dole queues in our cities. Where are bankrupt small business owners moving to? They are joining the dole queues. Where are we all moving? We are moving in the wrong direction. The coalition is the only party that can get Australia on the move again—moving in the right direction with detailed policies, in stark contrast to the abysmal lack of policies of the current Government.

—This is a motion of condemnation of the Government—and it ought to be, because this Government has brought the people of Australia to the end of an era. Whereas, once, this nation lived with opportunity and prosperity, now this nation lives with debt and desolation. It is no surprise to anyone on this side of the chamber that the policies of this Government have turned Australia into the Argentina of South East Asia. We have a foreign debt in excess of $200 billion. Senator Button and Mr Dawkins would like us to compare Australia with some other countries. I intend to do just that. I will compare Australia with the countries of Latin America—Mr Keating may have forgotten about them—and show how poorly this nation is performing. Argentina's foreign debt is not $200 billion; it is less than half of Australia's foreign debt.
—With how many people?
—With twice the number of people that we have in Australia.
—Perhaps we should go down the Argentinean road.

—I think the Government has gone down the Argentine road. Brazil's foreign debt is $169 billion—still well short of the $200 billion-plus that this nation owes. Chile, Mexico, Colombia and Venezuela have all been well and truly passed by Australia in the headlong rush to go further into debt—the headlong rush led by this Government to mortgage the future of the next generation of Australians.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button could not give us an indication of what policy, if any, the Government had to turn this problem around. Instead, he tried to make an excuse. He is very good at trying to make excuses. The excuse that he offered today was that we should not look at the level of the debt—let us just close our eyes to that; we should look at the ability of this country to service the debt. He then proposed that the Senate give him and the Government a pat on the back because the interest on our foreign debt has fallen from 19 per cent of exports to 15.4 per cent of exports.

Well it might, because world interest rates have been coming down. But it is the ability to pay for the servicing of the debt that we have to consider. It does not matter whether that figure is 19 per cent of exports or 15.4 per cent of exports; the bottom line is that in this country—in this Australia—at the end of this era, we have to borrow to pay the interest on the money we already owe. Countries such as Argentina can run a balance of trade surplus, while Australia has a balance of trade deficit.

Australia is bleeding $15 billion or more a year in money that we send overseas, because we import more than we export. Chile runs a balance of trade surplus but Australia imports more than it exports. This Government's taxation policy encourages this nation to import more than it exports. It encourages businesses to go offshore and not manufacture here. It encourages Australian companies to take the jobs away from workers and give them to people in other countries where the Government does not tax the life out of the employees and the employers. That is why its policies have failed, and that is why its policies will continue to fail. But what does it offer us to solve the debt crisis?

TALK.START.PARA: —More of the same.

—More of the same. Of course, the Government would not like us to make those comparisons—and I do not like to make those comparisons—but it is time we knew the truth: there is not a single answer to be found on the other side of the chamber to solve this crisis.
—Not one single policy.

—`Not one single policy', my friend interjects, and this Government has been in office for nine to 10 years. But there is an alternative. Australia must understand that we can solve this crisis, but it will require Australia to start to rebuild its national savings base.

PARA.TAB: The reason this country continues to go into debt is that the savings of Australians are no longer there. When this Government came to power, something like one in every six after-tax dollars actually went into savings. Recently, it has dropped as low as one in every 30 after-tax dollars. If the money is not there for the banks to lend for our mortgages, our Mastercards or whatever, then they are going to go overseas.

What we in the coalition propose is a tax package which encourages people to save and which will start to rebuild the savings base. It is a tax package which will take $4,000m a year less in total taxation off Australia than this Government rips out of our pockets at the moment. It is only by creating that excess wealth in the pockets of Australians that we can start to save and start to rebuild this nation's economy.

Would the Government accept such a policy solution? No. That is why we believe it is absolutely essential that this nation be turned around by turning around the tax policy. It is absolutely essential that this nation start to get out of the dreadful strait in which it finds itself.

In Question Time today Senator Button said, `Let's not talk about gross debt; let's talk about net debt'. Let us talk about net debt. Net foreign debt in this nation in the last three months has increased by about $13,000m. To put that into perspective, it did not increase that much in the 80 years that followed Federation. In the last three months, the net foreign debt of Australia has increased by more than it increased in the first 80 years after Federation.

I suggest that what this nation needs is the end of an era—the end of an era of debt and desolation, the end of an era with no policy and the end of an era presided over by a morally and economically bankrupt Labor Party which, with its leader Paul Keating, has nothing to offer Australia but more desperation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator will use proper titles.
—Mr Paul Keating has nothing to offer Australia but more debt, more desolation, more despair and more desperation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the motion moved this afternoon by Senator Hill. The first thing that needs to be said, and said in very clear and unequivocal terms, is that there is no policy paralysis evident at any level of the Australian Government or at any level of the ALP. Precisely the opposite is true. The policy grid-lock that is evident in Australian politics grips the coalition. It is handcuffed, and apparently happily handcuffed, to two losers—the goods and services tax and Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Opposition. There is no other way to explain the simple fact that over the last six months, as the economy has proved more sluggish than was believed to be the case earlier in 1992, the coalition has simply slid away by every measurement in the polls.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe for one moment that one can make political judgments just on the basis of opinion polls or on the basis of research. That is not a basis on which a political judgment can be drawn. The simple fact of the matter is that time after time, and now in clusters, all of the polling about what Australians think of their national politics reflects adversely on the coalition.

It could well be, as Paul Kelly outlined in his book entitled The End of Certainty published just a few weeks ago, that the 1980s did bring to a conclusion an age in which political certainty was readily apparent and that we have moved into an age of uncertainty. It is beyond question that the coalition during the 1980s, in so far as its political leadership was concerned, was the most uncertain institution in the country, evidenced by the apparent revolving door. Perhaps in the 1990s we have moved into a period of uncertainty.

All the publicly available material seems to be suggesting that as times become more uncertain, people identify more closely with the policies of the Labor Government—the policies of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and those who sit on this side of the chamber. There is no other explanation. If there is another explanation, all of us are waiting to hear it.

There is no question that there is a preparedness on this side of the chamber to be innovative and to adjust where necessary. There is no question either that the runs are on the board in terms of efficiencies in industry, of productivity—the waterfront being a classic case in point—or achievement, particularly in the manufacturing industry. If we look at the manufacturing industry in terms of exports or productivity improvements, the record is there. It is a record of accomplishment. That is a record we are quite happy to argue early in 1993. On this side there is a preparedness to be flexible.

Opposite, of course, there is utter gridlock. Since the GST became holy writ—since it was handed down in tablet form—the coalition has stayed absolutely manacled to it and will remain so, despite the fact that the GST was brought down the best part of 18 months ago when economic circumstances were entirely different. They were utterly different from the circumstances that confront us at the moment.

I think it is always wise in politics to make a concession where a concession is needed, as Senator Button did the other day. The balance of payments figures are disappointing; there is no question about that. It would be both idle and futile to say otherwise. Exports dropped 11 per cent in October but they rose by 12 per cent in September—to put matters in a better perspective. The drop in exports was particularly marked for gold and other metals, for example, and had a carry-on effect upon the figures generally.

Manufacturing export figures were also disappointing. But let us put it in the context of the simple reality that manufactured exports for the three months to October remained 14 per cent above the level of a year ago. That is a good record to argue. That is a record in which we can take some satisfaction, not as a government but as a nation. There has been change, and change apparent.

The coalition always seems to want to look at figures in isolation. There is never a comprehensive approach from those opposite; never a comprehensive grasp of detail or of policy complexity. They have a very simplistic approach. The GST is the classic example of that. That will prove the Opposition's undoing in terms of the contest that is looming.

Senator O'Chee made some remarks about Australia being the Argentina of South East Asia. That ought not to be laughed at only in this chamber; it would be laughed at in Argentina. Not only does Argentina not represent our future, but also it never represented our past. I had the privilege of visiting Latin America a few months ago with a parliamentary delegation. We do not have the problems that Argentina has experienced and is experiencing. We do not have the failures of government that Argentina experienced over a long period of time; over four decades—not only the periods of military dictatorship but also the periods of utter profligacy which occurred.

As people in Argentina say themselves, they took several decades out of their political history when they could have been achieving the kinds of things that we achieved during the 1980s in terms of employment growth, productivity improvement and changing the national profile—particularly in the manner in which Australia sees itself as part of a global trading environment, looking to Asia and to the Pacific Rim in particular. Of course, what Senator O'Chee did not talk about in terms of either Brazil or Argentina were the relative figures in respect of gross domestic product. We cannot compare apples and oranges. People who are realistic understand that instinctively.

We avoided any possibility of making the kinds of misjudgments that people in Latin America made in the 1970s and the 1980s. We avoided it specifically in 1986 when the then Treasurer, now the current Prime Minister, Mr Keating, made his famous reference to the banana republic. The Labor Government sought, by way of deliberate policy steps, not to go down the road that, quietly and irretrievably, we appeared to be going down for a very long period of time under coalition governments in the 1950s and 1960s and again during the Fraser era—the interregnum in the 1970s.

An American friend of mine said to me just recently: `Why on earth are your political opponents wedded to a political manifesto that dates from 1980? This is 1992. They are wedded to a political manifesto that would have been worthy of Margaret Thatcher at the 1979 general election or Ronald Reagan at the 1980 presidential election'.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should have done it last time, but they did not have the courage.

—They should have moved to it at least in 1990, as Senator Button makes clear. In all probability, they should have moved to something more radical a decade ago. But they have always lacked courage; they have always been behind the ball in those terms. It will be an absolute pleasure to debate these matters before the Australian electorate when the contest is on in earnest and the argument is for real in the early period of 1993.
—What is your agenda?

—The Opposition has manacled itself with enthusiasm to a 1980s failed agenda from the UK under Margaret Thatcher and a failed agenda from the Reagan Administration. I find it staggering; I find it absolutely extraordinary that any group of politicians could be so foolish. But that has happened.
