It happened in 1991, it has carried right through 1992 and it will prove the undoing of the coalition again in the autumn of 1993. A 1980s agenda has now been rejected in the UK by a Conservative government; it has been rejected by the American people in the election just held.

PARA.TAB: Let us look for a few moments at the agenda of President-elect Bill Clinton and Vice President-elect Al Gore. They are about adopting policies that the Labor Government adopted in 1983 and 1984.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your agenda?
—What is your agenda?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! There are too many interjections from my left.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never minded interjections. In some cases they are the most sustained political references of which people are capable. The situation that confronts the Americans at the moment is that after 20 January the Clinton Administration will be embarking upon the kind of program that the Labor Government adopted in this country in 1983 and 1984, beginning with a summit to bring together a range of people who have something to contribute by way of ideas. That was successful in the early 1980s and got the economy moving again—an economy that had been lagging and had been sluggish during the Fraser Government. That is what the President-elect has made clear he wants to do. But there is more. The United States is about to embark on a major program of infrastructure spending to do with rail and road, in almost precisely the same way that the Labor Government here embarked upon the program in February of this year.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that what we are doing is almost precisely in line with contemporary Western industrial thinking. In terms of what passes for thinking opposite, people are about to loom onto the political landscape with a new series of taxes which, of course, have greatest impact upon those who can least afford them.

I am indebted to my colleague from South Australia, Senator Maguire, who published his Canberra report earlier this week entitled, How the Liberals would increase your food bill. It is an analysis based upon Treasury documentation and assessment—ranging from margarine to cheese—as to how the food bill would skyrocket under the coalition, the Liberals and the Nationals. A kilogram of margarine, for example, would move from $2.85 to $3.12; canned tuna from $3.54 to $3.89; and so it goes, finishing with cheese moving from $4.25 to $4.67.

The average household bill goes absolutely and utterly through the roof. If we look at the estimated price rises under the Liberals' 15 per cent GST, there is no certainty, of course, that they would stay at 15 per cent. If you believe that, as the Duke of Wellington once said, you would believe anything. There is no guarantee on that. Clothing would rise by 11.19 per cent, electricity by 10.65 per cent, dry cleaning by 10.51 per cent, shoe repairs by 10.51 per cent, right through to the telephone at 8.14 per cent, textiles 8.04 per cent, gas 7.67 per cent and public transport 6.59 per cent.

Again, seen at a glance, the impact is greatest upon those right at the bottom of the socioeconomic scale. The people who will be hit hardest are those least able to defend themselves. Look at the overseas experience in terms of the impact of the GST, the new impost. For example, look at the Australian Consumer Association's assessment of what happened in New Zealand. The association warned that 30 per cent of the savings from the abolition of taxes similar to those which the coalition claims it is about to abolish in New Zealand were not passed on to consumers. I cite the AFCO statement of September 1992 as a reference. Some 30 per cent of proposed or imagined savings were not passed on to consumers. That ought to be made clear at this stage of the debate.

The impact of the GST is savage, regressive and pernicious. That will become increasingly clear. It may be the end of certainty in political terms, but there is nothing more certain than that adding to the tax burden on Australians, as the coalition proposes to do, is a massive political negative and a massive economic impediment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at your own tax rate, absolutely astronomical.

—Senator Brownhill should compare the tax rate with the tax rate that prevailed in 1982-83 when Australians were paying 62c in the dollar in personal income tax. That is now down around 47c. He should compare the corporate tax rate, which was well over 60 per cent, with the 39 per cent rate that now prevails. We are happy to make those comparisons. I am delighted that Senator Brownhill raises the point. I am happy to debate that on any platform anywhere with him.

PARA.TAB: It will be instructive for Australians when the televised debates between Mr Keating and Dr Hewson occur during the general election campaign. There will be a cluster of issues on which the election will be decided: the econ

SPEECH.PARA: omy, tax, industrial relations and a constellation of issues in terms of social security, health, education and the environment. In all those areas the Labor Government has particular undeniable strengths. In all those areas the Opposition has policies which are, at best, flawed and, at worst, utterly and absolutely unworkable. In terms of the contest that looms in the autumn of 1993, the Opposition has manacled itself, handcuffed and smiling, to two losers—Dr Hewson and the GST. The ultimate judgment which will be passed upon the Opposition in 1993 will be very similar to the judgment being passed upon it in the polls right now, that is, another rejection.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pretty hard to deny that Australia is now in deep economic trouble. The question for Australians is whether what the Opposition proposes would be any more of a solution to these troubles than what they are served up from this Government. Last month's current account deficit of nearly $2 billion prefaces a nightmare scenario in Australia in which we have, as many other senators have said, large increases in imports, a collapse in exports, still sluggish growth and increasing unemployment. At the same time, we have a continued deterioration in our foreign debt position which constrains domestic growth options.

PARA.TAB: This is what appears to be happening: the growth rate is not quick enough to stop unemployment increasing, and a balance of payments crisis is looming again. In the last week we have seen an appalling balance of payments figure and weak growth performance, as evidenced in the Australian national accounts. These figures have quite rightly received national media attention.

However, another very important study was released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on 30 November which has gone largely unnoticed. The study includes a review of foreign debt statistics published in the Bureau's monthly Australian Economic Indicators. This review reveals the alarming statistic that Australia's foreign debt has been increasing at the rate of almost 30 per cent per year since the mid-1970s; it is not something that just came in coincidentally with this Labor Government. In 1976 net foreign debt was just $2.4 billion. By 1980—still under a coalition government—it had almost trebled to $6.9 billion. In 1984 it was $30 billion; in 1986 it was $75 billion and it is now $160 billion.

The scale of the problem is indicated by the ratio of net debt to gross domestic product. This was 5 per cent in 1976, 10 per cent in 1982 and 42 per cent yesterday. So it doubled in percentage terms under a coalition government but it has quadrupled since then. So in half a generation we have increased our foreign indebtedness by over 1,000 per cent. If the rate of this increase in foreign debt continues, we will undoubtedly see the International Monetary Fund intervening in the management of Australia within the next decade or two. Our economic sovereignty is clearly threatened in the medium to longer term by this trend. The cost of servicing this debt is also growing exponentially. In 1980-81, net interest payable abroad was one per cent of GDP, but it is currently running at 3 per cent. It would have been higher had it not been for a sharp drop in interest rates.

Unemployment is clearly the greatest economic and social issue facing this country. It has been estimated by the Catholic Social Welfare Commission that unemployment is costing the Government between $10 billion and $18 billion. So the cost of providing benefits to those without work and the tax which would have been collected on their wages, plus payroll taxes, amounts to $10 billion to $18 billion. The fact that this is still trending upwards is the most terrifying aspect of the unemployment figures. For the last generation we have seen the underlying rate of unemployment ratchet upwards after each period of economic decline and we have also seen the average length of time of unemployment increase.

The simple fact is that the market will not deliver decent levels of employment for many years to come, if at all. We as a country are going to have to share the employment opportunities. We are going to have to accept lower living standards imposed on us by the rest of the world. We are going to have to ensure that what that entails, the load that that brings, is fairly shared across the community.

So I agree with the Opposition that there is a crisis. It has not been taken seriously early enough by this Labor Government. However, I do not agree that there has been a policy paralysis. I think that is without foundation. We sit here every day and we have dozens of pieces of legislation implementing Government policy. Where I think there has been a problem is in the need to review the delivery of these policies. At least there are a few meagre signs that this Government is having a rethink about the level of intervention that is necessary in our economy. This is quite different from the solutions being offered by the Opposition. I think the first part of the motion could just as well read `The need to condemn the Opposition for its total policy paralysis' in so far as it is proposing failed economic rationalist policies of the 1980s. It is proposing a net cut of $4 billion in government spending. It is proposing smaller government and a reduction in services. That will lead to unemployment. The Opposition's solutions do not guarantee employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the tax cuts—30 per cent.

—I will come to that. The Opposition is saying that it is going to hold inflation at 2 per cent. That will lead to interest rate increases, it will be an extra oncost to business and it will lead to the spiral of having to put people off in order to cope. Senator Hill said today in Question Time that one of the solutions would be the abolition of payroll tax. We agree. He said, `Do something about the tax on exports'. We agree. He said, `Abolish the wholesale sales tax and reduce personal income tax'. We all know that there is going to be this marvellous trickle-down effect, and that reducing personal income tax has this miraculous link with increased productivity. There is absolutely no link between reducing personal income tax rates and higher productivity. In fact, United States studies actually show the converse.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats support assisting State governments to phase out payroll tax, we support slowing down tariff reductions in strategic industries and we support providing tax incentives and support for priority industry sectors. We will be voting for the urgency motion but with the qualification that we do not agree with the application of the description `total policy paralysis' to the Government only; we think that applies to both sides.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to quickly respond to a few comments made by previous speakers. Firstly, I want to comment on Senator Button's lacklustre defence of our massive foreign debt. He said that we have to admit that we have a problem. But he then in defence said that the debt servicing element is not as bad as it was last year. Senator O'Chee responded to that point.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I want to respond to Senator Loosley's comments, particularly about handcuffing ourselves to Dr John Hewson and the Fightback program of policies. We do not see ourselves on the Opposition benches as being handcuffed; we see ourselves as proudly placing before Australians, some 18 months before the election, a program of sweeping reform—which is long overdue—nailing those policy flags to the mast and ensuring to the best of our ability that they are explained to Australians so that they will be able to vote at the next poll knowing full well the Opposition's policies. We will accept their judgment when the election day comes, whenever Paul Keating, the Prime Minister, decides to hold it. We have not heard from any Government speakers any defence of the fact that the Government seems to have no policy solution to either Australia's massive unemployment problem or the rapidly rising foreign debt problem.

Senator Loosley then used the US analogy, which I will continue to pick him up on. The greatest use of that analogy is in looking at the very close links between the Reagan and Bush policies and the policies followed by the Hawke and Keating governments. The great failure of the Reagan era—there were many successes in it, particularly in foreign policy terms—was to match the tax cuts put through Congress early in his term with expenditure reductions. The US Government's debt and current account problems that were well and truly predicted by David Stockman about six or seven years ago have come true and have brought about the ultimate demise of both the US economy and the Reagan-Bush Republican tenure in the White House.

Senator Loosley's next comment, which certainly requires rebuttal, concerned his Government's record on taxation. He referred to the Government's reductions in the top marginal tax rates, which are very similar to what Ronald Reagan and George Bush did in the United States; they brought down tax rates but did not do anything about matching those tax cuts with expenditure cuts. This Government has cut top marginal tax rates, but it has done almost nothing for middle income earners and even less for low income earners. As I said earlier today in a previous debate, it has been the low and middle income earners that have lost out the most under this Labor Government, which is supposed to be representing that section of the population.

The reality of taxes during the term of this Government is that there has been a total increase of taxation in real terms of 39 per cent against GDP growth of 32.45 per cent. PAYE tax has risen 14 per cent; company tax, 63 per cent; superannuation taxes, 2,573 per cent; withholding tax, 113 per cent; sales taxes, 53 per cent; and petrol taxes, 205 per cent. All are real figures in 1991-92 dollars.

This Government's taxation record is a disgrace, both in terms of total collections and the complexity of its tax system, which has become a major impediment to business in Australia. It is an impediment that Senator Button, in his more erudite moments, has admitted makes Australia uncompetitive. I am prepared to accept that this Government will not reform the tax system or the industrial relations system. It has talked about it but done nothing, and I am prepared to accept that for ideological reasons it will not do anything.

I want to spend the few minutes remaining to me focusing on the things the Government could do and which many commentators are urging it to do, which is to get on with micro-economic reform. It has talked about it for 10 years. As someone said, micro-economic reform is now being uttered by parrots and galahs around Australia because the phrase has been said so often. Parrots and galahs are repeating it, but very few people know what it means.

This Government made a commitment in the One Nation statement to pump money into railways and infrastructure reform. Only a few days ago we read in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) that $170m—I will be corrected if I am wrong—has been taken out of the railway reform program and is being pumped into making more pine log fences and painting rocks white as a short term, bandaid servicing of the unemployment problem. This nation needs infrastructure reform, and it needs efficient railways, roads, ports and shipping. This Government has failed to do anything about it.

I refer to the example of waterfront reform. Senator Loosley said that he is happy to go to the people with the achievements of waterfront reform. In this week's Business Review Weekly, Robert Gottleibsen said of the Government's achievements in this area:

The cost of government services and transport . . . have not come down because reform has been too slow. The waterfront reforms have become a joke as the waterfront and shipping industry have pocketed the productivity gains, leaving exporters little better off.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no use having reform on the waterfront unless our exporters are better off as a result. We need to cut costs there and increase Australia's competitiveness.

PARA.TAB: As the Treasurer, John Dawkins, said yesterday, the only way to pay this foreign debt is to export more, ensure that we export more than we import, become competitive and achieve a turnaround. That will not occur unless we have the reform which this Government has failed to carry out.

Shipping reform is often spoken about, but little is done about it. There is still the stupid trans-Tasman agreement which is protected because of a trade union brotherhood across the Tasman. Australian coastal trade is protected from competition, and a range of reforms could take place in relation to the Australian National Line. This week's Business Review Weekly refers to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Peter Cook, as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . dragging the chain on deciding whether to introduce a range of shipping reforms.
The Australian Mining Industry Council suggests that the Government is trying to go slow on these reforms to try to maximise the price of ANL. The Government is deluding itself on both counts.

PARA.TAB: The other area of reform is road transport. The Government knows that its own Caucus and back bench committee has referred the impact of sales taxes on transport to the Minister. These are reforms that the Opposition has faced up to in the Fightback package to ensure that the cost of transporting things across Australia is reduced.

The other area is infrastructure and whether the private or public sector should be funding it. Of course, the great reform that the Government introduced this year in the Budget was the decision to treat limited partnerships as companies for taxation purposes, again stifling—if not destroying—a great avenue of private sector investment infrastructure. That is the Government's great contribution to infrastructure reform this year.

The debate leading up to this election will be about change and who can introduce that change. The coalition has a program of sweeping reform. However, we agree that the Australian people must feel that this change will take place at a pace that will protect their living standards. That is why the Fightback package is very careful to ensure that low and middle income earners will be protected with rises in pensions and family allowances, cuts in their personal taxation and a whole range of measures. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to contribute to this debate today on the urgency motion moved by Senator Hill. I will not read the entire motion. Suffice to say, basically it states that this country is in a desperate mess and the people on the Government side of the chamber have no plan to fix it. In fact, they have policy paralysis. They have no idea how to get out of the mess they got us into.

PARA.TAB: The first contribution on behalf of the Government was made by Senator Button—who is now so interested in this debate that he is reading The best of bad Hemingway. Nonetheless, in the very beginning he asserted that we are an intellectually bereft Opposition. Having made that assertion, did he offer a plan to indicate that the Government had any intellectual capacity to address these problems? No! He accused us of being intellectually bereft but offered no plan himself.

In his contribution he took some more time to go over old debates. No doubt someone in the Public Service has been digging around in the Hansard looking for a few quotes he could chip in with here and there. He took up a bit more time so that he would not have to offer a plan then either or answer as to why the Government does not have a plan to get us out of the problems we are in.

He then sought to justify the appalling unemployment rate in this country by pointing to other nations which have similar rates. An unemployed person does not give a damn what the unemployment rate is in any other country. That person actually does not care what the rate is here, because as far as that person is concerned he or she is 100 per cent unemployed. I notice that Senator Button was particularly selective in his choice of the areas where he was prepared to contrast Australia with other nations.

For example, I notice that he did not tell us that our labour productivity growth through the 1980s—the time in which his Government was in charge—was an average 40 per cent below the OECD average. Senator Button is keen to compare in some respects but not in others. Why would we engage in this comparison with other nations when the problem we have is here in Australia with the economic malaise and mess created by this Government? It is not relevant to see what is happening elsewhere in that respect. Why waste the time on that when the Government has no plan and no idea of how to fix it!

I turn to Senator Loosley's contribution to this debate. Senator Loosley has a particular debating style which is to stand up and make particular assertions but then to offer no facts to back them up. He said that it was clear and unequivocal that there was no policy paralysis in the Government. In my office I turned my television up thinking, `Here it is coming; it is clear and unequivocal that there is no policy paralysis. They have got a plan and they are going to let everybody in on it'. However, Senator Loosley dropped that point and went on to something else; it was a mere assertion. All this Government does is assert that it knows what it is doing. If the economic conditions under which Australians are suffering are evidence that this Government is doing the best it can, we had better get rid of it.

Senator Loosley went further than that. For example, he said that the economic circumstances were different when we—that is, the Labor Party—wanted a GST. There is one thing that absolutely has not changed that is one of the key reasons for shifting to a GST. Those wholesale sales taxes are still on the production process. They carry through and make us uncompetitive. That was the case then and it is the case now. In terms of that aspect promoting of a GST, what else has changed is irrelevant. The main reason to shift to a goods and services tax is to take out all those unnecessary taxes that are cascading through the system, building up the price of our goods and services and thus making them uncompetitive, and spread them out over all consumers in an even and fair way.

The best that Senator Loosley could say in relation to the balance of payments figure was that it was disappointing. He may as well say, `Let them eat cake'. Frankly, I do not care whether or not he is disappointed. We want to know what the Government plans to do to improve the situation. This urgency motion is all about condemning the Government for not having a plan to get out of this. The motion condemns the Labor Government for having a policy paralysis. The fact that Senator Loosley is disappointed is quite inconsequential to that.

Senator Loosley then went on to make an even better point, as far as he was concerned—that Bill Clinton is going to follow the Labor Party policies in that he is going to have a summit like Labor had in 1983 or 1984. I am writing to everyone I know in the United States and saying, `Get out of there now'. If the Clinton Administration is going to start following the policies of this Government, if it looks at what has happened to this nation since Labor has been in office and says, `That is a good idea. Let's follow that', then people had better get out of there fast. Even Senator Loosley would not be bold enough to make that assertion.

Then we hear about Senator Maguire's dear little newsletter frightening the hell out of everyone about the price of goods going up, food in particular. There is no denying that the price of some food and some clothing will go up but the price of some other things will come down. I have had a good look at Senator Maguire's newsletters and I have not seen much in there about personal income tax; I have not seen much about it being $11 cheaper to fill the tank of the family car. I see the Labor Party sending out propaganda focusing on our plans—but only on the negative parts and not promoting any of the positives. I would like to see Senator Maguire writing something about his own Government's policies. The reason he has to remark about our policies is that the Government does not have any. This Government is suffering from a policy paralysis, as asserted by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill.

Since Senator Button was good enough to take us on a little trip back through the Hansard, I thought it might be interesting in the closing minute or two of my speech to draw the Senate's attention to some of the things that this Government, through its Leader, has told the Australian people over a period. This one is a gem. In 1990—only two years ago—as part of the Budget Speech, the former Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: Economic policy has worked and is working . . . the current account deficit will improve markedly and employment will pick up. In short, the kind of outcome the Government was seeking, delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.
That is what the Prime Minister was saying only two years ago and look where we are now. Similarly, in 1990 he said that we would:
. . . see the investment coming home, the capital stock going into place, the production rising, the current account declining . . .
We know that is not true now. This is the investment Senator Button is always talking about in plant and equipment that does not ever eventuate. He continued:
When that happens, all of this imagery will change at such a pace that I really will have, I'm sure, some difficulty dealing with the popularity breakout.
He has to have tickets on himself, doesn't he? In 1990 he said:
We won't have a scorched earth policy, we won't destroy business activity, we won't destroy employment . . .
In 1990, he said:
We won't let there be a recession.
Worse still, at the end of that year the Prime Minister said:
I knew there had to be one but I didn't want to tell you.

That tells us what we get from this Government: promises that it will get better. We can see from the Government's record that it does not. What we want to know now is: what plans has it to fix the problem? What can it do to break the policy paralysis it suffers from?

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this urgency motion moved by the Liberal-National Party Opposition in the Senate this afternoon. This is a very shallow exercise by those opposite to try to distract attention from the fiasco of the goods and services tax. They have seen during this week their brainchild—a tax on goods and services—come crashing down as opinion poll after opinion poll has been published in the Australian community showing that the Opposition is now trailing the Government in the popular esteem of the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: It is a very selective and partial motion. It is a total attempt to distract electorate thinking and opinion from the fiasco of the goods and services tax and the daily mounting fiasco of Dr Hewson's leadership of the Liberal Party. Look how selective this motion is. At no point in this motion is there any reference to Labor's great achievement in getting inflation out of the Australian economy. At no point in this motion is there any reference to us removing price inflation as a disease in the Australian economy. Those opposite do not want to talk about it. They do not want to know about the record of getting inflation out of the economic system in Australia. As I have reminded people in the Opposition time and time again, the reality is that when they left office in March 1983 price inflation was 11 1/2 per cent per annum. We had double digit inflation under the Opposition when it was last in government. Prices under this Government have now been wound back to 0.8 per cent in the consumer price index.

I am pleased to see that a very similar figure was recorded yesterday in the gross domestic product deflator figures, which also showed price rises of about 0.8 per cent per annum. It is a very low level of inflation for Australia in historical terms. It is also very low compared with the five western European countries and Japan which have historically been regarded as the world's low inflation countries. Inflation and prices in Australia are now below the rates in countries such as Germany, Japan, the Netherlands, Switzerland and so forth. It is a very big achievement. The reduction in prices has been a response to Labor policy deregulating the Australian economy and of more competition. I instance the domestic airline industry where for many decades under Liberal governments we were allowed to fly domestically on only two airlines in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a closed shop.

—It was a closed shop, as Senator Loosley says. The Liberals were manacled—happily handcuffed—to a two-airline policy. Basically, they would not allow new entrants into the Australian domestic airline industry. We have allowed that to happen. There is now a third carrier providing competition in that industry, keeping a downward pressure on price rises for tickets in the domestic airline industry.

PARA.TAB: An important contributor to reducing inflation has been the cuts in interest rates. Honourable senators opposite seem to forget that interest rates are now part of the base for calculating the consumer price index. Every time we have reduced interest rates in the Australian economy, it has had a downward effect on the consumer price index and on measured inflation. In fact, since January 1990, when we first made reductions in interest rates, there have been 13 rounds of cuts in interest rates under this Government. Every time we have reduced those interest rates, we have made a further impact in reducing pressures on the consumer price index.

It is interesting to note that when the first round of those cuts was made in January 1990, Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Opposition, actually accused us of making premature cuts in interest rates. Almost three years ago he told us that we were premature in cutting interest rates in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would prefer to forget that now.

—Yes, that is one of the things the Liberal Party would prefer to forget. It would also prefer to forget the achievements of this Government overall in getting price rises out of the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to talk about gross domestic product—the measure of total production in the Australian economy. We have now had four consecutive quarters of growth in gross domestic product in the Australian economy. In the last quarter, the September quarter, there was very strong growth in farm product and very strong growth in investment in new dwellings—two significant areas of growth in the Australian economy.

One of the striking things about the debate on gross domestic product over the last 48 hours is that the Liberals seem to believe it is negative. One gets the impression from listening to Senator Short and other people that the growth in GDP in the September quarter was negative. One gets the impression that they are talking about negative growth when, in fact, over the last 12 months we have had a growth rate of 2.1 per cent in total production in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Private non-farm GDP has fallen. You know that.

—Plus 2.1 per cent, I say to Senator Short. That is a very respectable figure in world terms—2.1 per cent growth in gross domestic product. That is positive growth, not negative growth. That is extremely respectable. We have the fifth highest growth rate of the 17 most industrialised countries in the OECD.

PARA.TAB: Japan's growth rate forecast for 1992 is 1.2 per cent. Ours is already 2.1 per cent. The growth rate of New Zealand—that darling of the conservatives opposite; that country they all go on pilgrimages to to see how to turn a First World country into a Third World country—is expected to be only 2 per cent, so ours is already higher than the growth rate in New Zealand.

We should look at the United Kingdom. We had the pilgrimages to the UK during the 1980s when those opposite all went and sat at Margaret Thatcher's knee to learn how to run a conservative economic policy. For the last nine quarters in a row—that is, nine times three months in a row—there has been negative growth in the United Kingdom. For 2 1/4 years there has been negative growth in the United Kingdom under Tory policies—the sorts of policies these people opposite want to follow.

Germany—the former industrial powerhouse of Europe—has had four consecutive quarters of negative economic growth. We should contrast that with Australia, which has had four consecutive quarters of positive economic growth. We were told this afternoon that Australia is in crisis. But what I have just said is the reality. All of those speakers from the other side of the chamber claimed today that Australia is in economic crisis, when at present we are recording below average world inflation and above average world economic growth compared with the developed countries of the world.

I would like to refer Senator Short to the forecasts made by the Westpac bank. Senator Short would have received the forecasts last week, as I did—and, I presume, all other members of parliament did—from the Westpac bank. It made some forecasts about economic growth in Australia and in other countries in which it banks. What did it say? It forecast 3 per cent real economic growth in Australia in the 1993 calendar year. What did Westpac say about New Zealand—that darling of the conservatives? It did not forecast 3 per cent growth for New Zealand; it could only come up with a 2 1/2 per cent growth estimate for that country, despite all the policies that those opposite want to copy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is 2 1/2 per cent any good?

—Three per cent in Australia is better. Perhaps Senator Campbell did not hear what I said. The forecast for Australia is 3 per cent and the forecast for New Zealand is 2 1/2 per cent. Westpac is forecasting only a 2 1/2 per cent growth rate for Japan. This private enterprise organisation is making its forecasts for the next calendar year with Australia coming out on top of those tables with the highest growth of those three countries. We are told time and again that this country is in crisis, but the international perspective is not that at all. Germany has been going down for four quarters in a row and Australia has been going up for four quarters in a row. There has to be something right going on in Australia.

PARA.TAB: There is some reference in this motion to Australia's current account deficit. In typical Opposition fashion it is reported in isolation. The motion does not relate the current account deficit to the size of the Australian economy. It is very simplistic; it is very naive. It does not in any way relate the size of the current account deficit and our overseas balance of payments to the level of spending or to production in the Australian community. That is what has to be done.

If meaningful comparisons are to be made between Australia now and Australia in the past, it is necessary to relate the current account deficit to the size of the economy. If comparisons are to be made between Australia and other countries, they must be done on a common basis; it is necessary to relate the current account deficit to the size of the economy. It is very illuminating when one goes through that exercise. The Opposition's current spokesman for industrial relations, Mr John Howard, was Treasurer in 1981-82. What was the current account deficit at that time as a proportion of gross domestic product? It was a whopping 5.6 per cent. The current account deficit represented more than one-twentieth of the Australian economy. For this current financial year, it is likely to be 3 per cent.

When we put the current account deficit in perspective in relation to the size of the Australian economy, clearly Australia's performance now is relatively better than it was when the Liberals were last in power in 1981-82. We are being told in this motion that Australia is in crisis, yet the Opposition shadow Minister for industrial relations presided over a balance of payments current account deficit of 5.6 per cent of gross domestic product.

The other very annoying thing about this debate is the Opposition's focus on all the bad news. Those opposite do not tell us about the positive things in the balance of payments. I heard Senator Loosley refer to the 14 per cent growth in manufactured exports up to October. That is the sort of thing that those opposite will not talk about. They will not talk about the massive growth in the pharmaceutical industry in Australia—the massive growth in pharmaceutical exports. They will not talk about the massive growth in exports of ships from Australia. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would know something about that, living in Hobart. The Australian shipbuilding industry is becoming very successful in exporting ships.

I heard Senator O'Chee talking about Argentina. I recently had the privilege of being in Buenos Aires. The relevant comparison to be made is that Australia is now exporting hydrofoils from Tasmania to Argentina to operate on the River Plate between Buenos Aires and Montevideo in Uruguay. We can do these things. They are happening in large numbers and at high value. We are selling computer equipment overseas. Importantly, from the perspective of my State of South Australia, the wine industry is experiencing massive growth in exports. In the last year there was a growth in export of Australian wine of between 30 per cent and 40 per cent—not 3 per cent or 4 per cent—achieving a figure of $230m in the last financial year. The target for Australian wine exports at the turn of the century is not $300m or $400m; it is $1,000m. That is very achievable indeed. It is enormously good news for my State of South Australia, which contributes 51 per cent of the grape crush. It is clear that all States of Australia have an enormous comparative advantage in the wine industry. The price of vineyard land is very cheap in Australia compared with the Northern Hemisphere. Some very good potential for growth for Australia is coming from the wine industry.

I also point out, again from the perspective of the Liberals talking about Australia being in crisis, that Australia now exports 21 per cent to 22 per cent of its gross domestic product. When the Liberals were last in office the figure was 15 per cent at best. That just shows the extent to which the Australian economy has become internationalised and how the structural reforms and structural changes which have taken place now make it possible for us to export a much greater proportion of our gross domestic product.

Meanwhile, we have an Opposition that wants to bring in a goods and services tax. Somehow it believes that there are still such things as economic panaceas—that if we pull one lever the whole economy will fall into place in a perfect and blissful way. It wants to bring in a goods and services tax because it thinks it will fix the economy. The reality is that it will do enormous damage to the Australian tourism industry—a key export industry which does very important, positive things in terms of our balance of payments. When the Liberals were last in power in 1982-83, about a half of million overseas visitors a year came to Australia. Now the figure is about 2 1/2 million overseas visitors per annum.

But the Liberals want to put a tax on holidays in Australia. When people pick up their brochures in New York or Tokyo they will find that the cost of holidays in Australia has gone up compared with those in other countries. There will be a bigger incentive for Australians to go overseas than to take their holidays in Australia because there will be tax on tourism in Australia. Although they might like to, the Liberals cannot apply a tax in Rio, Hawaii or wherever. It will be a big kick-start for Australians to go overseas. Also, look what has happened to family budgets—(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—In accordance with provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Auditor-General's Report No. 8 of 1992-93—Department of Veterans' Affairs—Compensation pensions to veterans and war widows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General's eighth report of 1992-93 addresses fundamental issues in the repatriation system. The report has been a very long time in coming, reflecting the scope of the issues investigated by the Auditor. Work apparently began in April 1991. The tabling of the report was scheduled for November 1991. It has now finally reached the Parliament more than 12 months later.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General has clearly made a very thorough review based on a lot of research of the compensation subprogram and associated areas. The report represents the first major review in the Veterans' Affairs portfolio since the introduction of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. In this sense, it is extremely valuable because it provides a contemporary analysis of repatriation practices and legislation.

The report questions fundamental aspects of the compensation subprogram and the associated legislation. In the Auditor-General's view, the subprogram and supporting legislation do not adequately reflect the consequences of the ageing of the veteran population; the needs of younger veterans, in particular those suffering psychiatric conditions; or the need for equitable treatment of veterans and their dependants. There is strong criticism of program management. The Auditor suggests that there is little accountability and that the Repatriation Commission and the Department of Veterans' Affairs have adopted a limited and reactive management approach.

The Auditor-General is also critical of the current appeals process. His message, in simple terms, is that change is needed at the first level so that better decisions can be made in the first instance. This would mean fewer decisions being appealed. He also highlights the need for greater consistency.

The coalition accepts these points. They are matters which the coalition has been pointing out over and over again for a long time. A number of the problems highlighted by the Auditor-General have already been raised by the Opposition in one form or another and are addressed, at least in part, in our policy statement, which was released recently.

This report comes at a time when the Parliament has been considering a Bill which proposes significant changes to the manner in which incapacity or death can be related to service. The second reading debate is scheduled for the last sitting week. The Bill is to be significantly amended by the Government after being savaged at a Senate committee hearing.

I do not intend to debate the merits or otherwise of that Bill now, but this report obviously has important implications for any legislative action taken by the Government in relation to the standard of proof provisions in the Veterans' Entitlement Act. In this regard, the report demands careful examination and a response that is comprehensive, not piecemeal. This report has already been the subject of much discussion within the ex-service community and by others with a direct interest in the Veterans' Affairs portfolio. In the context of this report, a number of events in the past few months could be seen to be a softening-up process.
On 21 July, in the lead-up to the Budget, we saw a page 1 story in the Australian Financial Review entitled, `Smoking and veterans: a $320m annual cost'. The article opened with the sentence:

SPEECH.PARA: Australian taxpayers are paying more than $320 million a year in compensation pensions to disabled war veterans or their widows as a result of illnesses or deaths caused by smoking.

This set the tone of the article, which implicitly suggested that veterans were benefiting unfairly from repatriation legislation provisions at the expense of taxpayers. John Stone followed up that story with some unfortunate and misguided comments. In a letter published in the Financial Review, I set out the obligations of the Commonwealth to properly compensate our veterans and stressed that these obligations do not diminish over time.

PARA.TAB: The story had been on the boil for some time. The journalist had interviewed me on the smoking hypothesis issue well before the story appeared. The timing of the story fitted in nicely with a government framing a Budget and looking for portfolio savings. The story was founded on costings prepared for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) on war widows and disability pension expenditure flowing from the smoking hypothesis, which were leaked to the Australian Financial Review journalist.

As a further step in the softening-up process, the Bill to which I referred earlier was introduced last month. It was ostensibly designed to overcome a High Court decision which the Government claimed would mean open slather on veterans' benefits and a massive blow-out in pension costs. The Government's interpretation of the High Court decision and its subsequent legislation was blown out of the water at a Senate committee hearing. It was clear to everybody present at the hearing that the Bill was going much further than the Government claimed.

The question arises: to what extent was the looming presentation of this Auditor-General's report, of which the Department has seen working drafts all along the way, a factor in the content of that legislation? It may be that repatriation legislation needs to be improved, and the Auditor-General strongly suggests that it does, but if there is to be change, it must be after consultation with the ex-service community and it must be presented honestly and openly and not in an opportunistic way. Sadly, consultation with the veterans' community over the recent amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act was non-existent. This Department and this Government have been operating recently in a more and more complacent, indeed arrogant, manner with regard to veterans.
I believe that, as far as possible, change should occur on a bipartisan basis. In the foreword of this report, the Auditor-General notes:

SPEECH.PARA: Disability and war widows' pensions are the principal means by which the nation has met its obligation to those who served to protect it in times of conflict.
This obligation must be clearly understood by anyone who seeks to effect change to our repatriation system.

PARA.TAB: The report is strongly critical of the administration of the compensation subprogram. It suggests that DVA management has not provided sufficient information and analysis to inform the Government and the Parliament of the results of the compensation program. There are also significant deficiencies in the Department's information systems and their use. Of greatest concern is that veterans are being let down by the inefficiencies and failings of the system. The Department is not well geared to handle the many complex issues arising from claims relating to psychiatric conditions. Rehabilitation facilities for veterans suffering post-traumatic stress disorder are almost non-existent. The present pension system is a disincentive to improvement. The report finds that more claims could be accepted within the current legislative framework if the Repatriation Commission accorded greater priority to an equity objective. What an incredible indictment of a government that has presided over this system for 10 years—a government that claims that social justice and equity are part of its platform.

The coalition's policies are important in this regard. Our recently released policy statement identifies the needs of veterans with respect to the claims system as: easy access, confidence that their claims will be treated fairly, and a system that is as simple as possible. The policy further states that the coalition will reform the claims system so that it is fairer, better understood and more efficient.

In the face of all the shortcomings in the compensation program and the associated legislation, the Auditor-General calls for a fundamental review of the operation of veterans' compensation arrangements. He notes that any examination of veterans' entitlements requires the support of the wider community and a bipartisan approach. He has suggested that the most appropriate forum for consideration of the issues would be a joint parliamentary committee. Unfortunately, with an election looming, this might not be possible for the present as such a committee would expire upon the calling of an election.

There is no doubt that fundamental review is required and that as far as possible it does need to occur in a bipartisan environment. Veterans are dissatisfied with many aspects of the present compensation arrangements. They feel they have been short-changed by this Government. This alone should be reason for government action. The Government has also alarmed veterans and raised a number of important issues through the amendments proposed to overturn the Bushell decision in the High Court. These amendments, I believe, are simply a symptom of the greater problems highlighted by the Auditor-General in his report.

The report is, in many respects, a report card on the Minister and his administration of the portfolio. The Auditor-General has raised issues which should be of great concern to all with an interest in the good administration of the Veterans' Affairs portfolio. The Minister should be thinking already of what action can be taken to begin a process of review. I look forward to hearing the views of the ex-service community on the matters raised in the report. Of course, many of these things might have been dealt with long ago if the Government had not chosen to abolish the monitoring committee which was set up by former Senator Gietzelt with the 1986 legislation.

It is clear that an ageing veteran population means new challenges in meeting the needs of veterans—and the coalition recognises this. It is clear that much more needs to be done in better meeting the needs of our younger veterans. The changing needs of the veteran population demand that we as policy-makers must be attuned to these challenges and willing to work constructively with the ex-service community on the way in which these challenges might be addressed. But they also demand a commitment to veterans and their dependants and recognition of the sacrifices they have made for our country. Our commitment does not diminish with the age of the veterans.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
