DEBATE.TITLE: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1992ABORIGINAL EDUCATION (SUPPLEMENTARY ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1992OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I was interrupted by the suspension of the sitting for lunch, I was busy comparing student organisations and the responsibility and obligations of enrolment at a university with the responsibilities and obligations of home owners when they purchase a home and bring themselves under the jurisdiction of a local council, and the requirement to pay for the broad range of services provided by the councils in various areas. This includes, to varying degrees, payment towards the political activities of a municipal council as well. These political activities vary from council to council, depending on how politicised those councils are. In many councils it includes a subscription to the nuclear free zone secretariat. This, in itself, is a very controversial measure in some regions, and one which the Australian Democrats certainly support. I raise that simply to provide, by way of example, the degree to which councils can engage in political issues, in the same way as student organisations engage in political questions as a part of the broad range of activities that they are engaged in. If people do not like the political activities that a local council or a student organisation is engaged in, then they have the democratic right to vote them out at the next election.

PARA.TAB: The Liberals have claimed today that universal membership of student organisations breaches individual freedom, even international treaties; however, in our view, this argument falls down in a number of areas. The point of choice for students is at enrolment. When a student decides to enrol at a university, the decision to join the student organisation should not be considered separate from this. According to the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, the freedom of choice lies in whether a person becomes a member of the university. This argument is sustained in legislation. Our legal system refuses to recognise any legal right to avoid membership and the requirement to pay a prescribed fee.

Underlying these judgments is the notion that a university is a complex social institution of which student organisations are a vital part. Universities have the power to levy a fee due to their special statutory existence and by virtue of enrolling students who voluntarily bring themselves within the ambit of the university's authority.

There is one further point on the question of university autonomy which, as we know, is a key plank of the Opposition's education policy. It is our view that the coalition's policy on voluntary student unionism is highly intrusive on the question of university autonomy. The coalition would seek to directly intervene in the affairs of a university which is otherwise governed by the university by-laws; that is, its policy on voluntary student unionism is in direct contradiction with its stated policy of university autonomy. In our view, this contradiction in its own policy simply exposes the purely political nature of the coalition's policy in respect of student organisations.

The issue of membership of student organisations is clearly a political issue. It is a fundamental plank in the Opposition's platform, designed to reduce student resistance to aggressive and unfair education changes. The Australian Democrats support the rights of individual students and encourage the implementation of conscientious objection clauses into student organisation constitutions and university by-laws which would enable students to opt out of membership and pay the equivalent fee to a nominated source, usually a charity. Many institutions already have these clauses in their by-laws; in fact, in 1990 a survey revealed that 60 per cent of institutions already had these by-laws regarding opt out clauses in their constitutions, and therefore it is our belief, given that some two years has elapsed, that that figure is probably much higher at this time.

In most cases the coalition has contradicted tenets of its own philosophy in its arguments against automatic membership and university autonomy. It claims that student organisations are unrepresentative, yet voluntary voting and a democratic election process mirror the coalition's own policy.

The Liberals couch their political motivation in the guise of freedom of association and of individual rights. Their goal is to destroy student organisations through the introduction of voluntary student unionism, after which student organisations would not have the support base or the resources to survive.

Students are faced with an electoral Hobson's choice at the next election. They have a choice between full fees, vouchers and restricted Austudy as part of the Opposition's policy and the Government's mortgage-type fees for postgraduate and non-award courses, HECS hikes and other loan schemes. More than ever before students need a strong support base to protect their interests. More than ever they need effective student organisations to protect their interests and services.

The Australian Democrats remain the only political party willing to protect an accessible and equitable public education system. To this extent, we reiterate our concern and support for the fact that student organisations play a vitally important role in the total fabric of university life. Students are obligated to become members when they decide to enrol in a university and bring themselves under the ambit of a university culture. We will continue to fight for a fairer and open education system for all Australians. I commend these Bills to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested in the rather tortuous logic of Senator Sowada. I will address the question of student unionism in a few minutes, when I will come back to those comments. We are discussing a number of Bills in this debate. I wish to express my disgust that we have five or six Bills thrown together in one cognate debate. These issues are important enough, as we are dealing with universities, school students and a whole range of other issues in Australian education. Each of these matters really deserves full debate in its own right. Here we are, towards the end of the session for the year, being forced to consider all of these Bills together.

PARA.TAB: There is no time for me to deal adequately with the huge number of Bills that are before us within this cognate debate. I wish to focus my remarks on the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 to provide grants of assistance to States and universities. The measures in this Bill that relate to the funding of higher education are largely drawn directly from the ideas of the Opposition's Fightback package. Therefore, it is natural for us to applaud this because the Government, with its ideas on higher education, obviously recognises that it has failed dismally. In particular, this has been shown by the fact that the national unified system created by Mr Dawkins is now largely discredited.

At last, the Government has found it necessary to accept the coalition's policies. I will be dealing with a number of these as shown in the Bill. One of the most important measures in this Bill rolls capital funding into recurrent funding. The coalition has long been in favour of doing this and it should have been done some time ago. The advantage of this move is that it allows institutions to plan their own capital developments. This reduces their dependence on political discretion to decide whether they receive those capital funds.

The Bill also increases the number of postgraduate research awards by 200. Again, this is a move that the Opposition has advocated in the Fightback package. However, the Opposition plans to go further and increase the stipend under these awards by $2,000. By doing this we will attract the very best students into the postgraduate awards.

Currently, the very best students seek out awards overseas. They do this because they are rewarded better elsewhere. Research in Australia therefore has not had the chance to reach its full potential. By increasing the number and the amount of those awards, as we propose doing under Fightback, there will be the opportunity for this to happen.

Another measure which I am pleased to see the Government introducing is the provision of direct grants to institutions. This is an excellent idea because it will facilitate the implementation of the Opposition's national education award system when we are in government after the next election.

One of the most important measures implemented by this Bill is the Government's open learning initiative. Clearly, this is an initiative which the Government does not fully understand. This ignorance of the way in which open learning works was demonstrated by the statement made by Mr Dawkins when he announced the funding of the OLI in the August Budget. Mr Dawkins claimed that the Government's open learning initiative would make higher education available to everyone in Australia who had a television set and a letterbox. This is truly nonsense; it is an absurd statement. Senator Sowada has already indicated that she thinks it is an absurd statement.

The money that the Government is providing for the OLI is not enough to fund quality higher education. The Government is proposing simply to fund the open learning initiative at a cost per student per course equivalent to the HECS rate. It then assumes that the OLI will be self-funding. Given that the cost per student per course is closer to $7,000 for a less complex, low resource degree such as arts or economics, quality is obviously not a high priority for this Government—if the OLI scheme is anything to go by.

The Government has failed to adequately explain which services will not be provided in the OLI course and which services, such as tutorials and marking of assignments, will have to be paid for by the students enrolled. The open learning initiative, as proposed by the Government, is completely dominated by one university—that being Monash University—and the five distance education centres established by our universities around the country over the last 10 years are in serious danger of being left out in the cold through inappropriate government policies. This could be a very exciting area of growth in education, but the Government, by coming in with this very centralised approach of focusing the initiative on one institution, will destroy something that has been developing very well.

Probably the most disturbing aspect of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) is that it contains a measure to legislate for compulsory student unionism. I found Senator Sowada's use of logic in this matter intriguing. She mentioned that we work for autonomy and that that is the broad direction of our policy. That is true. I would have thought that voluntary student unionism was something that moves us very much down that line. I think that all students should be given the opportunity to become members of a union, just as they should be given that opportunity in other areas of activity in our economy.

I was a PhD student about 10 years ago, and every year I had to pay into a student union fund. I objected to doing this. I was told, `If you don't pay into this fund, we will not enrol you'. I said, `If you put it that way, all right, I'll do it'. It was compulsory. Part of my money that went into the fund went overseas to support the PLO, which was part of the student organisation's initiative at that time. I objected very much to my money being used in that way, but I was compelled to do it. People should not be compelled to contribute to such causes or to the funding of these bodies if they do not want to. Therefore, we support the voluntary student unionism provision.

One of the problems we have with the way student union funds are used is that there is a very long history of funds not being used particularly wisely. For example, the Tasmanian branch of the National Union of Students has recently been rocked by charges of alleged misappropriation of funds. It is now subject to criminal proceedings. It has been claimed that cheques were written out of union funds for personal use by a member of the union executive and his friends. They were not accountable and there were no obvious internal control procedures followed.

There are many other cases. One of the many other cases is the NUS women's office conference in September which had an authorised budget of $6,000. The convener overspent by $40,000 because it was decided arbitrarily to subsidise the four days of accommodation, food and airfares for the 100 delegates to the conference, even though it was clear that delegates were supposed to pay their own way. The long, documented list of the abuse of student funds by student unions is extensive.

Taxpayers' money is badly needed in other areas of higher education. We need to create extra places for qualified students, we need to provide infrastructure for funding and research and we need to create a more internationally competitive work force. All of these things require money, and the money that is going to higher education should be used responsibly. By adopting some of the Fightback education policies, this Bill very clearly shows the people of Australia that this Government has run out of ideas in dealing with higher education.

When it is thrown out of office after the next election, this Labor Government will have left a sorry legacy. It has consistently introduced measures that have led to mediocrity rather than international standards of excellence. It has created a situation where this year 50,000 Australian students will miss out on a place in universities. It has created a bureaucratic nightmare in higher education with destructive intervention in the internal affairs of what should be autonomous institutions. It is very obvious that the Government has failed this sector.

We need to rejuvenate the higher education sector by immediately implementing the policies outlined in the Fightback document. If the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had gone to an election earlier than he plans, we would have an opportunity to bring these policies in as quickly as possible. Unfortunately, we are going to have to wait probably until the middle of next year. When we are in government, we will restore university autonomy and thereby give freedom to universities to create extra places to meet increased demand.

The Opposition's basic philosophy for education is that individuals and institutions should have the freedom to choose their own futures within very broad limitations. With freedom comes responsibility, including financial responsibility. Given that responsibility, institutions should be independent of government control or interference as far as possible. The Opposition will restore independence to universities and support increases in basic research.

Links with industry will be encouraged in a way which will enhance research opportunities rather than through the disruptive and ad hoc policies pursued by Labor. We will establish an effective student market for higher education by basing the recurrent funding of universities on a system of national education awards given to students on the basis of merit and scholarship.

The Opposition will restore universities' essential freedom to set their own courses and end the process of bureaucratically approved profiles. We will also give universities the freedom to offer additional places to Australian undergraduates beyond the government places and on their own terms. Through these innovative measures we will restore autonomy to universities and create a university system of world class standard, providing the diversity of opportunity that is required to meet the diversity of student need. Under the additional $3 billion that we are spending on education over the next seven years, there will be some hope for creating the clever country rather than the rather pale shadow that has been the sorry legacy of 10 years of ALP rule in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will confine my remarks to the implementation of clause 66 of the Higher Education Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and the Opposition's strong opposition to it. Senator Sowada and my colleague Senator Tierney have referred to the issue of voluntary student unionism. Clause 66 basically guarantees to student bodies or unions—or guilds as they are called in some States—funding from the Commonwealth or, more importantly, from the back pockets of Australian taxpayers, in the event that a State government in its wisdom decides to ensure that no campus or administration is able to impose upon students a compulsory levy, or a compulsory union due as it should more accurately be described.

PARA.TAB: I will spend some time on this matter because I want to try to convince Senator Sowada and the Australian Democrats that what they are doing is not only very bad for the rights of individual students, for institutions and for the guilds, but also it is very bad for Australian taxpayers. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin), in his second reading speech, used an argument that the justification for clause 66—that is, taking taxpayers' money and giving it to student unions in the event that membership of those unions is made non-compulsory—was that States do not have the right to interfere with the rights of institutions. Senator Sowada reinforced that point. As Senator Tierney said, perhaps unkindly, she was using tortured logic.

I want to put another piece of logic to Senator Sowada, to the Democrats and to the Government on behalf of the Opposition. In the choice of the rights of an institution and the rights of individual Australians and students, we should always choose the rights of the individual. Institutions, universities or colleges have the rights of an inanimate object—a bunch of buildings, a few ovals and some gardens—and, of course, the history and culture that goes with those institutions. Those institutions may have some rights, but when it comes to Australian politicians, and particularly senators, choosing between the rights and autonomy of an institution and the decisions made by the institution, by its governing bodies and by its administrators, and the rights of individual young Australians, they should always choose those young Australians.

By imposing a compulsory payment of a student union due, we say to that student, `You have a great choice'. As Senator Tierney said, `You either pay that student union due or you don't come and study here and you don't get your degree'. It is the same sort of choice that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, mentioned today. He quite properly implied that to put a contract in front of a person and say, `You have a choice of whether to sign it or not' under the duress of losing his job, is wrong. If we apply that sort of duress to students by forcing them to either pay a student union due or not, the choice is only theirs to the extent that if they do not want to pay it, they do not have the opportunity to further their education, to study at that university and to get a degree or a diploma.

Fundamentally, we have always thought that was wrong in principle. It is a principle which I have fought for years of my life. It is a principle that dedicated young Australians, particularly in the Australian Liberal Students Federation and the Liberal clubs around Australia, have fought for many years. It is a principle that has taken those young, particularly Liberal, students years to put into senior Party policy. It is a principle that has not been supported in the past by Liberal State governments. A former State Liberal Government in Western Australia failed to introduce voluntary student unionism. That former State Liberal Government stands condemned for not introducing it. The Greiner Liberal Government in New South Wales also failed to implement that reform. I am proud to be a member of a coalition that has voluntary student unionism in its policy platform.

I want to pass to the important principle that I hope the Democrats will turn their minds to: we are really creating a massive featherbed for student unions by the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth taxpayer basically saying, `It does not matter what happens to your organisation, it does not matter how successful you are or how well you run that organisation, we will underwrite your expenses'. Problems have occurred with NUS lately. There has been the scandal in Tasmania where I believe the NUS President has admitted to charges of stealing from the organisation and the scandal associated with the funding of the recent national women students conference which blew its budget by $40,000. These are the sorts of scandals that will happen where there is this massive featherbedding, underwriting and lack of accountability. That occurs where there is compulsory funding, which we have at the moment and, as Senator Sowada quite rightly said, where there is a voluntary voting system.

Senator Sowada, and anyone else who has been involved in campus, knows full well that involvement in the political process on campus is far less than desirable. There is usually a small bunch of activist Far Left socialists, a bunch of activist Far Right Australian Liberal students and a small handful of Democrats, Greens and all sorts of people in between. I respect each one of those groups, because people who get involved in the political process anywhere in this country, particularly on campus, do a great service to this nation and often provide future material that sooner or later ends up in this Parliament. That may or may not be a good thing and I will not reflect on that for too long.

The point I am trying to make is that where we have this featherbedding created by ensuring a source of funding to an organisation, without that organisation having to fight for that funding and go out and convince people that it is a good idea to hand over money to that particular organisation, then of course it will not be careful about how it spends that money. A result of the compulsion that has applied at so many campuses across Australia is that the fees have been going up and up, compulsorily imposed with the imprimatur, sanction and legislative force of State governments. I am told that the fees across some campuses now are upwards of $300 and $400—an enormous amount of money for a student to find.

In clause 66, we do not only have featherbedding by creating compulsion and denying individual people's rights to choose whether or not they want to join a union. We now have this Federal Government taking from the Australian taxpayer—and mark my words; it will—the money to ensure that no matter what happens with those unions, they will always be funded.

Let us take, for example, the University of Western Australia which, I believe, raised in the vicinity of $1.5m from compulsorily collected fees in the last financial year. It is not too hypothetical to suggest that if voluntary student unionism applied as it should on Australian campuses, we could have a union dominated by mad reactionary students of either the Right or the Left. It has happened from time to time. I will not be partisan about it; there could be mad reactionary students from either the Right or the Left dominating that union. We could end up with a union membership of a president in a full time paid position, a secretary and a couple of others. There could be four or five members of that union, with this Commonwealth Government underwriting that union to the tune of $1 1/2m.

That is probably taking it to the extreme, and I do not seek to enforce my argument with an extreme example, but the point I am making will naturally occur. There will be student organisations that are representative to the extent, as Senator Sowada and I agree, that they are controlled by activists of the Left, the Right or her Party, but who are not usually representative of the vast bulk of the student body. They will get control of these organisations and will no longer have to appeal to the broader student body when recruiting their membership and, indeed, when representing the will of the student body. The Commonwealth Government will reach into the back pockets of the long-suffering taxpayers of Australia and say to the unions, `Regardless of what you do, we will guarantee that funding'.
The Bill does not just say, `We will give the assistance required', or `replace the amount of money you would have collected under compulsory student unionism'. The Bill states:
(a) the institution will pay each amount of that financial assistance received by it to the student organisation concerned without undue delay; and . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Just to make sure the institution does not pocket the money and not give it to the union, the Bill states:

PARA.TAB: (b) the institution will give to the Minister, not later than 30 June next following that year, a statement by a qualified auditor, in an appropriate form, as to the amounts so paid to the organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, `We will give the institution the money. We will ensure that it is paid to the organisation and just because we do not trust the institution, we will make sure an auditor gives you the money'. The point that I have made in a long and roundabout way is that if the Government wants student unions—and the Liberal Party is not opposed to student unions; the Australian Liberal Students Federation is not opposed to student unions—to be a positive force on campus, to create a political outlet, to continue the culture of political activism on campus, then it must ensure that those unions are representative of the student body, that they fight for their survival and for membership and that they fight for the interests of the students.

PARA.TAB: The point I make, and I hope that I have convinced Senator Sowada of this, is that if the Government featherbeds these unions by ensuring that their funding is compulsory, and then further featherbeds them by ensuring that if that funding is not made compulsory it is underwritten by the Australian taxpayer, then it will ensure that that goal of student unionism is not achieved. Indeed, all that will achieve is unions that are out of touch and unrepresentative of the student body, just as we have seen in the last few days with the National Union of Students.

I will conclude by saying that the ultimate cost of this legislation to the Australian taxpayer could be upwards of $40m, depending, of course, on the rate at which campuses move to voluntary student unionism. I am sure that I am joined by all of my colleagues on this side of the chamber who wish the Opposition in Western Australia, led by Richard Court and Hendy Cowan, great luck at the next State election. We look forward to Richard Court becoming the Premier of that State and introducing voluntary student unionism as one of his first Acts of parliament, something that his father before him failed to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of his rare aberrations, Senator Campbell.

—Indeed, Senator Crichton-Browne. We also, of course, wish Dean Brown great luck for the forthcoming election in South Australia and hope that he will introduce the same policy in the South Australian Parliament when he takes government. I see Senator Baden Teague from South Australia nodding furiously in agreement. We also look forward to the New South Wales Government introducing the reform that Premier Greiner failed to introduce, and that is to introduce voluntary student unionism on New South Wales campuses.

PARA.TAB: We look forward to genuine voluntary student unionism across Australia. We look forward to student unions becoming truly representative and democratic bodies that become energised and representative of their student bodies and a proud part of Australian political life. Student unions across Australia at the moment are a joke; they are a farce; they are an outrage. They are continually dogged by scandals. The source of those scandals is, of course, the lack of accountability of those unions. The sorts of scandals we have seen in Tasmania recently are, of course, a by-product of that.

I conclude by imploring the Australian Democrats to think very carefully about the long term effects of clause 66, whether or not it is in the interests of the Australian taxpayer, whether it is in the interests of the student unions themselves, and whether or not it achieves the objectives of the Democrats. I do not think it does, so I implore them to support the Opposition's opposition to clause 66. I hope that they will join with the Opposition in voting against this clause.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Before I call on Senator West—and I apologise, Senator West—I think it is appropriate, after hearing from Senator Campbell, because it was quite clear that he did not breach Standing Orders by reading his speech, and I am quite sure that Senator West will not, knowing her usual manner, that I take the presumption of noting, without naming any names, that more and more honourable senators are reading their speeches. This is in direct contravention of standing order 187, and I remind honourable senators of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, if that was any reflection upon my speech—
—I specifically excluded you, Senator Campbell, and said that precisely because you had not read your speech I felt it was an appropriate time to make that comment.
—I want to put on the record the fact that I have not read a speech since 20 May 1990, and that was my first speech, which I did not enjoy reading one little bit.
—I shall refer to copious notes which I have spread about me, but I shall not read my speech.
—I hope I don't have to take a point of order, Senator West.

—I think that I will be quite all right. I want to address part of the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill and, in particular, the disadvantaged schools section. This section provides Commonwealth money to the States for disadvantaged schools. It is something that the Federal Minister declares on the recommendation of the State governments. The State governments determine the process whereby these recommendations are put to the Federal Government.

PARA.TAB: In New South Wales this determination is done by the use of an objective index of socioeconomic disadvantage that is based on the occupational status of parents of students at each school surveyed and which is adjusted to take into account the size of the family and the educational qualifications of the parents. That is fine rhetoric, but it does not take into consideration the distance of a school from any other facilities and the climate of the area at the time.

I refer particularly to the north-west section of New South Wales and the two schools at Bourke—Bourke Public School and Bourke High School. I also know that Tibooburra Outback School of the Air has come off the disadvantaged list, as have Hermidale Public School and Coolabah Public School.

By anybody's standards in Australia, Bourke and Tibooburra are isolated. Bourke is 400 kilometres from Dubbo. Tibooburra is another 200 or 300 kilometres further north-west of that again. Travel to such places, particularly to Tibooburra, is via unsealed roads, which are impassable when there is a small amount of rain. But these sorts of factors have not been taken into consideration.

Each individual family whose children go to the schools in Bourke was surveyed. I know from hearing media reports that the return rate of the survey at the high school was very high. The return rate at the primary school was 52 per cent. The survey was done seven months before this announcement was made. At the time the survey was done, the abattoir in Bourke was in operation. This was a temporary situation until recently. The abattoir has had a cyclical pattern of having worked, closed down for a considerable period, reopened and then closed again. This has put 120 people off the employment list.

Bourke has also seen the closure of, and reduction in number of work forces in, State Government departmental offices. This is a town with a population of 3,500 and a police force of 32. This should give some indication that Bourke is a town that is struggling to overcome a number of problems that are fairly well publicised and, I think, overemphasised by the media. But it is a town that I like very much. It is a community that is struggling to overcome its problems and one which has now found that its schools have been struck off the list for this form of assistance.For the Bourke schools to take their kids on a trip to McDonalds, which is a big treat for a lot of kids, would involve a 400-kilometre trip both ways. If it has rained, they might also have problems getting through the roads at various places.

One question on the survey asked participants whether they have full or part time work. The answer to be given was either yes or no. There was no question asking whether they had permanent work or how long since they had permanent work. In this area, there are many long term unemployed people. As I said, Bourke's population is 3,500. I suspect that nearly 50 per cent of that population is Aboriginal, and the participation rate of those people in the work force is way below the average.

The results of a survey that was done by ATSIC in the region recently showed that the participation rate for Aboriginals at the local level was 46 per cent as opposed to a national participation rate of 60 per cent. The Aboriginal population had an unemployment rate of 53 per cent, as opposed to a national rate of now 11.1 per cent; at the time, it was 10.5 per cent. Youth unemployment in the town was 67 per cent, as opposed to a national average then of 25 per cent.

These are the sorts of things that indicate to me that this is a disadvantaged town. Question 6 on the survey asked, `What is the highest educational qualification you have?'. They could choose from school, trade/technical, university or other tertiary education. It did not in any way indicate what level of school education the person might have had. I cannot think of too many people who could not say that they had not actually attained some school education, but it is no guide or assistance in judging just how good the literacy and numeracy skills are of the parents in that town. Many of the parents and guardians did not achieve educational qualifications, but in the response all they could do was give the school qualification.

The loss of the DSP to Bourke will have a significant impact both on funding and teacher numbers. It means they will lose at least one teacher, if not two, in the primary school alone. This is the sort of community that I would consider to be disadvantaged. I do not know how it has come about that the State Government could say that Bourke is not disadvantaged as opposed to Canterbury, Casino, Coffs Harbour and a few other places.

Other schools, in Broken Hill, have come off the program and others have gone on. I know that there is a need to review the situation and that there are some priorities, but I think in this case the State Government has made an almighty mistake in its survey. As I said before, this community has high unemployment rates. It is a recipient of the capital works program and has a high Aboriginal population. There is a recession and it is a wool and cotton growing area. Cotton commodity prices are not too bad, but we all know what wool prices are like—they are very low.

In addition, that area has had three years of drought. Even if the wool prices were okay, people are not able to obtain jobs and work in the wool industry. The cotton industry is also having problems, because, if there is no significant rainfall out there, there will be fewer jobs in the cotton industry as well.

I urge the Department to look very carefully at how the States arrive at the criteria they use for the selection of disadvantaged schools. I know that the States will roar and yell and each one of them will tell us that its method is the best—as they have done with every item of education that I have ever raised with a State. When I worked for the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and I suggested that there might have been a problem, each State maintained that on the education level its methods of doing things are the best.

It is an aberration that these two schools have been taken off the State list which has come to our Minister. Our Minister does not have the power, nor does this Parliament, to change that list and add schools to it. The only power the Minister has is not to declare schools on the program if an excess of students are placed on it by the States. We do not have any powers in this matter and it is of grave concern to me that the State of New South Wales can exclude schools such as Bourke Public School and Bourke Primary School from such a very important program in an area that is disadvantaged and which lives up to that name. This area is attempting to overcome its problems, but all it appears to be getting from this State Government is a slap in the face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise for only two minutes to share with Senator Campbell his strong views about compulsion to join student union associations. I think he observed that most of them are run by radicals.
—You were thinking of yourself.
—Senator Crichton-Browne a radical?
—It depends on the direction in which you are radical.

—I am radically central. I think Senator Sowada made the observation in my absence that these groups are invariably led by radicals of one type or another. I was interested to observe what the President of the University of Western Australia branch of the ALP, a Mr Keating, said when he was responding to an article in the West Australian entitled `Where have all the radicals gone?'. That article referred to the guild at the University of Western Australia and in his letter Mr Keating observed as follows:

PARA.TAB: The answer is remarkably simple—they are now running the country in Federal and State Governments. The Guild of Undergraduates' honour boards for the past 30 years now read like a who's who of Federal and State cabinets.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps that in some way buttresses what Senator Campbell had to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —It works both ways. Look at your side.

—If it works both ways, it reminds us that we ought to protect society from the tyranny of extremities, whatever direction they are coming from. The best way to ensure that is to allow people an opportunity to associate or dissociate. The legislation before us amends an Act which was first introduced in 1984 and which required that funding would not be provided to State governments unless they provided for compulsion upon students to join the unions. I think that provision is to be found in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1984. But, interestingly, it states that universities are not able and are not allowed, autonomously, to collect fees payable to the relevant institution during the time of enrolment or applying for enrolment. Certainly, they are not allowed to collect fees:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in respect of the granting of a degree, diploma or other award (including a qualification relating to a trade, technical or other skilled occupation). . .
That, of course, does not include:
. . . fees payable in respect of an organization of students, or of students and other persons, or in respect of the provision to students of amenities or services that are not of an academic nature.
In other words, the universities are not allowed to levy fees to obtain qualifications but they are allowed to levy them—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are compelled to.

—They have to compel them under this legislation. They are able to compel students to join together for the purpose of providing services, amenities and political activity. I find that curiously in contradiction of the platform of the Western Australian Labor Party which reads, inter alia:

SPEECH.PARA: Recognition and protection of fundamental political and civil rights, including freedom of expression, the press, assembly, association, conscience and religion.
In other words, the Labor Party states in its platform that it believes in the right of association or of dissociation. It is not dissimilar to the Liberal Party's platform which reads:
The Liberal Party vigorously advocates individual liberty and the right of freedom of speech, religion, organisation, assembly, procession and non-violent dissent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only difference is that we believe it.
—The difference between the two of them is that the Labor policy is compulsory whereas ours is an ideal.
—It will always remain so. The real difference is that you will never get a chance to implement it.
—Order! We are all looking to a 7.30 finish this evening.
—What happened to your two minutes?
—Mr Deputy President, as I always say, I have been provoked.
—I agree with you.
—Let me remind the Senate that article 20 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association.
(2)No-one shall be compelled to belong to an association.

This is the Government which is forever telling us how we must comply with international treaties, agreements and arrangements as well as international understanding. For centuries it has been acknowledged and accepted in Western societies that our universities should have a special inalienable freedom; that they should be institutions where the pursuit of truth is paramount—where students and academics together can question, challenge, dissect, analyse and debate without fear or favour and without concern for controls or influences outside the campus of the university.

PARA.TAB: However, interestingly, we find in Australia that a student can be denied a university qualification simply on the basis of refusing to join an association. I find that to be remarkably in conflict with the fundamental principles which are espoused by Senator Schacht every day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator `Human Rights'.
—Senator `Human Rights'. I have had drawn to my attention a document circulated by the University of Western Australia to the heads of departments, which reads in part:

PARA.TAB: The students whose names are listed in the attached advice to departments have not paid the Amenities and Services fee . . . After due warning their applications for enrolment have been cancelled.

Consequently, the students have no rights and privileges and may not attend lectures, seminars, tutorial and other classes, sit examinations or use the Library. Would you please ensure that staff request any student on this list who continues to attend classes etc. is referred to Mr D. Russell, Fees Clerk, North-West Wing of the Administration Building.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, they are black banned from the university simply because they are not prepared to join a union. I have searched my mind for a reasonable—not compelling, but a reasonable—explanation as to why there should be compulsion upon students to make contributions to their union.

PARA.TAB: It is not simply for the amenities. If it were simply for the amenities, one could give a very good economic argument why there ought not be compulsion: if the local tavern on the campus is capable of surviving, it will survive without compulsion. In fact, it will survive better without compulsion because once we have compulsion we do not have the need for efficiencies and profits. It goes past that. These students are required to contribute to a political point of view about which they might have strong diametrically opposed views.

We find that students of one political persuasion or another—it makes no difference which; it depends on who is running the show at the time—are compelled to make a financial contribution to a political point of view which does not represent theirs. I hope Senator Collins, in the short time that is available to him, will explain to this chamber, the Parliament and the wider community why students should be required to make a contribution to a political point of view which is not theirs and which they do not represent, or why they should be compelled to make a contribution to campus amenities and facilities which they may wish never to use.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will accede to Senator Crichton-Browne's invitation. Of course, it fundamentally depends on one's point of view. Senator Crichton-Browne argues trenchantly from his particular political philosophy one view and ignores some of the difficulties with the Opposition's approach to the same matter. I will touch on that. The Opposition and the Australian Democrats have raised two major concerns in their contributions to the debate on the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and other Bills which cut across the schools and higher education sectors—equality and cost effectiveness. This Government stands by its record over the last 10 years. We have delivered massive improvements in both quality and cost effectiveness in both sectors.

PARA.TAB: In the schools sector this is evidenced by major improvements in the retention rates. The retention rate to year 12 is continuing to increase across Australian schools, and in 1991 reached 66.9 per cent and 81.6 per cent for government and non-government schools respectively. The overall retention rate of 71.3 per cent for 1991 has exceeded the retention target set by the Government of 65 per cent by the early 1990s.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's because they can't get a job.
—Not only are more of our young people staying on to year 12, but the quality of teaching and learning that they are experiencing in school has also improved over the same period.
—Senator Collins, you obviously didn't write that.

—Although the Commonwealth does not run any schools, we believe it is in the national interest to promote the provision of a high quality education system by enhancing, where possible, the raw material of schooling—namely, the school curriculum. I will respond to those interjections—my only response to interjections that I will allow myself during this debate, because we want to get out of here—by saying that I take exception to the messages contained in those interjections. It is a popular myth that the quality of school education today is not a patch on what it used to be years ago. The fact is that the quality of schools and teaching has improved out of sight and is continuing to improve, as is acknowledged by most parents who take an interest in schools.

PARA.TAB: I was a member of the Catholic Education Council in the Northern Territory for some years and I have had active participation in COGSO. It is often acknowledged by parents who take an interest in schools that this common myth that educational standards are declining and things were better 20 years ago is a piece of nonsense.

Educational reform in this country is complex and requires extensive consultation with all concerned. We are not interested in going down the path of the Kennett Government in abolishing school communities with little warning and imposing change without any consultation. At the historic meeting in Tasmania in 1989 the Australian Education Council agreed to develop a national curriculum framework for Australian schools. That decision—the Hobart declaration on schooling—started a process which will see the development of high quality curriculum materials through to the next century. To this end, over the past four years this Government has been working together with State governments and non-government education authorities to develop national curriculum frameworks.

I should say at the outset that there is nothing compulsory about this exercise. We are not in a position, even if we wanted to be—which we do not—to impose a central curriculum on Australian schools. National curriculum development is in every sense a cooperative endeavour. Participation in its development and the use of the final product are entirely voluntary at state system and even at school level.

As part of the reform agenda, the Federal Government has also established a national project on the quality of teaching and learning to promote the delivery of quality teaching to our school students and to enhance the status of the teaching profession in the eyes of the community. The other key part of the reform agenda lies in the post-compulsory area. The Mayer committee report on key competencies, released on 23 November 1992, outlines a plan for action which will enable all of our young people to acquire essential employment related key competencies which will allow them to participate effectively in the work force. The States have already agreed to further collaborative work with the Commonwealth in this significant area.

In the schools sector, the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1992 sets the framework for continuing to improve the quality and cost effectiveness of Australian schooling. Under our new schools funding policies, the only limitations on growth in the non-government sector result from the application of principles of sound educational planning. These principles, represented by the new schools policy, require new non-government schools to be established in areas where there are sufficient potential students to justify a new school.

The steady increase in funded enrolments in non-government schools over the last decade makes an absolute mockery of the accusation levelled by our opponents that the new schools policy is used to restrict growth in non-government schools. Between 1980 and 1991 enrolment in non-government schools grew by 190,000 students, or 29 per cent. The non-government system's share of the total school population increased from 22 per cent in 1980 to 28 per cent in 1991.

The new schools policy is first and foremost a policy to enhance planned educational provision and, as such, enjoys widespread support among non-government schools. I can well understand why some non-government schools are horrified by proposals in the Fightback document to abolish the new schools policy and provide Federal funding to every new or expanding non-government school, regardless of where it proposes to set up. Under such a strategy, existing non-government schools would have no protection from rival schools in receipt of Federal funding opening up in the same neighbourhood. But this Government has also addressed a number of issues which do not figure in the Opposition's rhetoric—issues such as equity, stability and security.

The Bill provides the framework for the establishment of a national equity program for schools which will focus on improved outcomes for students facing educational disadvantage and provide greater flexibility for education systems in their use of these funds. In return, we are asking the States to provide a range of data on educational outcomes for these students. These two Bills provide ongoing stability and security for all Australian schools. This security and stability in funding is something that both government and non-government schools have come to expect and enjoy under this Federal Labor Government.

Recognising that all schools need to plan ahead, we announced school funding levels eight years in advance, the first four years of which are guaranteed in legislation. These Bills detail the funding levels for both government and non-government schools through the years 1993 to 1996. This Government would like to see the continuation, through to the year 2000, of the stability and security which have characterised funding over the past eight years. We are genuinely concerned that the effective collapse of needs based funding advocated by our opponents will reopen the state aid debate and threaten the viability of the whole non-government sector. For its part, the Federal Government will continue to defend the dual system of education which recognises the right of parents to choose schools which reflect their values and which funds all non-government schools on the basis of need.

Turning to the higher education sector, this Bill is an important manifestation of this Government's commitment to higher education. This commitment encompasses not only the dedication of massive resources but also the determination to achieve an education system which is both accessible and of the highest quality.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many couldn't get into university?

—Senator Walters should go and have a cup of tea, a Bex and a good lie down. The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill provides $3,745m for higher education in 1995, the third year of the new funding triennium, 1993-95. This represents this Government's continuing commitment to the achievement of a quality higher education system. The Government created 85,000 new places in higher education between 1989 and 1994, including an additional 5,645 places in 1993 and 1994. Post-graduate research awards now total 1,500 per year.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague acknowledged the level of resources provided for higher education but questioned whether this represented value for money and cast doubt on the quality of the provision. This Bill includes the provision of $76m each year from 1994 to be allocated amongst universities which demonstrate effective performance in quality management. These funds were part of a package of initiatives announced by the Government in 1991 to enhance and improve quality in higher education, including the establishment of a committee for the advancement of university teaching. An additional $4m is being allocated in 1993 to fund successful applications for teaching development grants.

Senator Teague also questioned the quality of the open learning initiative. Senator Tierney, on earlier occasions, has called the open learning initiative `a cheap political gimmick'. In fact, open learning is a quality response to a growing need for more flexible access and to provision of tertiary education at a time of continuing strong demand. The Government is providing substantial support, to the tune of $47m, to ensure that this initiative is put on a solid financial and educational footing. The Government has decided to further improve access to open learning by offering a deferred payment arrangement to some students, although details of this arrangement have yet to be determined. I was pleased to note the Australian Democrats' support for this approach.

Senator Sowada did, however, sound a warning note about overseas students and the need to ensure that quality of provision is maintained, with adequate grievance procedures for individual students. This Government recognises that quality in education is crucial to Australia's participation in international education. In addition to the quality measures I have mentioned, specific measures have been taken to ensure that our standing is maintained in international education.

While most international educational activity must be and is carried out by the institutions, the government plays a coordinating and supporting role. The introduction of the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991 helped stabilise the industry by providing both financial regulation and quality assurance for international students in Australian institutions.

Perhaps the most serious accusation levelled by the Opposition is that the proposed HEFA amendment to protect financial support for student representative organisations is an attack on the civil liberties of the Australian higher education students. This Government considers that it is an important feature of university autonomy that higher education institutions should be able to make their own decisions about the imposition of fees for student services and amenities.

The Government objects to proposals to interfere with that autonomy. The Opposition would prevent institutions from insisting on students paying a student union fee, thus depriving universities of some $200m in revenue and, unless the Commonwealth meets the funding shortfall, depriving students of a range of services, such as counselling, health, sport, careers advice and amenities. I am pleased to note the Democrats' support for this amendment and their recognition of the essential services that are provided by student unions.

On the other hand, the Opposition would be quite happy to allow universities to charge any other fees they wish. A fee for service provided by a university itself would be acceptable to the Opposition but an identical fee for an identical service provided by a student organisation would not. The Opposition's real aim—an obvious aim, as evidenced by the contributions to the debate; that is, the political destruction of student representative organisations—is all too apparent.

This brings me to the major problem with the Opposition's higher education policy—the impact of fees in conjunction with its voucher scheme. Those policies would fail to have any significant impact on the various problems mentioned in the Opposition's amendment. In particular, there could be no significant impact on unmet demand. How many unsuccessful applicants could afford places in a university? Instead, Opposition policies would make access to higher education a matter of ability to pay rather than ability to succeed.

Finally, the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill provides $241m of Commonwealth assistance to State, Territory, non-government and independent Aboriginal education providers over the 1993-95 triennium. While a relatively small amount of money compared with the other Bills that are here today, it is important to note that this assistance provides the underpinning for the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy—a key agreement between all governments to improve access to, and participation in, education by the indigenous people of Australia.

I know from conversations that I had with Geoff Spring, the then Secretary of the Department of Education in the Northern Territory who I think has gone on to higher things in Victoria, how much the Northern Territory Department of Education valued the completion of this national policy on Aboriginal education. I know of the strong support that the Northern Territory Government gave it.

The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody found that education is a key element in overcoming the economic and social disadvantage faced by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The 13 per cent increase in funding over the current triennium that this Bill represents is a commitment from this Government to increasing educational opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
The Government will be opposing the second reading amendments moved by the Opposition for the reasons I have just given.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: In respect of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992:

TAB.TAB: Omit all words after "research infrastructure".

PARA.TAB: In respect of the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1992:

TAB.TAB: Omit all words after `international levels".

In order to gain majority support for at least some element of the Opposition amendments, we will not oppose the Democrat amendments. We would, of course, expect the Democrats to support the amended form of the amendments that I have moved.
—The first Bill that the Senate will consider is the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2). The question is that Senator Sowada's amendment to Senator Teague's amendment be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 66 should be deleted from the Bill, and the remainder of the Bill be adopted. The principle involved is that this chamber ought to ensure that there is freedom of association in Australia, including amongst students at universities. In the case of student unions, we have never seen legislation such as is represented by clause 66. It directly transgresses the principle of freedom of association, and the Liberal and National parties oppose it.

PARA.TAB: I referred briefly to this in my contribution to the second reading debate, as did my colleagues Senator Tierney, Senator Campbell and Senator Crichton-Browne. As Senator Collins said, we are aware that there is a difference of view in this matter. I do not accept the Minister's aspersion that the Liberal and National parties are doing this only for pragmatic political reasons, such as to deny funds to left wing student unions that would be using their resources politically against my parties. I genuinely believe in the principle that, as we profess in all of our human rights statements, and as we profess in both the major Party platforms and I think the Democrats do as well, we should have this kind of freedom of association.

Secondly, I believe that it is the right of State parliaments to legislate for freedom of association in student unions, and by taking this clause 66 measure we are rejecting that right. In practice, it will give power to the Minister in the Commonwealth to override any decision made by a State parliament, such as is the case pending in New South Wales and as may be the case, given the policies of the Liberal and National parties, in the other States.

Thirdly, I refer to those who would put the argument that a number of amenities are provided in universities which depend upon the student union fee. There is a way around this and that is to divide those activities supported by student union fees at the moment which are universal or of an amenity kind, from those that are controversial and where there can be conscientious objection. I think it would be without offence to at least the majority of Australians that the amenities be provided. But it is against the consciences of the majority of Australians to be forced to pay moneys for controversial political activities, or to support publications which may be quite contrary to the moral views of some of the students so cajoled into joining and paying such money.

I believe that this is the major way to answer those who raise that argument about our sporting associations, drama associations, places of meeting, even indeed the provision of facilities such as toilets. I remember that at the University of Adelaide the principal toilets used by students were, in fact, in the student union. This is a facility which is only allowed to be kept open, if you like, by union fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would stop that.

—I say to Senator Tate that such facilities must be available to students—indeed, to the whole community of persons at the university. There are ways then of sensibly overcoming this problem. I acknowledge that there are those who would argue that drama and sport ought to be entirely voluntary and that the university ought not to require a payment with respect to sport and drama. I happen not to be of that view. The area that I oppose—that is, in addition to a facilities fee—is that of the controversial, political and other activities of such a student association.

PARA.TAB: The fourth matter I wish to refer to is the blatant hypocrisy of the Government. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, in the second reading speech argued that he was actually protecting the university from the intrusion of the State government. I must move on quickly as I see the clock is moving towards 7.30 p.m.

I wish to note and remind the Senate that on 18 December 1990—two years ago—a similar measure was initiated by this Government, and it was rejected by the Senate by one vote. I wish to appeal very briefly to those who voted with me and the Liberal and National parties at that time. Senator Harradine, Senator Kernot and Senator Lees had the courage of their convictions and voted for the motion that I moved, which was successful and which saw the end of the Government proposal at that time. Senator Sowada, who is in the chamber, is new; she was not here then; Senator Chamarette, too, is new and was not here then. I appeal to all those I have named especially to vote with the Liberal and National parties on the amendment I have just proposed to ensure that we have freedom of association. Indeed, I appeal to all honourable senators to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be strongly opposing this amendment. Senator Teague has left out some important matters, one of which, of course, is that the major function of student unions is not to provide controversial student activity—and they do not. They, in fact, provide about $200m worth of services to students across Australia, in terms of such things as counselling and child care—and, of course, I am personally familiar with the operation of these student unions. If this amendment were carried here in the Committees, those activities would have to be either abandoned or replaced by additional calls on the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: But as I have pointed out—and it does not have to be gone over again in any detail—those opposite have a very convenient policy on all of this. They have no difficulty with the universities charging any fees they like. In fact, that is their policy. They put themselves in the situation where it is okay for a university to levy a fee to provide a service at a particular price, but it is not okay for a student union to do the same. This would be a terrible disruption to invaluable services that are provided by these organisations. The Government strongly opposes this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be opposing the amendment proposed by the Opposition. In so doing, I would simply like to respond to some of the issues that were raised by speakers on the Opposition side during the second reading debate on the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2). It has been suggested by some that this is an attack on freedom of association. But what the Opposition has failed to mention is that over 60 per cent of tertiary institutions already have conscientious objection clauses in their by-laws—that is, some form of opt-out clause which will enable students, if they have an objection to joining a student union, to opt out of membership.

PARA.TAB: That is a right which is enshrined in many by-laws in universities around Australia. We would hope that the figure would be very much greater now than it was when that 1990 survey into the issue was done. Given the controversy generated by this issue, it is my understanding that many university councils have sought—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate for more than a few minutes. I wanted to recognise that today is the twentieth anniversary of the election of the Whitlam Labor Government on 2 December 1972, when I had the honour to be elected for the first time to this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: This is an important date in Australia's history, and particularly in the history of the Australian Labor Party. I hasten to assure the Senate that I will not go into a long dissertation of memoirs of that election night or of the period of the Whitlam Government. I will not be accused of wallowing in the past. But it is a significant day that deserves a brief mention so that such an anniversary does not pass unmarked.

The place of politics in Australian life made a quantum leap at that election. It began for so many people a period of hope and pride in Australia, the development of open government and all sorts of policies of which Australia can be proud. Of course, the truth of that period is somewhere between the rosy view that Gough Whitlam himself would take and the highly critical view that his and his Government's detractors would take.

I just want to place on record my pride in having been part of that era which established so much and set in train other policies which were implemented later. In current days, as this twentieth anniversary is recognised, various commentaries have made a comparison with the Kennett Government in Victoria. People are saying that Mr Kennett is moving just as swiftly as Mr Whitlam did in December 1972.

The significant difference is that, in the case of the Whitlam Labor Government in December 1972, it was a matter of implementing the Australian Labor Party's program as clearly enunciated in the election campaign and for many months before that. It was a question of implementing an openly known program and sticking to the policies that had been presented to the people.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 14 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to a recent postcard protest relating to koalas directed to the Australian Embassy in Washington DC and the Australian Consulate-General in New York and certain correspondence and advice on how to handle the protest which was disseminated by Peter Fuller, Public Affairs Officer, Americans and Europe Division, Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, from whom did Mr Fuller obtain his briefing information on koalas.

(2) (a) What is the relationship between the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Australian Koala Foundation (AKF) and its American Group, Friends of the Australian Koala Foundation; (b) why is the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade distributing information from the AKF to its North American Embassies; and (c) has any representative of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade actually visited the office of the Friends of the Australian Koala Foundation and checked its bona fides.

(3) Why has the Consul (Public Affairs) New York refused to reply to two letters from Australians for Animals in which the Co-ordinator has sought to find an explanation for the many inconsistencies and untruths distributed by the Consulate-General's office in New York.

(4) Why has the Australian Embassy in Washington consulted with Dr Ken Phillips of the NSW Koala Protection Society over the koala protest in the United States and why did the Embassy of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade draft a letter on behalf of the New South Wales Koala Protection Society for distribution to concerned Americans.
(5) Why did the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade personnel, Brett Bayly and Peter Fuller, brief Ms Deborah Tabart of the Australian Koala Foundation on the United States protest.
(6) Why are the Australian Embassy in Washington DC and the Consulate-General in New York providing misleading and incorrect information on the koala to the American public.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Mr Fuller obtained his briefing information from a number of sources, principally officers of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service in Canberra, field, regional and headquarters staff of the NSW, Victorian and Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Services, staff of Taronga Park Zoo, and staff of the Universities of New South Wales and Queensland, the Australian Koala Foundation and Coffs Harbour City Council.

(2) (a) There is no formal relationship between the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Australian Koala Foundation and its American organisation, Friends of the Australian Koala Foundation.

(2) (b) The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade does not distribute Australian Koala Foundation information to its North American posts, although examples of AKF publications and information sheets have been occasionally sent to these posts on an advisory basis.

(2) (c) No. However, the Australian Koala Foundation is a non-profit organisation, based in Queensland, which funds koala research and conservation. As a company limited by guarantee, it is subject to scrutiny by the Australian Securities Commission. The AKF raises funds through sponsorship, promotions and private donations and has devoted more than half a million dollars to research since its inception in 1986. Friends of the Australian Koala Foundation is an agency of the AKF in New York which is staffed by an AKF employee.

(3) The Consul (Public Affairs) New York believes that Ms Sue Arnold, Co-ordinator of the Australians for Animals, did not ask for a response, other than in a rhetorical sense. He also did not wish to enter into an acrimonious correspondence.

(4) Dr Ken Phillips is an authority on the scientific research involving koalas and the Australian Embassy in Washington has consulted him several times. He is the Executive Director in the US of the Koala Preservation Society of NSW. The society runs a well-regarded hospital for koalas at Port Macquarie. Dr Phillips is an adjunct Professor at New York University and formerly a teacher at Harvard University. The embassy did not draft a letter on behalf of the NSW Koala Protection Society. Dr Phillips sent a draft letter to the Counsellor (Public Affairs), Mr Christopher Sweeney, at the embassy asking for Mr Sweeney's comments. The letter, which was not distributed, contained Dr Phillips's views about the US allegations of mistreatment of koalas in Australia.

(5) Messrs Fuller and Bayly discussed the koala protest in the US with Ms Tabart as part of a broad exchange of information between the parties concerned. The discussion covered a variety of aspects of the welfare, treatment and conservation status of koalas. As Executive Director of the AKF, Ms Tabart has extensive knowledge of the issues involved.

(6) The Australian Embassy in Washington DC and Consulate-General in New York are not providing misleading information to the American public. Any ambiguities or errors of detail identified in earlier responses have now been amended.
