TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 19 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of reports from the Sudan that two foreign aid workers have been killed by deserters from the Sudan People's Liberation Army, and that two other aid workers are missing.
(2) Can any further information about this incident be provided.

(3) What is the Australian Government's attitude to the conflict in Sudan, in particular: (a) what representations has the Government made to the Government of the Sudan; (b) what representations has the Government made in the United Nations; (c) does the Government support the exercise of the rights of the people of Southern Sudan towards self-determination, as provided in the United Nations' charter; and (d) what aid and assistance can the Government provide for those left injured, homeless or orphaned by the war in the Sudan.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) A United Nations employee of Burmese nationality and a Norwegian journalist were killed in southern Sudan in late September. The bodies of two other aid workers, a Kenyan man and a Filipina woman, kidnapped at the same time, were found later. The Kenyan worked for UNICEF and the Filipina was a nurse with the non-government organisation (NGO) Interaid. The Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) claimed that a breakaway faction was responsible for the deaths but the UN declared that it held the SPLA in general responsible. It was the first time aid workers had been killed by the rebels in southern Sudan since 1987. The four died of gunshot wounds but the UN reported that they had not been caught in crossfire as the SPLA had claimed. The UN's Operation Lifeline Sudan suspended relief efforts in the area involved after the bodies were found.

The four foreigners were killed at the time of the defection of a senior commander of the Torit faction led by John Garang. The defector, William Nyuon, had formed a third splinter group (apart from Torit and Nasir). The unofficial SPLA representative in Cairo told our Embassy there that Nyuon's splinter group was responsible for the executions. According to the representative, Nyuon split from Torit with the intention of mounting a coup d'etat against Garang. When the coup failed, Nyuon and his followers went to a UN camp where they demanded food. The two UN officials on duty explained to the group that the food was available only for southern Sudanese civilians whose livelihoods had been destroyed during the war. Nyuon ordered his bodyguards to shoot the two officials. The two witnesses to the shootings were kidnapped and later killed.

The latest information from our High Commission in Nairobi is that responsibility for the deaths has not yet been formally established, with the Torit and Nyuon factions blaming each other. A UN investigative team headed by Assistant Secretary-General Abdou Ciss visited Kenya and southern Sudan in October. The team interviewed UN and NGO personnel as well as representatives of the various factions of the SPLA. The report has been submitted to the Secretary-General but has not yet been released.

(3) (a) The Australian Government deplores the killings and shares the serious concerns of the international community for the innocent people affected by the civil war in Sudan. We have made representations to the Government of Sudan concerning the human rights situation, in particular, the grave human rights crisis in Juba, southern Sudan. Following the receipt of a report from Amnesty International in September on the human rights situation in Juba, our Embassy in Cairo made representations to the Sudanese Government, conveying the Australian Government's deep concern over the allegations. The Sudanese Government has not yet responded to our representations. I also raised Australia's concerns about human rights abuses, including detention without trial and the displacement of people from their homes, when I met the Sudanese Ambassador to Australia (resident in Kuala Lumpur) in May.

(b) Although Australia has not made any representations on the Sudanese conflict in the United Nations, we have asked our missions in New York and Geneva to provide information on the international community's reaction to the increasingly serious situation in Sudan, and what plans are underway to prevent it escalating further. In this context the United Nations Under-Secretary General for Humanitarian Affairs, Mr Jan Eliason, visited Sudan in mid-September to review humanitarian affairs there. Following his discussions with the Sudanese Government, 21 new air corridors for relief supplies have been agreed upon. The number of non-government organisations operating in Sudan has also been increased from 26 to 46. A follow-up visit by a member of Mr Eliason's staff is planned shortly and will include a visit to the Nuba mountains to assess the situation there.

Australia participated in a critical review of the human rights situation in Sudan at CHR 48 in 1992 under the confidential procedures of the Commission on Human Rights. The human rights situation in Sudan remains under consideration by the Commission and will be examined under this procedure at CHR 49 which will be held in Geneva from l February to 12 March 1993.

(c) Australia has consistently supported work in the United Nations to give effect to the right of self-determination of peoples throughout the world. We take the view that the right is not limited in time to the process of decolonisation nor is it accomplished by a single act or exercise. Rather it entails the continuing right of all peoples and individuals within each state to participate fully in the political process by which they are governed. Enhancing popular participation in this decision-making is an important factor in realising the right to self-determination and enabling the full enjoyment of human rights.
We encourage the Sudanese Government and people to resolve their difficulties and differences in accordance with this general principle having regard to the right of political participation.

(d) In the last financial year, the Australian Government contributed $4,570,973 to UN agencies and NGOs which operate in Sudan. On 10 November 1992 the Government announced an emergency aid package to Sudan totalling $2,520,000. As in previous years assistance will be channelled through international and Australian agencies and will include relief supplies, supplementary feeding, medical assistance and support for airlift operations. A large proportion of Australia's assistance has and will continue to be earmarked for people injured or left homeless by the war in Sudan.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 26 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of reports from the Red Cross that they are no longer able to provide money to people in East Timor who want to lodge emigration applications?
(2) Does the problem lie in the fact that intended recipients of the funds are unable to withdraw the money from bank accounts?
(3) How can Australians offer financial assistance to people who want to leave East Timor through normal channels?
(4) Will the Minister be raising this issue with the appropriate authorities in Indonesia?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am not aware of any such reports from the Red Cross. The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) in Jakarta and the Australian Red Cross Society have advised officials from my Department that they also are not aware of any such reports and that, in any event, they do not attempt to provide money to East Timorese who want to lodge emigration applications.
(2) Enquiries by my Department have revealed no evidence of any general problems with intending East Timorese emigrants accessing their bank accounts.
(3) There would seem therefore to be nothing stopping Australians sending money through normal channels to individuals in East Timor who want to emigrate.

(4) If the honourable Senator would like to provide me with more details about these reports I would be happy to follow them up and raise the issue with Indonesian authorities if there is any substance to them.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs upon notice on 26 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the letter that former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Gerry Hand) wrote to Isobel in September 1989 regarding the Old Swan Brewery site, where he, in part, stated ". . . the Perth Aboriginal community, of course, may apply to me under the Act in the future, should they consider that the site is endangered", I ask:
(1) Has the Minister received any request from Aboriginal or other persons or groups to reimpose a protection order on the old Swan Brewery site?
(2) What action has the Minister taken in response to any requests?
(3) In view of the work and disturbance at the site, if no action has been taken, can the Minister explain the delay?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister for Aboriginal And Torres Strait Islander Affairs has received three applications from Aboriginal persons, under the provisions of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 (the Act), for the protection of the old Swan Brewery site in Perth.

(2) In line with his obligations under the Act the Minister wrote to the Hon Judyth Watson, Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in Western Australia, to determine what action, if any, she intended to take to protect the site. The Minister also considered whether the State's actions had breached an agreement, concerning the administration of the State Aboriginal Heritage Act 1972, entered into by the Commonwealth and State Governments in 1989.

(3) After having consulted with the Western Australian Government and with his Cabinet colleagues the Minister has decided to decline to make a declaration under the Act preventing the redevelopment of the site.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 9 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which department and which division has the responsibility for the area of 1680 square metres of office space in the Edmund Barton Building recently relinquished by the Australian Fisheries Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The building is owned by the Commonwealth and managed by Australian Estate Management.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 10 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: Will the Government conduct a review of the guidelines for new bleached eucalypt kraft mills prior to the 1994 review date, considering the rapid changing in pulping technology around the world; if not, what steps is the Government taking to safeguard the future international competitiveness of new mills that may be built in Australia by writing totally chlorine-free guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: No. The National Pulp and Paper Research Program is building up knowledge base on the environmental impacts, monitoring systems and production processes for eucalypt kraft pulping and bleaching systems. The Program is also investigating alternative technologies and the information generated will form an objective basis for the review of the guidelines at the scheduled time.

A bleached eucalypt kraft mill meeting the current guidelines will cause no known ecologically detrimental impacts. The guidelines are and will remain based on the best available technology economically achievable.
